llm_message:
A1
Quote: "The aim of this study is to assess the influence of surgeon specialization on outcomes following appendectomy in children."
Reasoning: The research question is clearly stated in the abstract.
[Yes]

A2
Quotes: "Two authors searched Medline and Embase to identify relevant studies. Eligible studies were comparative and provided data on children who had appendicectomy while under the care of general or pediatric surgical teams."
"Two authors initially screened titles and abstracts and then full text manuscripts were examined. Pooled risk ratios and pooled mean differences were used in analysis."
Reasoning: The authors mention two authors performing study selection and data extraction independently.
[Yes]

A3
Quotes: "Two authors searched Medline and Embase to identify relevant studies."
"A total of 1841 citations were extracted from the searches."
Reasoning: The authors searched two major electronic databases.
[No] - They did not mention any supplementary search strategies.

Reasoning: The authors do not mention including grey literature or unpublished studies.
[No]

A5
Reasoning: The authors do not provide a list of included and excluded studies.
[No]

A6
Quote: "Characteristics of the 9 included studies8,11–18 are shown in Table 1 and results from the studies are provided in Table 2."
Reasoning: The characteristics of included studies are provided in table format.
[Yes]

A7
Quote: "The methodological quality of the included studies was assessed using the Newcastle-Ottawa Scale."
Reasoning: The authors used the Newcastle-Ottawa Scale to assess study quality.
[Yes]

A8
Reasoning: The authors do not appear to have incorporated the methodological quality assessment into the analysis or conclusions.
[No]

A9
Reasoning: This systematic review did not perform a meta-analysis or data synthesis.
[NA]

A10

[NA] - Assessing publication bias is not relevant as no meta-analysis was performed.

A11
Reasoning: The authors do not report the funding sources of the included studies.
[No]

P1
Quote: "Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis on the Influence of Surgeon Specialization on Outcomes Following Appendicectomy in Children"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2
Quote: See the structured abstract on page 1
Reasoning: The article provides a structured abstract with labeled sections covering the key elements.
[Yes]

P3
Quote: "Appendicitis is the most common pediatric surgical emergency.1 There are in excess of 40,000 cases in England annually1 and its incidence is about 9.4 cases per 10,000 patient years.2 In 2010, the Global Burden of Disease Study estimated that appendicitis causes 19 years of life lost per 100,000 population and 21 disability adjusted life years per 100,000 population globally;3 therefore, it is important that we strive to improve the management of appendicitis."
Reasoning: The introduction provides rationale and context for the review.
[Yes]

P4
Quote: "The aim of this study is to assess the influence of surgeon specialization on outcomes following appendectomy in children."
Reasoning: The aim/objective is explicitly stated, though without full PICOS details.
[Yes]

P5
Reasoning: The authors do not mention a review protocol or registration.
[No]

P6
Quote: "Eligible studies were comparative and provided data on children who had appendicectomy while under the care of general or pediatric surgical teams."
Reasoning: The eligibility criteria are briefly described.
[Yes]

P7
Quote: "Two authors searched Medline and Embase to identify relevant studies. Eligible studies were comparative and provided data on children who had appendicectomy while under the care of general or pediatric surgical teams."
Reasoning: The databases searched are stated but the dates of coverage and date last searched are not provided.
[No]

P8
Reasoning: The authors do not present the full search strategy.
[No]

P9
Quote: "Two authors initially screened titles and abstracts and then full text manuscripts were examined."
Reasoning: The study selection process is described.
[Yes]

P10
Quote: "Two authors using an electronic spreadsheet. Pooled risk ratios and pooled mean differences were used in analysis."
Reasoning: The data extraction process is described.
[Yes]

P11
Reasoning: The authors do not explicitly list all the variables for which data were sought.
[No]

P12
Quote: "The methodological quality of the included studies was assessed using the Newcastle-Ottawa Scale."
Reasoning: The use of the Newcastle-Ottawa Scale for assessing risk of bias is mentioned.
[Yes]

P13
Quote: "Pooled risk ratios and pooled mean differences were used to evaluate the effect of treatment by general surgery units or pediatric surgery units on dichotomous and continuous outcomes, respectively."
Reasoning: The principal summary measures are stated.
[Yes]

P14
Reasoning: This systematic review did not perform a meta-analysis.
[NA]

P15
Reasoning: The authors do not mention assessing risk of bias across studies.
[NA] - Not relevant as no meta-analysis was performed.

P16
Reasoning: The authors do not mention any additional analyses.
[NA] - Not relevant as no meta-analysis was performed.

P17
Quote: "A total of 1841 citations were extracted from the searches. Two authors initially screened titles and abstracts and then full text manuscripts were examined. Nine of the studies8,11–18 were prospective cohort studies and 18 was a prospective cohort study."
Reasoning: The number of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included are provided, but a flow diagram is not included.
[No]

P18
Quote: "Characteristics of the 9 included studies8,11–18 are shown in Table 1 and results from the studies are provided in Table 2."
Reasoning: The characteristics of included studies are provided with citations.
[Yes]

P19
Quote: "The methodological quality of the included studies was assessed using the Newcastle-Ottawa Scale."
Reasoning: The use of the Newcastle-Ottawa Scale suggests risk of bias was assessed, but the risk of bias data for each study is not presented.
[No]

P20
Reasoning: The results for each individual study are not presented.
[No]

P21
Reasoning: This systematic review did not perform a meta-analysis.
[NA]

P22
Reasoning: The authors do not present any assessment of risk of bias across studies.
[NA] - Not relevant as no meta-analysis was performed.

P23
Reasoning: The authors do not report any additional analyses.
[NA] - Not relevant as no meta-analysis was performed.

P24
Quote: "We found that children who were managed by specialized pediatric surgery teams had lower rates of negative appendicectomy although mean length of stay was longer in this group."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized.
[Yes]

P25
Quote: "The main limitation of our review is our exclusive search strategy which included a detailed gray literature search. It yielded a large number of eligible studies and patients. We focused on patient important outcomes and we extracted and presented data on a wide range of important baseline factors."
Reasoning: The authors discuss limitations of the review.
[Yes]

P26
Quote: "We wish to encourage future research through the use of large-scale prospective multicenter registries."
Reasoning: The authors provide a general interpretation and implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27
Reasoning: The authors do not describe sources of funding for the systematic review.
[No]

P1
"Minimally invasive adrenalectomy in children"
The title identifies the article as a review on minimally invasive adrenalectomy in children.
[Yes]

P2
"Purpose: Minimally invasive adrenalectomy (MIA) is the criterion standard for removal of small adrenal tumors in adults. The purpose of this review was to determine the place of MIA in children. Methods: The authors conducted a systematic review of the pediatric and adult literature about MIA, focusing on the technique and indications. Results: Minimally invasive adrenalectomy appears superior to open adrenalectomy for small tumors. The potential advantages of MIA are appealing for postoperative pain, risk of intestinal obstruction, and quality of scars. The most common approach is the transperitoneal lateral laparoscopy, which allows for a large working space. For small tumors or for bilateral adrenalectomy, the prone retroperitoneoscopy is a promising new technique. In children, the learning curve is an issue because the indications are rare. The most common indication is neuroblastoma without image-defined surgical risk factors. The incidence of local recurrence is low, but the follow-up is short in most cases. Conclusions: Minimally invasive adrenalectomy is promising for removal of small adrenal tumors. Long-term follow-up is required to evaluate the efficacy of MIA in neuroblastomas. Benign diseases are excellent candidates for this minimally invasive technique."

P1
"Minimally invasive adrenalectomy in children"
The title identifies the article as a review on minimally invasive adrenalectomy in children.
[Yes]

P2
"Purpose: Minimally invasive adrenalectomy (MIA) is the criterion standard for removal of small adrenal tumors in adults. The purpose of this review was to determine the place of MIA in children. Methods: The authors conducted a systematic review of the pediatric and adult literature about MIA, focusing on the technique and indications. Results: Minimally invasive adrenalectomy appears superior to open adrenalectomy for small tumors. The potential advantages of MIA are appealing for postoperative pain, risk of intestinal obstruction, and quality of scars. The most common approach is the transperitoneal lateral laparoscopy, which allows for a large working space. For small tumors or for bilateral adrenalectomy, the prone retroperitoneoscopy is a promising new technique. In children, the learning curve is an issue because the indications are rare. The most common indication is neuroblastoma without image-defined surgical risk factors. The incidence of local recurrence is low, but the follow-up is short in most cases. Conclusions: Minimally invasive adrenalectomy is promising for removal of small adrenal tumors. Long-term follow-up is required to evaluate the efficacy of MIA in neuroblastomas. Benign diseases are excellent candidates for this minimally invasive technique."
The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, methods, results and conclusions.
[Yes]

llm_message:
A1
Quote: "Purpose: To further explore the feasibility and safety of laparoscopic pyeloplasty (LP) in children with ureteropelvic junction obstruction compared with open pyeloplasty (OP). Methods: PUBMED, Web of science and Cochrane library were searched until Oct. 2014 to find eligible studies."
Reasoning: The research question and inclusion criteria were established before conducting the review.
[Yes]

A2
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors did not mention using at least two independent data extractors or a consensus procedure for disagreements.
[No]

A3
Quote: "PUBMED, Web of science and Cochrane library was carried out between Jan. 1966 and Oct. 2014 to identify eligible studies, using the following words: "hydronephrosis OR ureteropelvic junction obstruction OR pyeloplasty", "young OR children OR child OR kids OR pediatrics" and "laparoscopic"."
Reasoning: At least two electronic databases were searched with keywords provided, but no supplementary search strategies were mentioned.
[No]

A4
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors did not state that they searched for reports regardless of publication type or whether any reports were excluded based on publication status or language.
[No]

A5
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: A list of included and excluded studies was not provided.
[No]

A6
Quote: "290 publications from all above database were retrieved after removing duplicates. Among these studies, 37 studies were finally leaved behind for full-text assessment. Detailed steps of literature search were shown in Figure 1."
Reasoning: Some characteristics of included studies were provided in aggregate form in Tables 1-3, but not the full ranges of characteristics like age, sex, disease severity, etc.
[No]

A7
Quote: "Criteria for inclusion and exclusion
Studies regardless of the sample size will be eligible for inclusion if they meet the following criteria: 1). comparative study; 2). compared standard LP with OP; 3). proved sufficient data on outcomes of interest; 4). procedures should perform in children (less than 18 years old). Besides, we only concerned standard LP; other types such as RALP and one-port LP were not under consideration."
Reasoning: The authors provided inclusion and exclusion criteria for study selection, but did not specify 'a priori' methods for assessing the scientific quality of included studies.
[No]

A8
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors did not assess the scientific quality of included studies, so this item is not applicable.
[NA]

Quote: "Considering the enormous difference of evidence level, we did not pool data from a RCT with other comparative studies. Odds ratio (OR) and its 95% confidential interval (CI) were used to assess dichotomous data, while weight mean differences (WMDs) were used to assess continuous data."
Reasoning: Appropriate methods were used to combine findings, assessing heterogeneity and using odds ratios and weighted mean differences.
[Yes]

A10
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The likelihood of publication bias was not assessed.
[No]

A11
Quote: "None."
Reasoning: Conflicts of interest were not reported for the systematic review or the included studies.
[No]

P1
Quote: "An updated meta-analysis of laparoscopic versus open pyeloplasty for ureteropelvic junction obstruction in children"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2
Quote: "Abstract: Purpose: To further explore the feasibility and safety of laparoscopic pyeloplasty (LP) in children with ureteropelvic junction obstruction compared with open pyeloplasty (OP). Methods: PUBMED, Web of science and Cochrane library were searched until Oct. 2014 to find eligible studies. WMD, OR, RD and their 95% CIs were used to estimate the difference. Baseline such as age, gender and crossing vessel, perioperative outcomes such as length of stay, operative time, overall complications, and success rate were compared. All the meta-analyses were performed in Revman 5.2. Results: 15 comparative studies and one RCT were eligible and included in the meta-analysis. Compared with OP, LP groups might be associated with shorted length of hospital stay (WMD: -1.92, 95% CI: -2.45–1.39), reduced complications (OR: 0.71, 95% CI: 0.49-1.01) and equal success rate (RD: 0.01, 95% CI: -0.02-0.04), but prolonged operative time (WMD: 48.64, 95% CI: 31.16-66.12). Conclusion: Our findings supported that laparoscopic pyeloplasty is feasibility and safety in the treatment of UPJ obstruction in children, especially in high-volume centers with experienced experts. Considering the select bias and recall bias, more RCTs are required to further explore the efficiencies of LP."
Reasoning: A structured abstract is provided with labeled sections for background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, participants and interventions, appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, and conclusions.
[Yes]

P3
Quote: "Ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction is one of the commonest causes of hydronephrosis in adults, especially in children. And to date, open pyeloplasty (OP) has still been the gold standard for operative manage, though minimally invasive surgeries such as laparoscopic pyeloplasty (LP) and robot assisted laparoscopic pyeloplasty (RALP) have increasingly been adopted in pediatric practice."
Reasoning: The rationale for the review is described in the context of what is already known about ureteropelvic junction obstruction and its surgical treatment options.
[Yes]

P4
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: An explicit statement of the PICOS question being addressed was not provided in the introduction.
[No]

P5
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The existence of a review protocol and registration information were not reported.
[No]

P6
Quote: "Criteria for inclusion and exclusion
Studies regardless of the sample size will be eligible for inclusion if they meet the following criteria: 1). comparative study; 2). compared standard LP with OP; 3). proved sufficient data on outcomes of interest; 4). procedures should perform in children (less than 18 years old). Besides, we only concerned standard LP; other types such as RALP and one-port LP were not under consideration."
Reasoning: Study eligibility criteria were specified, but a full rationale was not provided.
[No]

P7
Quote: "PUBMED, Web of science and Cochrane library was carried out between Jan. 1966 and Oct. 2014 to identify eligible studies, using the following words: "hydronephrosis OR ureteropelvic junction obstruction OR pyeloplasty", "young OR children OR child OR kids OR pediatrics" and "laparoscopic"."

Reasoning: The process for selecting studies, including screening, eligibility, and inclusion, was described and shown in a flow diagram (Figure 1).

Besides, we only concerned standard LP; other types such as RALP and one-port LP were not under consideration."

Reasoning: Odds ratios and weighted mean differences were stated as the principal summary measures.

Odds ratio (OR) and its 95% confidential interval (CI) were used to assess dichotomous data, while weight mean differences (WMDs) were used to assess continuous data. Because several studies reported 100% success rate in both groups, which could hardly obtain ORs, in such case, risk difference (RD) was used to evaluate this outcome."

Reasoning: A flow diagram (Figure 1) was provided showing the numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage.

Quote: "Characteristics of included studies
290 publications from all above database were retrieved after removing duplicates. Among these studies, 37 studies were finally leaved behind for full-text assessment. Detailed steps of literature search were shown in Figure 1."
Reasoning: Study characteristics for which data were extracted, such as study size, PICOS, and follow-up period, were presented for each included study in Tables 1-3, along with citations in the references section.

No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: Data on risk of bias assessments for each included study were not presented.
[No]

P20
Quote: "For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot."
Reasoning: Simple summary data for each intervention group and effect estimates with confidence intervals were reported for outcomes in Tables 1-3 and Figures 2-8, but not displayed in forest plots.
[No]

P21
Quote: "Considering the enormous difference of evidence level, we did not pool data from a RCT with other comparative studies. Odds ratio (OR) and its 95% confidential interval (CI) were used to assess dichotomous data, while weight mean differences (WMDs) were used to assess continuous data."
Reasoning: The results of each meta-analysis, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency, were presented in the text and figures.
[Yes]

P22
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The results of assessing risk of bias across studies, such as publication bias, were not presented.
[No]

P23
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: Additional analyses such as sensitivity or subgroup analyses were not mentioned.
[NA]

P24
Quote: "The findings of the present meta-analysis showed that children in LP groups may benefit from shortened length of hospital stay and reduced overall complications, though the LP groups are with prolonged operative time. Besides, the success rate of LP is similar to OP. Most of the findings were consistent with the previous meta-analysis conducted by Mei et al [3] except overall complications."
Reasoning: The main findings, including the strength of evidence for each main outcome, were summarized with relevance to key groups like healthcare providers and policymakers.
[Yes]

P25
Quote: "There are several limitations which should be taken into account. Firstly, only one RCT was included in this meta-analysis and most of studies were retrospective, which may lead to select bias and recall bias. More large-scaled well-designed RCT are needed to explore the feasibility and safety of LP compared with OP. Secondly, almost all the outcomes could be influence by the experience of surgeon. To attempt a real fair comparison, all the operation should be performed by one or specified surgeons to adjust for the potential effects of learning curve. But in most study included, pyeloplasty was not carried out by the same experienced surgeon in the same surgical team. This may bias our results in a certain degree."
Reasoning: Limitations at the study and outcome level (e.g. risk of bias) and at the review level (e.g. only one RCT included) were discussed.
[Yes]

P26
Quote: "Our findings of this meta-analysis revealed that LP groups were with less length of hospital stay and lower complication rate than OP groups. Considering the similar success rate of these two approaches, the laparoscopic pyeloplasty is feasibility and safety in the treatment of UPJ obstruction in children, especially in high-volume centers with experienced experts. Considering the select bias and recall bias, more RCTs are required to further explore the efficiencies of LP."
Reasoning: A general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research were provided in the conclusion.
[Yes]

P27
Quote: "Disclosure of conflict of interest
None."
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review were not described, and no conflicts of interest were declared.
[No]

Because several studies reported 100% success rate in both groups, which could hardly obtain ORs, in such case, risk difference (RD) was used to evaluate this outcome."
Reasoning: The methods of handling data and combining results were described, including assessing heterogeneity and using odds ratios, risk differences, and weighted mean differences as appropriate.
[Yes]

P15
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: Methods for assessing risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence, such as publication bias across studies, were not specified.
[No]

P16
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: Additional analyses such as sensitivity or subgroup analyses were not mentioned.
[NA]

P17
Quote: "290 publications from all above database were retrieved after removing duplicates. Among these studies, 37 studies were finally leaved behind for full-text assessment. Detailed steps of literature search were shown in Figure 1."
Reasoning: A flow diagram (Figure 1) was provided showing the numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage.
[Yes]

P18
Quote: "Characteristics of included studies
290 publications from all above database were retrieved after removing duplicates. Among these studies, 37 studies were finally leaved behind for full-text assessment. Detailed steps of literature search were shown in Figure 1."
Reasoning: Study characteristics for which data were extracted, such as study size, PICOS, and follow-up period, were presented for each included study in Tables 1-3, along with citations in the references section.
[Yes]

P19
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: Data on risk of bias assessments for each included study were not presented.
[No]

P20
Quote: "For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot."
Reasoning: Simple summary data for each intervention group and effect estimates with confidence intervals were reported for outcomes in Tables 1-3 and Figures 2-8, but not displayed in forest plots.
[No]

P21
Quote: "Considering the enormous difference of evidence level, we did not pool data from a RCT with other comparative studies. Odds ratio (OR) and its 95% confidential interval (CI) were used to assess dichotomous data, while weight mean differences (WMDs) were used to assess continuous data."
Reasoning: The results of each meta-analysis, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency, were presented in the text and figures.
[Yes]

P22
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The results of assessing risk of bias across studies, such as publication bias, were not presented.
[No]

P23
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: Additional analyses such as sensitivity or subgroup analyses were not mentioned.
[NA]

P24
Quote: "The findings of the present meta-analysis showed that children in LP groups may benefit from shortened length of hospital stay and reduced overall complications, though the LP groups are with prolonged operative time. Besides, the success rate of LP is similar to OP. Most of the findings were consistent with the previous meta-analysis conducted by Mei et al [3] except overall complications."
Reasoning: The main findings, including the strength of evidence for each main outcome, were summarized with relevance to key groups like healthcare providers and policymakers.
[Yes]

P25
Quote: "There are several limitations which should be taken into account. Firstly, only one RCT was included in this meta-analysis and most of studies were retrospective, which may lead to select bias and recall bias. More large-scaled well-designed RCT are needed to explore the feasibility and safety of LP compared with OP. Secondly, almost all the outcomes could be influence by the experience of surgeon. To attempt a real fair comparison, all the operation should be performed by one or specified surgeons to adjust for the potential effects of learning curve. But in most study included, pyeloplasty was not carried out by the same experienced surgeon in the same surgical team. This may bias our results in a certain degree."
Reasoning: Limitations at the study and outcome level (e.g. risk of bias) and at the review level (e.g. only one RCT included) were discussed.
[Yes]

P26
Quote: "Our findings of this meta-analysis revealed that LP groups were with less length of hospital stay and lower complication rate than OP groups. Considering the similar success rate of these two approaches, the laparoscopic pyeloplasty is feasibility and safety in the treatment of UPJ obstruction in children, especially in high-volume centers with experienced experts. Considering the select bias and recall bias, more RCTs are required to further explore the efficiencies of LP."
Reasoning: A general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research were provided in the conclusion.
[Yes]

P27
Quote: "Disclosure of conflict of interest
None."
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review were not described, and no conflicts of interest were declared.
[No]

Quote: "The present systematic review highlights that FURSL can be used even for stones in lower pole locations, for stones up to 30 mm, and in children from the age of three months. [15], which looked at SWL in urinary tract calculi in the paediatric population. They showed that the overall success rate was 83.4% for renal calculi and their complication rate was slightly higher at 15.0%, where no major complications were recorded."
Reasoning: Limitations at the review level are discussed, including the small number of studies and patients. Limitations at the study and outcome level are not addressed.

Quote: "To compare the effectiveness and safety of FURSL in the paediatric population with the more conventional methods of SWL and PCNL, large, multicentre trials would be required. To facilitate the analysis of data, the outcomes measured should be reported in a uniform manner."
Reasoning: A general interpretation is provided in the context of comparing FURSL to other methods, with implications for future research suggested.
[Yes]

Reasoning: Sources of funding and support for the systematic review are not reported.
[No]

llm_message:
A1
"The aim of the present review was to look at the role of ureteroscopy (URS) for treatment of paediatric stone disease. We conducted a systematic review using studies identified by a literature search between January 1990 and May 2013."
The review aim and inclusion criteria were established a priori.
[Yes]

A2
"Two reviewers independently extracted the data from each study."
At least two independent data extractors were involved.
[Yes]

A3
"The terms used in the search included the following: 'ureteroscopy', 'paediatric', 'pediatric', 'paediatrics', 'pediatrics', 'children', 'calculi', 'stones', 'laser', 'laser therapy' and 'urolithiasis'. Mesh phrases included the following: ('Ureteroscopy' [Mesh]) AND 'Paediatric' [Mesh], ('Calculi' [Mesh]) AND 'Ureteroscopy' [Mesh], ('Paediatric' [Mesh]) AND 'Stones' [Mesh], ('Paediatric' [Mesh]) AND ('Lasers' [Mesh] OR 'Laser Therapy' [Mesh]), ('Lasers' [Mesh]) AND 'Calculi' [Mesh]) AND (('Paediatric' [Mesh]), and ('Ureteroscopy' [Mesh]) AND ('Calculi' [Mesh]))."
A comprehensive search strategy using multiple databases and key terms was provided.
[Yes]

A4
"Only papers written in the English language were considered for inclusion. References of the searched studies were also evaluated for potential inclusion."
Only English language articles were included, no mention of including grey literature.
[No]

A5
No list of included and excluded studies was provided.
[No]

A6
"A total of 14 studies (Fig. 1), published during the period of January 1990 to May 2013, were found to fit the inclusion criteria. In total, 1718 procedures were carried out, with a range of 50–660 procedures per study (Tables 1,2 [2,6,11,16–26])."
The number of included studies and a range of their sample sizes were provided.
[No]

A7
"The quality of the included studies was assessed according to the Cochrane Collaboration and Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) checklist."
The scientific quality of included studies was assessed using the PRISMA checklist.
[Yes]

A8
"This review found there was a SFR of 86.3%, which compares well with the SFRs reported in studies of SWL in the treatment of paediatric stone disease."
The results of the quality assessment were considered in the review's conclusions.
[Yes]

A9
This systematic review did not perform a meta-analysis.
[NA]

A10
No assessment of publication bias was reported.
[No]

A11
No disclosure of conflicts of interest for the included studies.
[No]

P1
"Ureteroscopy for stone disease in the paediatric population: a systematic review"
The title identifies the article as a systematic review.
[Yes]

P2
The abstract is structured with labeled sections for background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, and conclusions.
[Yes]

P3
"Paediatric stone disease has been on the rise in recent years [1,2]. The reason for this rise is multifactorial. Developmental abnormalities of the genitourinary system are known to contribute to stone formation. These abnormalities promote stasis of urine as well as recurrent UTIs and increase the potential for crystallization to occur."
The rationale for the review is described in the context of the increasing incidence of pediatric stone disease and contributing factors.
[Yes]

P4
"The aim of the present review was to look at the role of ureteroscopy (URS) for treatment of paediatric stone disease."
An explicit statement of the review question is provided, but without full PICOS elements.
[No]

P5
No mention of a review protocol or registration number.
[No]

P6
"To be included in this systematic review studies were required to have reported on at least 50 cases of paediatric patients (aged ≤18 years) who underwent URS for stone disease, and their outcomes. The variables that were of interest were the efficacy and safety of the procedures and any complications associated with them; these were graded according to the Clavien–Dindo criteria. The efficacy of the procedure was defined as the SFR and the need for any further procedures."
Study eligibility criteria related to patient age, sample size, and outcomes of interest were specified.
[Yes]

P7
"The terms used in the search included the following: 'ureteroscopy', 'paediatric', 'pediatric', 'paediatrics', 'pediatrics', 'children', 'calculi', 'stones', 'laser', 'laser therapy' and 'urolithiasis'. Mesh phrases included the following: ('Ureteroscopy' [Mesh]) AND 'Paediatric' [Mesh], ('Calculi' [Mesh]) AND 'Ureteroscopy' [Mesh], ('Paediatric' [Mesh]) AND 'Stones' [Mesh], ('Paediatric' [Mesh]) AND ('Lasers' [Mesh] OR 'Laser Therapy' [Mesh]), ('Lasers' [Mesh]) AND 'Calculi' [Mesh]) AND (('Paediatric' [Mesh]), and ('Ureteroscopy' [Mesh]) AND ('Calculi' [Mesh]))."
The databases and search terms used were described, but the dates of coverage and last search date were not reported.
[No]

P8
"The terms used in the search included the following: 'ureteroscopy', 'paediatric', 'pediatric', 'paediatrics', 'pediatrics', 'children', 'calculi', 'stones', 'laser', 'laser therapy' and 'urolithiasis'. Mesh phrases included the following: ('Ureteroscopy' [Mesh]) AND 'Paediatric' [Mesh], ('Calculi' [Mesh]) AND 'Ureteroscopy' [Mesh], ('Paediatric' [Mesh]) AND 'Stones' [Mesh], ('Paediatric' [Mesh]) AND ('Lasers' [Mesh] OR 'Laser Therapy' [Mesh]), ('Lasers' [Mesh]) AND 'Calculi' [Mesh]) AND (('Paediatric' [Mesh]), and ('Ureteroscopy' [Mesh]) AND ('Calculi' [Mesh]))."
The full search strategy was provided for at least one database (PubMed/MEDLINE).
[Yes]

P9
"Only papers written in the English language were considered for inclusion. References of the searched studies were also evaluated for potential inclusion. Authors of the relevant studies were contacted to verify data if unclear or unavailable."
The study selection process was described, including language restrictions and checking reference lists.
[Yes]

P10
"Two reviewers independently extracted the data which was then put into an Excel spread sheet. Studies meeting the inclusion criteria were analysed for the following variables: period of study, country of origin, stone size and location, population demographics (age and sex), type of anaesthetic used, number and type of procedure performed, method of stone extraction, use of stents (pre- and postoperatively), SFRs, procedure failures, procedure-related complications and hospital length of stay."
The data extraction process was described, involving two independent reviewers.
[Yes]

P11
"Studies meeting the inclusion criteria were analysed for the following variables: period of study, country of origin, stone size and location, population demographics (age and sex), type of anaesthetic used, number and type of procedure performed, method of stone extraction, use of stents (pre- and postoperatively), SFRs, procedure failures, procedure-related complications and hospital length of stay."
The data items collected were defined.
[Yes]

P12
"The quality of the included studies was assessed according to the Cochrane Collaboration and Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) checklist."
The PRISMA checklist was used to assess study quality, but the specific methods for incorporating this into data synthesis were not described.
[No]

P13
No summary measures were specified.
[No]

P14
This systematic review did not include a meta-analysis.
[NA]

P15
This systematic review did not include a meta-analysis.
[NA]

This systematic review did not include a meta-analysis.

"This review found there was a SFR of 86.3%, which compares well with the SFRs reported in studies of SWL in the treatment of paediatric stone disease. A recent study by Badawy et al. [27] reported SFRs of 83.4 and 58.5% in renal and ureteric calculi, respectively, in >500 patients."

P25
"The present review has two limitations. P26

The rationale for the review is described in the context of the increasing incidence of pediatric stone disease and contributing factors.

llm_message:
A1
"The aim of this systematic review was to critically examine the existing literature regarding the effectiveness of tongue-tie division in infants with ankyloglossia, using the new grades of recommendations, assessment, development, and evaluation (GRADE) rating system."
The research question and inclusion criteria were established a priori.
[Yes]

A2
No relevant quotes found.
No mention of duplicate study selection and data extraction.
[No]

A3
"An electronic literature search was systematically performed using databases including PubMed (January1966–April 2013), Japana Centra Revuo Medicina (Igaku Chuo Zasshi), 1983–April 2013), CINAHL, and Cochrane Library using the key words "ankyloglossia," "tongue-tie," "frenotomy," and/or "breast-feeding" in English and Japanese."
A comprehensive literature search was performed using multiple databases and key words.
[Yes]

A4
"The literature selection criteria included RCT and observational studies (cohort studies, case–control studies, and case series) that matched the aforementioned patient selection criteria. Case reports, case series with <10 subjects, opinion articles without patient data, literature reviews, Q&As, and letters to the editor were excluded. Guidelines, guidance, and position statements of medical associations focused on the effects of frenotomy in infants with breast-feeding difficulties were included as references for the review."
The inclusion criteria did not restrict based on publication status.
[No]

A5
"A total of 505 titles and abstracts were retrieved with the initial search terms of ankyloglossia or tongue-tie. Via the secondary search, relevant full-texts were obtained for 114 articles, using the search with terms of "frenotomy," "frenuloplasty," or "breast-feeding." According to the exclusion criteria, case reports with <10 subjects, expert opinions, reviews, Q&As, and letters to the editor were eliminated."
A list of excluded studies was provided, but not a list of included studies.
[No]

A6
"For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations."
The characteristics of included studies were provided in an evidence table.
[Yes]

A7
"The literature was divided into two groups: RCT (high-quality group) and observational studies (low-quality group). In regard to the most important outcomes (sucking/latch and nipple pain), meta-analysis of observational studies, continued a small number of RCT and meta-analysis of observational studies, were rated either A (strong evidence) or B (moderate evidence); the other four important outcomes were rated C (weak evidence) because they were purely observational studies, contained a small number of subjects, and/or lacked controls."
The scientific quality of included studies was assessed and documented using the GRADE system.
[Yes]

A8
"Evidence levels of the most important outcomes (sucking/latch and nipple pain), presented by RCT and meta-analysis of observational studies, were rated either A (strong evidence) or B (moderate evidence); the other four important outcomes were rated C (weak evidence) because they were purely observational studies, contained a small number of subjects, and/or lacked controls."
The scientific quality was used appropriately in formulating conclusions, with strong/moderate evidence for key outcomes and weak evidence for others.
[Yes]

A9
"Meta-analysis was carried out using Review Manager (RevMan ver. 5.2) of the Cochrane Collaboration.11 Effect size was measured using risk ratio in dichotomous data and mean difference in continuous data with 95% confidence intervals (95%CI)."
Appropriate methods were used to combine the findings of studies in meta-analysis.
[Yes]

A10
No relevant quotes found.
Publication bias was not assessed.
[No]

A11
No relevant quotes found.
Conflicts of interest were not reported for the systematic review or included studies.
[No]

P1
"Does frenotomy improve breast-feeding difficulties in infants with ankyloglossia?"
The report is identified as a systematic review in the title.
[Yes]

P2
The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objective, data sources, study eligibility criteria, participants and interventions, appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, and conclusions.
[Yes]

P3
"Ankyloglossia or tongue-tie is a congenital oral condition characterized by an abnormally short lingual frenulum, which restricts tongue movement. The length of attachment to the tongue and thickness of the frenulum vary widely in degree. It is often classified into mild "partial ankyloglossia", which is common, and severe as well as rare "complete ankyloglossia", where the tongue is fused to the floor of the mouth."
The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known about ankyloglossia.
[Yes]

P4
"The aim of this systematic review was to critically examine the existing literature regarding the effectiveness of tongue-tie division in infants with ankyloglossia, using the new grades of recommendations, assessment, development, and evaluation (GRADE) rating system. A clinical question was structured according to patient, intervention, comparison, and outcome, as follows: in infants with poor breast-feeding and ankyloglossia (patient), does frenotomy (intervention), compared to lactation support alone (comparison), improve feeding (outcome)?"
The introduction provides an explicit statement of the review question with reference to PICO.
[Yes]

P5
No relevant quotes found.
No mention of a review protocol or registration.
[No]

P6
"Literature that focused on neonates and infants <6 months of age who had breast-feeding problems and ankyloglossia was selected for analysis. Patients who suffered from other oral anomalies and disturbances of the central nervous system were excluded from the review."
Study characteristics and report characteristics used as eligibility criteria are specified.
[Yes]

P7
"An electronic literature search was systematically performed using databases including PubMed (January1966–April 2013), Japana Centra Revuo Medicina (Igaku Chuo Zasshi), 1983–April 2013), CINAHL, and Cochrane Library using the key words "ankyloglossia," "tongue-tie," "frenotomy," and/or "breast-feeding" in English and Japanese. The search was limited to articles written in English and Japanese."
All information sources searched and the date range are described.
[Yes]

P8
No relevant quotes found.
The full electronic search strategy is not presented.
[No]

P9
"A total of 505 titles and abstracts were retrieved with the initial search terms of ankyloglossia or tongue-tie. Via the secondary search, relevant full-texts were obtained for 114 articles, using the search with terms of "frenotomy," "frenuloplasty," or "breast-feeding." According to the exclusion criteria, case reports with <10 subjects, expert opinions, reviews, Q&As, and letters to the editor were eliminated. After adding four articles by hand-searching, four RCT, 12 observational studies,12–23 National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guidance,24 a guideline by the Academy of Breast feeding Medicine (ABM),25 and a position statement of the Canadian Paediatric Society26 met the criteria for the review (Fig. 1)."
The process for selecting studies is stated.
[Yes]

P10
No relevant quotes found.
The method of data extraction is not described.
[No]

P11
"The primary outcome measures regarding breast-feeding problems associated with ankyloglossia and their relative importance are listed in Table 1. Sucking/latch and nipple pain were rated as the most important outcomes, because these two outcomes were considered to be the main reasons for abandoning breast-feeding. Milk supply/milk production, continuation of breast-feeding, weight gain, adverse events, and dyad distress were rated as relatively less important outcomes."
The outcomes for which data were sought are defined.
[Yes]

P12
"The literature was divided into two groups: RCT (high-quality group) and observational studies (low-quality group). In regard to the most important outcomes (sucking/latch and nipple pain), meta-analysis of observational studies, continued a small number of RCT and meta-analysis of observational studies, were rated either A (strong evidence) or B (moderate evidence); the other four important outcomes were rated C (weak evidence) because they were purely observational studies, contained a small number of subjects, and/or lacked controls."
The methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies are described.
[Yes]

P13
"Meta-analysis was carried out using Review Manager (RevMan ver. 5.2) of the Cochrane Collaboration.11 Effect size was measured using risk ratio in dichotomous data and mean difference in continuous data with 95% confidence intervals (95%CI)."
The principal summary measures are stated (risk ratio and mean difference).
[Yes]

P14
"Meta-analysis was carried out using Review Manager (RevMan ver. 5.2) of the Cochrane Collaboration.11 Effect size was measured using risk ratio in dichotomous data and mean difference in continuous data with 95% confidence intervals (95%CI)."
The methods of handling data and combining results are described.
[Yes]

P15
No relevant quotes found.
No methods for assessing risk of bias across studies are specified.
[No]

P16
No relevant quotes found.
No methods of additional analyses are described.
[No]

P17
"A total of 505 titles and abstracts were retrieved with the initial search terms of ankyloglossia or tongue-tie. Via the secondary search, relevant full-texts were obtained for 114 articles, using the search with terms of "frenotomy," "frenuloplasty," or "breast-feeding." According to the exclusion criteria, case reports with <10 subjects, expert opinions, reviews, Q&As, and letters to the editor were eliminated. After adding four articles by hand-searching, four RCT, 12 observational studies,12–23 National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guidance,24 a guideline by the Academy of Breast feeding Medicine (ABM),25 and a position statement of the Canadian Paediatric Society26 met the criteria for the review (Fig. 1)."
A flow diagram is provided with the numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, included and excluded with reasons.
[Yes]

P18
The characteristics of each included study are presented in an evidence table with citations.
[Yes]

P19
"The literature was divided into two groups: RCT (high-quality group) and observational studies (low-quality group). In regard to the most important outcomes (sucking/latch and nipple pain), meta-analysis of observational studies, continued a small number of RCT and meta-analysis of observational studies, were rated either A (strong evidence) or B (moderate evidence); the other four important outcomes were rated C (weak evidence) because they were purely observational studies, contained a small number of subjects, and/or lacked controls."
Data on the risk of bias of each study are presented.
[Yes]

P20
Results for individual studies are presented in the meta-analysis forest plots, including summary data for each group and effect estimates with confidence intervals.
[Yes]

P21
Meta-analysis results are presented with forest plots showing effect estimates and confidence intervals.
[Yes]

P22
No relevant quotes found.
No results of assessment of risk of bias across studies are presented.
[No]

P23
No relevant quotes found.
No additional analyses were conducted.
[NA]

P24
"The results of this systematic review are summarized in the evidence profile (Table 6). The results of outcomes consistently showed the effectiveness of frenotomy for breast-feeding difficulties in infants with ankyloglossia. No major complications from frenotomy, most likely because it was performed by well-trained health-care professionals."
The main findings are summarized including the strength of evidence for each main outcome.
[Yes]

P25
"The quality of the literature was rated in regard to the two most important outcomes (sucking/latch and nipple pain) and five relatively less important outcomes (milk supply/milk production, continuation of breast-feeding, weight gain, adverse events, and dyad distress) according to the GRADE system.
Sucking or latch was difficult to assess independently from other outcomes because maternal subjective outcome measures included nipple pain, feeding time, infant satisfaction, and maternal distress. The objective assessment of the LATCH score also includes nipple pain as an assessment item."
Limitations at the study and outcome level are discussed.
[Yes]

P26
"A systematic review based on the GRADE system was conducted to examine the clinical question, does frenotomy improve breast-feeding difficulties in infants with ankyloglossia. In accordance with the current criteria, four RCT and 12 observational studies were included in this review. The evidence levels of the two most important outcomes (sucking/latch and nipple pain) were rated either A (strong evidence) or B (moderate evidence); the other four less important outcomes were rated C (weak evidence), and every outcome consistently showed the effectiveness of frenotomy for breast-feeding difficulties. No serious adverse events were reported."
A general interpretation of the results is provided in the context of other evidence, with implications for practice.
[Yes]

P27
No relevant quotes found.
Sources of funding for the systematic review are not described.
[No]

Milk supply/milk production, continuation of breast-feeding, weight gain, adverse events, and dyad distress were rated as relatively less important outcomes."
The outcomes for which data were sought are defined.
[Yes]

P12
"The literature was divided into two groups: RCT (high-quality group) and observational studies (low-quality group). In regard to the most important outcomes (sucking/latch and nipple pain), meta-analysis of observational studies, continued a small number of RCT and meta-analysis of observational studies, were rated either A (strong evidence) or B (moderate evidence); the other four important outcomes were rated C (weak evidence) because they were purely observational studies, contained a small number of subjects, and/or lacked controls."
The methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies are described.
[Yes]

P13
"Meta-analysis was carried out using Review Manager (RevMan ver. 5.2) of the Cochrane Collaboration.11 Effect size was measured using risk ratio in dichotomous data and mean difference in continuous data with 95% confidence intervals (95%CI)."
The principal summary measures are stated (risk ratio and mean difference).
[Yes]

P14
"Meta-analysis was carried out using Review Manager (RevMan ver. 5.2) of the Cochrane Collaboration.11 Effect size was measured using risk ratio in dichotomous data and mean difference in continuous data with 95% confidence intervals (95%CI)."
The methods of handling data and combining results are described.
[Yes]

P15
No relevant quotes found.
No methods for assessing risk of bias across studies are specified.
[No]

P16
No relevant quotes found.
No methods of additional analyses are described.
[No]

P17
"A total of 505 titles and abstracts were retrieved with the initial search terms of ankyloglossia or tongue-tie. Via the secondary search, relevant full-texts were obtained for 114 articles, using the search with terms of "frenotomy," "frenuloplasty," or "breast-feeding." According to the exclusion criteria, case reports with <10 subjects, expert opinions, reviews, Q&As, and letters to the editor were eliminated. After adding four articles by hand-searching, four RCT, 12 observational studies,12–23 National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guidance,24 a guideline by the Academy of Breast feeding Medicine (ABM),25 and a position statement of the Canadian Paediatric Society26 met the criteria for the review (Fig. 1)."
A flow diagram is provided with the numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, included and excluded with reasons.
[Yes]

P18
The characteristics of each included study are presented in an evidence table with citations.
[Yes]

P19
"The literature was divided into two groups: RCT (high-quality group) and observational studies (low-quality group). In regard to the most important outcomes (sucking/latch and nipple pain), meta-analysis of observational studies, continued a small number of RCT and meta-analysis of observational studies, were rated either A (strong evidence) or B (moderate evidence); the other four important outcomes were rated C (weak evidence) because they were purely observational studies, contained a small number of subjects, and/or lacked controls."
Data on the risk of bias of each study are presented.
[Yes]

P20
Results for individual studies are presented in the meta-analysis forest plots, including summary data for each group and effect estimates with confidence intervals.
[Yes]

P21
Meta-analysis results are presented with forest plots showing effect estimates and confidence intervals.
[Yes]

P22
No relevant quotes found.
No results of assessment of risk of bias across studies are presented.
[No]

P23
No relevant quotes found.
No additional analyses were conducted.
[NA]

P24
"The results of this systematic review are summarized in the evidence profile (Table 6). The results of outcomes consistently showed the effectiveness of frenotomy for breast-feeding difficulties in infants with ankyloglossia. No major complications from frenotomy, most likely because it was performed by well-trained health-care professionals."
The main findings are summarized including the strength of evidence for each main outcome.
[Yes]

P25
"The quality of the literature was rated in regard to the two most important outcomes (sucking/latch and nipple pain) and five relatively less important outcomes (milk supply/milk production, continuation of breast-feeding, weight gain, adverse events, and dyad distress) according to the GRADE system.
Sucking or latch was difficult to assess independently from other outcomes because maternal subjective outcome measures included nipple pain, feeding time, infant satisfaction, and maternal distress. The objective assessment of the LATCH score also includes nipple pain as an assessment item."
Limitations at the study and outcome level are discussed.
[Yes]

P26
"A systematic review based on the GRADE system was conducted to examine the clinical question, does frenotomy improve breast-feeding difficulties in infants with ankyloglossia. In accordance with the current criteria, four RCT and 12 observational studies were included in this review. The evidence levels of the two most important outcomes (sucking/latch and nipple pain) were rated either A (strong evidence) or B (moderate evidence); the other four less important outcomes were rated C (weak evidence), and every outcome consistently showed the effectiveness of frenotomy for breast-feeding difficulties. No serious adverse events were reported."
A general interpretation of the results is provided in the context of other evidence, with implications for practice.
[Yes]

P27
No relevant quotes found.
Sources of funding for the systematic review are not described.
[No]

llm_message:
A1 - Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quote: "The aim of the study was to compare the outcome after laparoscopic pyloromyotomy (LP) with those of open pyloromyotomy (OP) for infantile pyloric stenosis."
Reasoning: The aim of the study was stated, but no mention of a protocol, ethics approval, or pre-determined objectives.
[No]

A2 - Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
Quote: "Data were extracted by 2 independent investigators, and discrepancies were discussed to reach consensus."
Reasoning: Two independent investigators performed data extraction and resolved discrepancies by consensus.
[Yes]

A3 - Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quotes: "An electronic literature search of all articles from inception to February 2009 was conducted using Medline, the Cochrane Library, ISI, EMBASE, and the Chinese Biomedical Literature Database, using the following text and keywords in combination both as MeSH terms and text words: "pyloric stenosis", "pyloromyotomy", "pyloromyotomies" and "pyloromyotomy" in combination with "laparoscop*". The China Journal Fulltext Database (from 1994 to February 2009), Chinese biological medicine disc (from 1978 to February 2009), Chinese Scientific Journals Fulltext Database (from 1989 to February 2009) and Wanfang Database (from 1997 to February 2009) were also searched using the above terms."
Reasoning: At least 2 electronic databases were searched, key terms were provided, and additional sources like Chinese databases were searched.
[Yes]

A4 - Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
Quotes: "Further searches were done by manually reviewing abstract booklets, conference proceedings and review articles. Investigators were contacted for additional data if included outcomes were not published."
Reasoning: Conference proceedings and abstract booklets were searched, and investigators were contacted for unpublished data.
[Yes]

A5 - Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
Quote: "The literature searches yielded 461 potentially relevant articles. After a review of the titles, abstracts and removal of duplicates, 17 articles were selected for further evaluation. When inclusion criteria were applied, 3 randomized controlled trials with 492 infants were finally eligible for this study (Fig. 1)."
Reasoning: A flow diagram of study selection was provided, but no list of excluded studies.
[No]

A6 - Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quote: "Baseline characteristics of included trials are summarized in Table 1. The 3 studies spanned the period 1999-2007 and 2 large studies [10,13] even overlapped by 33 months, which means these 2 were carried out during the same 33 months of their respective duration."
Reasoning: Key characteristics of the included studies like time period and overlap were provided in aggregate form.
[Yes]

A7 - Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
Quote: "Using the quality assessment instrument of the Cochrane Handbook version 5.0.1 [11], we assigned 'Yes' for low risk of bias, 'No' for high risk of bias, or 'Unclear' for uncertain risk of bias. All studies described an adequate random sequence generation, allocation concealment and blinding. After retrieving included articles, no incomplete outcome data and selective outcome reporting were found (Table 2)."
Reasoning: The Cochrane risk of bias tool was used to assess study quality, and the results for each study were reported.
[Yes]

A8 - Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
Reasoning: The authors did not appear to consider study quality when formulating the conclusions of the review.
[No]

A9 - Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
Quote: "Statistical analysis was performed using RevMan 5.0.8. The results are expressed as SMD for continuous variables and OR for dichotomous outcomes; 95% confidence intervals (CIs) are also reported."
Reasoning: Appropriate statistical methods were used to combine the study findings in a meta-analysis.
[Yes]

A10 - Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
Reasoning: The review did not mention assessing publication bias.
[No]

A11 - Was the conflict of interest included?
Reasoning: The review did not report sources of support or conflicts of interest for the systematic review itself or the included studies.
[No]

P1 - Title
Quote: "Open versus Laparoscopic Pyloromyotomy for Pyloric Stenosis: A Meta-analysis of Randomized Controlled Trials"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
[Yes]

P2 - Abstract / Structured summary
Quote: The abstract contains labeled sections for Objective, Methods, Results, and Conclusions.
Reasoning: The abstract is structured with distinct sections covering the main PRISMA elements.
[Yes]  

P3 - Introduction / Rationale
Quote: "Ramstedt pyloromyotomy is easily performed and associated with minimal complications [5]. But in the 1990s, with the advance of minimally invasive surgery in infants, laparoscopic approaches have become progressively more popular and have replaced the open approach in many institutions [6,7]."
Reasoning: The rationale for the review is provided in the context of the increasing use of laparoscopic vs open pyloromyotomy.
[Yes]

P4 - Introduction / Objectives
Quote: "The aim of the study was to compare the outcome after laparoscopic pyloromyotomy (LP) with those of open pyloromyotomy (OP) for infantile pyloric stenosis."
Reasoning: An explicit objective statement is provided referencing the participants, interventions and outcomes of interest.
[Yes]

P5 - Methods / Protocol and registration
Reasoning: No mention of a review protocol or registration number.
[No]

P6 - Methods / Eligibility criteria
Quote: "Eligible studies were those that compared LP with OP for the treatment of infants with IHPS, and only randomized controlled trials was reviewed. The included studies had to report at least one of the following outcomes: complications during and following pyloromyotomy, the secondary endpoints included time to goal feeds, length of stay after surgery and operative time."
Reasoning: The eligibility criteria for study characteristics (RCTs of LP vs OP for IHPS) and report characteristics (complication and secondary outcome data) are specified.
[Yes]

P7 - Methods / Information sources
Quote: "An electronic literature search of all articles from inception to February 2009 was conducted using Medline, the Cochrane Library, ISI, EMBASE, and the Chinese Biomedical Literature Database, using the following text and keywords in combination both as MeSH terms and text words: "pyloric stenosis", "pyloromyotomy", "pyloromyotomies" and "pyloromyotomy" in combination with "laparoscop*". The China Journal Fulltext Database (from 1994 to February 2009), Chinese biological medicine disc (from 1978 to February 2009), Chinese Scientific Journals Fulltext Database (from 1989 to February 2009) and Wanfang Database (from 1997 to February 2009) were also searched using the above terms."
Reasoning: The electronic databases searched are described along with the date range of the search.
[Yes]

P8 - Methods / Search
Quote: The full search strategies are not provided.
Reasoning: The keywords are listed but the full reproducible search strategy is not reported for any database.
[No]

P9 - Methods / Study selection
Quote: "The literature searches yielded 461 potentially relevant articles. After a review of the titles, abstracts and removal of duplicates, 17 articles were selected for further evaluation. When inclusion criteria were applied, 3 randomized controlled trials with 492 infants were finally eligible for this study (Fig. 1)."
Reasoning: The process of screening, eligibility assessment, and inclusion is described.
[Yes]

P10 - Methods / Data collection process
Quote: "Data were extracted by 2 independent investigators, and discrepancies were discussed to reach consensus."
Reasoning: The data extraction process is described, involving two independent investigators and consensus resolution.
[Yes]

P11 - Methods / Data items
Reasoning: The review does not explicitly state all the variables for which data were sought.
[No]

P12 - Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies
Quote: "Using the quality assessment instrument of the Cochrane Handbook version 5.0.1 [11], we assigned 'Yes' for low risk of bias, 'No' for high risk of bias, or 'Unclear' for uncertain risk of bias."
Reasoning: The Cochrane risk of bias tool was used to assess risk of bias in the included studies.
[Yes]

P13 - Methods / Summary measures
Quote: "The primary endpoints in this review were complications during and following pyloromyotomy, the secondary endpoints included time to goal feeds, length of stay after surgery and operative time."
Reasoning: The primary and secondary outcome measures are stated.
[Yes]

P14 - Methods / Synthesis of results
Quote: "Statistical analysis was performed using RevMan 5.0.8. The results are expressed as SMD for continuous variables and OR for dichotomous outcomes; 95% confidence intervals (CIs) are also reported."
Reasoning: The meta-analysis methods, effect measures, and assessment of consistency are described.
[Yes]

P15 - Methods / Risk of bias across studies
Reasoning: Methods for assessing risk of bias across studies, such as publication bias, are not mentioned.
[No]

P16 - Methods / Additional analyses
Reasoning: No additional analyses such as subgroup analyses or meta-regression are mentioned.
[No]

P17 - Results / Study selection
Quote: See Figure 1 flow diagram.
Reasoning: The flow diagram provides the numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, included, and excluded with reasons.
[Yes]

P18 - Results / Study characteristics
Quote: See Table 1 for study characteristics.
Reasoning: Table 1 presents key characteristics of the included studies like sample size, interventions, and outcomes.
[Yes]

P19 - Results / Risk of bias within studies
Quote: See Table 2 for quality assessment of included studies.
Reasoning: Table 2 presents the Cochrane risk of bias assessments for each included study.
[Yes]

P20 - Results / Results of individual studies
Quote: See Table 3 and Table 4 for results of individual studies.
Reasoning: Tables 3 and 4 present the effect estimates and confidence intervals for each outcome from the individual studies.
[Yes]

P21 - Results / Synthesis of results
Quote: See Table 3 for meta-analysis results.
Reasoning: Table 3 presents the pooled effect estimates, confidence intervals, and heterogeneity measures for each outcome.
[Yes]

P22 - Results / Risk of bias across studies
Reasoning: The results do not include an assessment of risk of bias across studies, such as a funnel plot for publication bias.
[No]

P23 - Results / Additional analysis
Reasoning: No additional analyses such as subgroup analyses or meta-regression were reported.
[No]

P24 - Discussion / Summary of evidence
Quote: "The analyzed data confirmed that LP has a similar rate of complications, both perioperatively and postoperatively. However, the LP group seemed to have a slightly higher rate of incomplete pyloromyotomies requiring a repeat procedure, with 6 cases occurring out of a total of 137 infants (4.38%) compared to none in the OP group (9,10). This is in line with other published series which reported an incidence of incomplete pyloromyotomies of between 2% and 8% [14-16], whereas this complication is extremely uncommon with OP procedures [17]."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized, including the similar complication rates between LP and OP but slightly higher incomplete pyloromyotomy rate with LP.
[Yes]

P25 - Discussion / Limitations
Quote: "As with any systematic review, the limitations of this study reflect those of the individual studies. Most relied on information from databases. In this review, all trials included were obtained from online databases and no other articles were reviewed. Thus, a publication bias probably existed, although we did not assess this in detail because of the small numbers of trials that could be pooled. The heterogeneity of some variables in this study is also worthy of comment. 3 variables (full time to feed, length of stay after surgery, operating time) exhibited significant heterogeneity, as indicated by the I2 values which were all above 50%. Possible explanations include the following factors: First, the studies were all from different centers. Second, the procedures were performed by a number of different surgeons with different levels of skill and proficiency. Third, different centers may be at different points on the learning curve for LP."
Reasoning: Several limitations of the review are discussed, including publication bias, heterogeneity among the included studies, and differences between centers and surgeons.
[Yes]

P26 - Discussion / Conclusions
Quote: "Overall, this systematic review has shown a similar frequency of complications for LP and OP procedures. Furthermore, it also showed a trend toward shorter times for LP. Nevertheless, the conclusions from this study remain somewhat limited due to the small sample size."
Reasoning: The conclusions provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of the limitations of the small sample size.
[Yes]

P27 - Funding
Reasoning: The review does not report sources of funding or other support.
[No]

llm_message:
Here is the assessment of the systematic review using AMSTAR and PRISMA:

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quote: "The review was performed according to the PRISMA guidelines (Appendix 1)."
Reasoning: The authors state the review was conducted according to PRISMA guidelines, implying an a priori design.
[Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction? 
Quotes: "Abstracts for all articles were independently subjected to preliminary review by two investigators (JA, SK) to determine whether inclusion criteria were satisfied. A third reviewer (JT) resolved disagreement between reviewers." and "A standard data collection form (Appendix 2) created by the authors (JA, JT, SK) was used to extract information about study quality, including overall and per-group sample sizes,"
Reasoning: Study selection and data extraction were done independently by multiple reviewers.
[Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quotes: "We reviewed Medline citations, as well as the Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, between January 1, 1996 and June 1, 2012." and "Articles were identified using the search term "gastroschisis" and [("treatment outcome" or "prognosis") or randomized controlled trials]."
Reasoning: At least 2 databases were searched using relevant search terms. 
[Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
Reasoning: No mention of including or excluding studies based on publication status or searching for grey literature.
[No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
Reasoning: Figure 1 provides a flow diagram of included and excluded studies with reasons for exclusions, but does not provide a full list.
[No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quotes: "Data for birth weight and gestational age by type of closure were provided for 16 studies, and neither birth weight nor gestational age was strongly associated with study effects (Table 3)." and "However, the following variables were moderately (0.3>r>0.7) associated: birth weight and gestational age with ventilator days and TTiF; gestational age with NEC and mortality; and birth weight with TFuF and PND."
Reasoning: Some aggregate characteristics of included studies were provided, but not in table format for each study.
[No]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
Quote: "Heterogeneity was assessed by the I2 statistic, which is a measure of the proportion of variance across studies that can be attributed to heterogeneity rather than chance."
Reasoning: Heterogeneity, which reflects study quality, was assessed using I2 statistic. However, no other formal quality assessment was reported.
[No]

Quote: "Gastroschisis is the most common congenital abdominal wall defect. Reasoning: No results of assessment of risk of bias across studies like publication bias.

Reasoning: No additional analyses were reported.

Quote: "Silo closure is associated with better clinical outcomes in the studies with the least selection bias. Reasoning: The main findings are summarized with consideration of their relevance to key groups.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
Quote: "First, we identified the following three major variations in study design: 1) manner of selection of gastroschisis closure method, 2) inclusion of patients receiving surgically sutured silos in the silo group, and 3) inclusion of patients with complicated gastroschisis (including atresia, volvulus, and perforation). Reasoning: Limitations at the review level are discussed.
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
Quote: "This analysis highlights the heterogeneity of the available literature on closure methods for gastroschisis and the impact of study design on reported outcomes. Reasoning: The conclusions provide a general interpretation in the context of other evidence and implications for future research.
[Yes]

Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review are reported.
[Yes]

[Yes]

P2
Quote: "Background: The management of intestinal rotational abnormalities (IRA) in heterotaxy syndrome (HS) remains inconsistent. Because of the high incidence of malrotation in HS, screening of asymptomatic patients is standard of care in some institutions. The Ladd procedure is the treatment for malrotation, and has been reported to have high complication rates in HS patients.
Methods: We performed a systematic review of publications describing IRA in pediatric HS patients from January 1993 to present. The incidence of volvulus on surgical exploration was determined. Perioperative and long-term outcomes were analyzed to determine complication and mortality rates."
Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary with labeled sections for background, methods, and results.
[Yes]

Reasoning: The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is known about heterotaxy syndrome and intestinal rotational abnormalities.
[Yes]

P24
Quote: "Heterotaxy syndrome refers to abnormal arrangement of thoracoabdominal organs along the left-right body axis, and is associated with multiple congenital anomalies including complex congenital heart disease [4]. Previously reported to have up to 40% mortality, outcomes have improved in HS patients owing to refinements in surgical, anesthetic and critical care management [7,8]. IRA occurs in approximately 40–90% of HS patients [1]."
Reasoning: The discussion summarizes the main findings on the prevalence and outcomes of IRA in HS patients.
[Yes]

P25
Quote: "Despite the low risk of volvulus in the data presented here, there are anecdotal cases of patients with HS who presented with volvulus that resulted in death. At this time, it remains difficult to definitively ascertain whether the risk of death from prophylactic Ladd in HS or the risk of death from a volvulus in patients with HS who are observed is greater."
Reasoning: The authors discuss the limitations in definitively determining the risks of prophylactic Ladd vs observation based on the available data.
[Yes]

P26
Quote: "Ideally, a Ladd procedure should only be performed on those patients with HS that have the highest risk of volvulus, allowing the benefits of no operation to outweigh the risks."
Reasoning: The authors provide an interpretation that Ladd procedure should only be performed in high-risk HS patients, implying the need for future research to identify this subgroup.
[Yes]

No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review are not reported.
[No]

Quote: "Heterotaxy syndrome refers to abnormal arrangement of thoracoabdominal organs along the left-right body axis, and is associated with multiple congenital anomalies including complex congenital heart disease [4]. IRA occurs in approximately 40–90% of HS patients [1]."
Reasoning: The discussion summarizes the main findings on the prevalence and outcomes of IRA in HS patients.
[Yes]

P25
Quote: "Despite the low risk of volvulus in the data presented here, there are anecdotal cases of patients with HS who presented with volvulus that resulted in death. At this time, it remains difficult to definitively ascertain whether the risk of death from prophylactic Ladd in HS or the risk of death from a volvulus in patients with HS who are observed is greater."
Reasoning: The authors discuss the limitations in definitively determining the risks of prophylactic Ladd vs observation based on the available data.
[Yes]

[Yes]

P26:
"In conclusion, sutureless circumcision in children appears to have significant advantages to the standard closure using interrupted sutures. As reported there are advantages that include a better postoperative appearance and parental satisfaction, reduced inflammation and infection rates and a reduced operative time. The disadvantage is in the adolescent age group where tissue glue alone may not be an adequate form of closure due to the increased tension placed on the wound should the boys develop an erection. There is also a learning curve associated with the application of glue, but with experience a reproducible and reliable outcome should be expected."
Provides a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and mentions implications for practice, but not future research.
[No]
