llm_message:
A1
Quote: "The aim of this study is to assess the role of laparoscopy in the diagnosis and therapy of BAT."
Reasoning: The research objective is clearly stated.
[Yes]

A2
Quotes: "All articles published during the mentionated period associated with these keywords were selected. All articles referring to pediatric surgery, penetrating trauma, nontraumatic abdominal emergencies, iatrogenic injury were excluded."
"The articles have been grouped based on their scientific content: original studies on patients with multiples and single organ injuries, reviews, and case reports."
Reasoning: Study selection and data extraction methods are described, but it is not explicitly stated that these were done in duplicate.
[No]

A3
Quote: "A comprehensive literature search was performed on the U.S. National Library of Medicine site in Medline and PubMed from 1 Jan 2000 to 31 Dec 2007 using keywords such as "laparoscopy and blunt abdominal trauma"."
Reasoning: Only one electronic database (PubMed/Medline) was searched.
[No]

A4
Reasoning: The inclusion of grey literature is not mentioned.
[No]

A5
Reasoning: A list of included and excluded studies is not provided.
[No]

A6
Quote: "97 articles from Medline/PubMed were reviewed. Thirty-seven articles were excluded. This paper reviews 66 articles that met the inclusion criteria. With the scientific content reviewed, the articles were divided in three categories shown in Table 1, 2 and 3 which also include the number of investigated patients."
Reasoning: Some characteristics of the included studies are provided in an aggregated form in Tables 1-3.
[Yes]

A7
Quotes: "The articles have been grouped based on their scientific content: original studies on patients with multiples and single organ injuries, reviews, and case reports."
"With the scientific content reviewed, the articles were divided in three categories shown in Table 1, 2 and 3 which also include the number of investigated patients."
Reasoning: The scientific quality of included studies was not assessed.
[No]

A8
Reasoning: Since the scientific quality of included studies was not assessed (A7), this item is scored as No.
[No]

A9
Reasoning: This systematic review does not include a meta-analysis, so assessing the appropriateness of methods for combining studies is not applicable.
[NA]

A10
Reasoning: The likelihood of publication bias is not assessed.
[No]

A11
Reasoning: Conflicts of interest or funding sources are not reported for the systematic review itself or the included studies.
[No]

P1
Quote: "Is laparoscopy still needed in blunt abdominal trauma?"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as addressing laparoscopy in blunt abdominal trauma, but does not explicitly state it is a systematic review.
[No]

P2
Quote: "Laparoscopia diagnostică şi terapeutică în contuziile abdominale (CA) are o utilizare limitată şi cine controversată, datorită în special progreselor făcute de explorările imagistice actuale. Scopul lucrării noastre este de a evalua rolul actual al laparoscopiei în CA. Am efectuat un studiu al articolelor publicate asupra rolului laparoscopiei în CA în Pubmed şi Medline în perioada ianuarie 2000 - decembrie 2007. Articolele de chirurgie infantilă, cele referitoare la plăgile abdominale, urgenţele abdominale nontraumatice, leziunile iatrogene au fost excluse. Am evaluat 66 de articole care au inclus 22 de studii clinice, 27 de serii de cazuri, 17 review-uri şi 2 ghiduri. Studiile clinice au însumat 343 pacienţi cu CA abordaţi laparoscopic. Laparoscopia terapeutică a fost posibilă la 168 de pacienţi (48,98%). 51 de pacienţi au impus conversia(14,87%). Nu au fost leziuni omise, au fost doar 6 pacienţi cu complicaţii (1,75%) şi nu s-au înregistrat decese imputabile laparoscopiei. Indicaţiile principale ale laparoscopiei diagnostice în CA sunt reprezentate de suspiciunea de leziune diafragmatică respectiv suspiciunea de leziuni ale organelor cavitare la pacienţii cu examen clinic şi explorări imagistice echivoc. Este indicată şi în cazul pacienţilor cu suspiciune de leziuni traumatice viscerale la care nu se poate efectua în urgenţă explorări imagistice performante. În concluzie, deşi puţin utilizată, dovada fiind şi numărul redus de articole publicate, laparoscopia poate fi utilă la pacienţii cu CA dacă sunt selectaţi cu atenţie. Diagnostică echivoc în scopul reducerii incidenţei laparotomiilor inutile. Studii multicentrice prospective sunt necesare pentru a contura mai precis rolul laparoscopiei în CA."
Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, data sources, study selection criteria, results, and conclusions. However, it lacks information on participants, interventions, study appraisal and synthesis methods, limitations, and systematic review registration number.
[No]

P3
Quote: "Unfortunately, trauma is still the leading cause of death in people under 50 years of age (1). However, remarkable progress has been made in trauma management over the past few years that includes various specific protocols, emergence of a new surgical specialty (trauma and emergency surgery), non-operative management, damage control techniques, improved imaging investigations and minimally invasive therapy (1-4)."

With exploratory laparotomies, early postoperative complications reach an average incidence of 12-40%, late postoperative complications are 2-5%, and are associated with a death rate of 0-5% (16). The most common complications include pneumothorax, iatrogenic, visceral injuries, and extraperitoneal insufflation (4,8,13).There were no cases of gas embolization, not even in cases with large vessel injury."

P1
Quote: "Is laparoscopy still needed in blunt abdominal trauma?"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as addressing laparoscopy in blunt abdominal trauma, but does not explicitly state it is a systematic review.
[No]

P2
Quote: "Laparoscopia diagnostică şi terapeutică în contuziile abdominale (CA) are o utilizare limitată şi cine controversată, datorită în special progreselor făcute de explorările imagistice actuale. Scopul lucrării noastre este de a evalua rolul actual al laparoscopiei în CA. Am efectuat un studiu al articolelor publicate asupra rolului laparoscopiei în CA în Pubmed şi Medline în perioada ianuarie 2000 - decembrie 2007. Articolele de chirurgie infantilă, cele referitoare la plăgile abdominale, urgenţele abdominale nontraumatice, leziunile iatrogene au fost excluse. Am evaluat 66 de articole care au inclus 22 de studii clinice, 27 de serii de cazuri, 17 review-uri şi 2 ghiduri. Studiile clinice au însumat 343 pacienţi cu CA abordaţi laparoscopic. Laparoscopia terapeutică a fost posibilă la 168 de pacienţi (48,98%). 51 de pacienţi au impus conversia(14,87%). Nu au fost leziuni omise, au fost doar 6 pacienţi cu complicaţii (1,75%) şi nu s-au înregistrat decese imputabile laparoscopiei. Indicaţiile principale ale laparoscopiei diagnostice în CA sunt reprezentate de suspiciunea de leziune diafragmatică respectiv suspiciunea de leziuni ale organelor cavitare la pacienţii cu examen clinic şi explorări imagistice echivoc. Este indicată şi în cazul pacienţilor cu suspiciune de leziuni traumatice viscerale la care nu se poate efectua în urgenţă explorări imagistice performante. În concluzie, deşi puţin utilizată, dovada fiind şi numărul redus de articole publicate, laparoscopia poate fi utilă la pacienţii cu CA dacă sunt selectaţi cu atenţie. Diagnostică echivoc în scopul reducerii incidenţei laparotomiilor inutile. Studii multicentrice prospective sunt necesare pentru a contura mai precis rolul laparoscopiei în CA."
Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, data sources, study selection criteria, results, and conclusions. However, it lacks information on participants, interventions, study appraisal and synthesis methods, limitations, and systematic review registration number.
[No]

P3. Introduction / Rationale
Quotes: "For many years, boys with aphallia have been referred for early female gender reassignment [3]. However, many children undergoing feminization refute the redesignated gender after puberty despite orchiectomy [4,5]. Moreover, an emerging paradigm suggests that gender reassignment should be performed preferably before puberty, taking into account psychological and psychiatric evaluation and counseling [6]."
Reasoning: The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of current knowledge.

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence
Quotes: "In assessing recent literature, it seems rational that neophalloplasty should be regarded as the preferred strategy for boys born with aphallia, in opposition to female gender assignment."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized with consideration of their relevance to key stakeholders.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
Quotes: "Recent literature documents a move away from female gender reassignment in aphallia, limited our group of patients to only 19 articles, and in some of them, adult patients were included with children in the same series (Table 1). A further analysis, searching articles describing neophalloplasty techniques in aphallia, limited our group consists of non-microsurgical techniques, including flap techniques. These have the advantage of simplicity and feasibility to be performed at younger age, but are necessarily planned according to a two-stage strategy, combined with prosthesis implantation in adolescence."
Reasoning: Limitations at the study and review level are discussed.
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
Quotes: "As a personal input, based on this review and considering our personal experience, we still believe that flap techniques should be the first choice when treating a child with penile agenesis."
Reasoning: A general interpretation of the results is provided along with implications for practice.
[Yes]

P27. Funding
Quotes: "Funding: None."
Reasoning: Funding sources for the systematic review are reported.
[Yes]

Quotes: None relevant.

Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No additional analyses are mentioned and no quantitative synthesis was performed.
[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence
Quotes: "In assessing recent literature, it seems rational that neophalloplasty should be regarded as the preferred strategy for boys born with aphallia, in opposition to female gender assignment."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized with consideration of their relevance to key stakeholders.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
Quotes: "Recent literature documents a move away from female gender reassignment in aphallia, limited our group of patients to only 19 articles, and in some of them, adult patients were included with children in the same series (Table 1). A further analysis, searching articles describing neophalloplasty techniques in aphallia, limited our group consists of non-microsurgical techniques, including flap techniques. These have the advantage of simplicity and feasibility to be performed at younger age, but are necessarily planned according to a two-stage strategy, combined with prosthesis implantation in adolescence."
Reasoning: Limitations at the study and review level are discussed.
[Yes]

Reasoning: A general interpretation of the results is provided along with implications for practice.
[Yes]

Quotes: "Funding: None."
Reasoning: Funding sources for the systematic review are reported.
[Yes]

llm_message:
A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quotes: "We adhered to PRISMA guidelines for this systematic review [6]. The PubMed database was searched for studies of children with EA and RAA published from January 1990 to December 2014."
Reasoning: The authors mention adhering to PRISMA guidelines, but do not specify an a priori protocol or pre-registered objectives.
[No]

llm_message:
Here is the assessment of the systematic review using AMSTAR and PRISMA:

A1
Quote: "Purpose: Aim of this systematic review is to investigate the thoracic and cervical surgical approaches of H-type tracheo-esophageal fistula (TEF) according to the position of the fistula."
Reasoning: The research question and inclusion criteria are clearly stated in the purpose.
[Yes]

A2
Quotes: "Two independent authors extracted information related to the study. Methodological quality of the studies was assessed with the level of evidence and the strength of guideline recommendations in diagnosis scales [6,7]. For each study, data were extracted for three primary outcomes and three secondary outcomes. The primary outcomes were the number of treated patients, the study duration and the surgical approach. For open surgery group, the secondary outcomes were the level of the fistula, the use of contrast studies, the use of endoscopy, the cumulation of the fistula, the complications and the mortality. For thoracoscopic series, secondary outcome were the level of the fistula, the complications and the mortality, and many surgical details."
Reasoning: Two independent authors extracted the data and assessed study quality.
[Yes]

A3
Quotes: "For this systematic review we adhered to PRISMA guidelines [4,5]. The PubMed database (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/) was searched for studies on treatment of H-type TEF that were published since January 1977."
Reasoning: Only one database (PubMed) was searched, without any supplementary strategies.
[No]

A4
Quotes: "The following keywords were searched individually or in association: isolated trachea-esophageal fistula, H-type tracheo-esophageal fistula, N-type tracheo-esophageal fistula, cervicotomy, thoracotomy and thoracoscopy. The date of the last search was December 2012."
Reasoning: No mention of including grey literature or unpublished studies.
[No]

A5
Quote: "Fig. 1. Identification of studies from PubMed databases and inclusion in the systematic review."
Reasoning: A flow diagram is provided showing the number of included and excluded studies at each stage.
[Yes]

A6
Quotes: "For each study, data were extracted for three primary outcomes and three secondary outcomes. The primary outcomes were the number of treated patients, the study duration and the surgical approach. For open surgery group, the secondary outcomes were the level of the fistula, the use of contrast studies, the use of endoscopy, the cumulation of the fistula, the complications and the mortality. For thoracoscopic series, secondary outcome were the level of the fistula, the complications and the mortality, and many surgical details."
"The initial PubMed search yielded 185 potentially relevant articles. Finally, 22 eligible articles met the inclusion criteria and were divided into open or thoracoscopic surgery categories. All reviewed study were uncontrolled studies using retrospective data, such as case report or case series (classes of evidence III and rating scales of evidence E) [6]. No randomized-controlled trials or prospective studies comparing the different surgical approaches were found."
Reasoning: Key characteristics of the included studies like outcomes, study designs, number of patients are provided in aggregate form.
[Yes]

A7
Quotes: "Methodological quality of the studies was assessed with the level of evidence and the strength of guideline recommendations in diagnosis scales [6,7]."
"All reviewed study were uncontrolled studies using retrospective data, such as case report or case series (classes of evidence III and rating scales of evidence E) [6]."
Reasoning: The methodological quality was assessed using level of evidence scales, with the studies being rated as low quality (class III evidence).
[Yes]

A8
Quote: "The evidence base in regard to the treatment of H-type TEF, although not negligible, is poor and the skills and preferences of the surgeons guide the choice of the procedure."
Reasoning: The limitations of the evidence base are acknowledged when formulating the conclusions.
[Yes]

A9
Reasoning: This is a systematic review without a meta-analysis, so assessing the methods for combining studies is not applicable.
[NA]

A10
Reasoning: This is a systematic review without a meta-analysis, so assessing publication bias is not applicable. 
[NA]

A11
Reasoning: The sources of funding and support for the systematic review are disclosed, but not for each individual included study.
[No]

P1
Quote: "Cervical/thoracotomic/thoracoscopic approaches for H-type congenital tracheo-esophageal fistula: A systematic review"  
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review.
[Yes]

P2
Reasoning: The abstract is not structured into distinct labeled sections like Background, Methods, Results, etc.
[No]  

P3
Quote: "Tracheo-esophageal fistula (TEF) without esophageal atresia (H-type TEF) is a rare congenital malformation that accounts for about 4% of tracheo-esophageal malformations and has an incidence of around 1:50,000–80,000 births [1]. Surgical division of the fistula is curative, and the key to a successful repair is the pre-operatively identification of the level of the fistula with tracheoscopy, usually performed in collaboration with pediatric otorhinolaryngologists [2]. Although there is a general agreement that in the majority of H-type TEF cervicotomy is the approach of choice [3], when the fistula is located near the border between the neck and the thorax choosing the appropriate approach, cervical or thoracic is difficult."
Reasoning: Relevant background information is provided to describe the rationale for the review.
[Yes]

P4
Quote: "Purpose: Aim of this systematic review is to investigate the thoracic and cervical surgical approaches of H-type tracheo-esophageal fistula (TEF) according to the position of the fistula."
Reasoning: The objectives are explicitly stated, but do not mention all PICOS elements.
[No]

P5
Reasoning: No mention of a review protocol or registration number.
[No]

P6
Quotes: "Inclusion criteria were English and French articles that reported original data on treatment of newborn affected by trachea-esophageal fistula without esophageal atresia. Eligible study designs were case report, case series and review. The study selection process is presented in Fig. 1."
"Manuscripts finally included in the study were divided into two categories: open and thoracoscopic surgery."
Reasoning: Eligibility criteria related to study characteristics (study designs, population, intervention) and report characteristics (language) are specified.
[Yes]  

P7
Quote: "For this systematic review we adhered to PRISMA guidelines [4,5]. The PubMed database (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/) was searched for studies on treatment of H-type TEF that were published since January 1977. The following keywords were searched individually or in association: isolated trachea-esophageal fistula, H-type tracheo-esophageal fistula, N-type tracheo-esophageal fistula, cervicotomy, thoracotomy and thoracoscopy. The date of the last search was December 2012."
Reasoning: The electronic database searched (PubMed) and date last searched are reported.
[Yes]

P8
Reasoning: The full search strategy is not presented for the database searched.
[No]  

P9
Quote: "Fig. 1. Identification of studies from PubMed databases and inclusion in the systematic review."
Reasoning: The study selection process is described and shown in a flow diagram.
[Yes]

P10
Quotes: "Two independent authors extracted information related to the study. Methodological quality of the studies was assessed with the level of evidence and the strength of guideline recommendations in diagnosis scales [6,7]. For each study, data were extracted for three primary outcomes and three secondary outcomes."
Reasoning: The data extraction process is described, including two independent authors extracting the data.
[Yes]

P11
Quotes: "The primary outcomes were the number of treated patients, the study duration and the surgical approach. For open surgery group, the secondary outcomes were the level of the fistula, the use of contrast studies, the use of endoscopy, the cumulation of the fistula, the complications and the mortality. For thoracoscopic series, secondary outcome were the level of the fistula, the complications and the mortality, and many surgical details."
Reasoning: The variables for which data were sought are defined.
[Yes]

P12
Quotes: "Methodological quality of the studies was assessed with the level of evidence and the strength of guideline recommendations in diagnosis scales [6,7]."
Reasoning: The method of assessing risk of bias is described (using level of evidence scales).
[Yes]

P13
Reasoning: The principal summary measures are not explicitly stated.
[No]

P14
Reasoning: This is a systematic review without a meta-analysis, so methods for combining results are not applicable.
[NA]

P15 
Reasoning: This is a systematic review without a meta-analysis, so assessing risk of bias across studies is not applicable.
[NA]

P16
Reasoning: No additional analyses are mentioned.
[No]

P17
Quote: "Fig. 1. Identification of studies from PubMed databases and inclusion in the systematic review."
Reasoning: A flow diagram is provided showing the number of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, included and excluded with reasons at each stage.
[Yes]

P18
Quotes: "The initial PubMed search yielded 185 potentially relevant articles. Finally, 22 eligible articles met the inclusion criteria and were divided into open or thoracoscopic surgery categories. All reviewed study were uncontrolled studies using retrospective data, such as case report or case series (classes of evidence III and rating scales of evidence E) [6]."
Reasoning: The characteristics of the included studies are presented, but individual study citations are not provided.
[No]

P19
Reasoning: Results of the risk of bias assessment for individual studies are not presented.
[No]  

P20
Reasoning: Simple summary data for each group and effect estimates for each study are not provided.
[No]

P21
Reasoning: This is a systematic review without a meta-analysis, so results of meta-analyses are not applicable.
[NA]  

P22
Reasoning: This is a systematic review without a meta-analysis, so results of risk of bias across studies are not applicable.
[NA]

P23
Reasoning: No additional analyses are mentioned.
[NA]

P24
Quotes: "The evidence base in regard to the treatment of H-type TEF, although not negligible, is poor and the skills and preferences of the surgeons guide the choice of the procedure."
"In these children thoracoscopy has proved to be a safe and effective technique, achieving outcome comparable to open surgery, but avoiding the long-term morbidity and scarring associated to thoracotomy."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized, including their relevance to surgeons.
[Yes]  

P25
Quote: "Conclusions: The evidence base in regard to the treatment of H-type fistula in children is poor, and as well stated by Tovar and Fragoso [31], in the absence of evidence-based strategies, "eminence-based" ones are legitimate. Further well-designed pre-operative diagnosis of the fistula, right cervicotomy seems to be the approach of choice in the majority of case, with the thoracic approach appropriate only for fistulae opening below T2."
Reasoning: Limitations of the evidence base are discussed.
[Yes]

P26
Quote: "Further well-designed prospective studies are required to take into account selection and performance bias, and the issue of confounding are strongly required."
Reasoning: Implications for future research are provided.
[Yes]

P27
Quote: "The authors have no financial relationships relevant to this article to disclose."
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review are disclosed.
[Yes]

Although there is a general agreement that in the majority of H-type TEF cervicotomy is the approach of choice [3], when the fistula is located near the border between the neck and the thorax choosing the appropriate approach, cervical or thoracic is difficult."
Reasoning: Relevant background information is provided to describe the rationale for the review.
[Yes]

P4
Quote: "Purpose: Aim of this systematic review is to investigate the thoracic and cervical surgical approaches of H-type tracheo-esophageal fistula (TEF) according to the position of the fistula."
Reasoning: The objectives are explicitly stated, but do not mention all PICOS elements.
[No]

P5
Reasoning: No mention of a review protocol or registration number.
[No]

P6
Quotes: "Inclusion criteria were English and French articles that reported original data on treatment of newborn affected by trachea-esophageal fistula without esophageal atresia. Eligible study designs were case report, case series and review. The study selection process is presented in Fig. 1."
"Manuscripts finally included in the study were divided into two categories: open and thoracoscopic surgery."
Reasoning: Eligibility criteria related to study characteristics (study designs, population, intervention) and report characteristics (language) are specified.
[Yes]  

P7
Quote: "For this systematic review we adhered to PRISMA guidelines [4,5]. The PubMed database (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/) was searched for studies on treatment of H-type TEF that were published since January 1977. The following keywords were searched individually or in association: isolated trachea-esophageal fistula, H-type tracheo-esophageal fistula, N-type tracheo-esophageal fistula, cervicotomy, thoracotomy and thoracoscopy. The date of the last search was December 2012."
Reasoning: The electronic database searched (PubMed) and date last searched are reported.
[Yes]

P8
Reasoning: The full search strategy is not presented for the database searched.
[No]  

P9
Quote: "Fig. 1. Identification of studies from PubMed databases and inclusion in the systematic review."
Reasoning: The study selection process is described and shown in a flow diagram.
[Yes]

P10
Quotes: "Two independent authors extracted information related to the study. Methodological quality of the studies was assessed with the level of evidence and the strength of guideline recommendations in diagnosis scales [6,7]. For each study, data were extracted for three primary outcomes and three secondary outcomes."
Reasoning: The data extraction process is described, including two independent authors extracting the data.
[Yes]

P11
Quotes: "The primary outcomes were the number of treated patients, the study duration and the surgical approach. For open surgery group, the secondary outcomes were the level of the fistula, the use of contrast studies, the use of endoscopy, the cumulation of the fistula, the complications and the mortality. For thoracoscopic series, secondary outcome were the level of the fistula, the complications and the mortality, and many surgical details."
Reasoning: The variables for which data were sought are defined.
[Yes]

P12
Quotes: "Methodological quality of the studies was assessed with the level of evidence and the strength of guideline recommendations in diagnosis scales [6,7]."
Reasoning: The method of assessing risk of bias is described (using level of evidence scales).
[Yes]

P13
Reasoning: The principal summary measures are not explicitly stated.
[No]

P14
Reasoning: This is a systematic review without a meta-analysis, so methods for combining results are not applicable.
[NA]

P15 
Reasoning: This is a systematic review without a meta-analysis, so assessing risk of bias across studies is not applicable.
[NA]

P16
Reasoning: No additional analyses are mentioned.
[No]

P17
Quote: "Fig. 1. Identification of studies from PubMed databases and inclusion in the systematic review."
Reasoning: A flow diagram is provided showing the number of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, included and excluded with reasons at each stage.
[Yes]

P18
Quotes: "The initial PubMed search yielded 185 potentially relevant articles. Finally, 22 eligible articles met the inclusion criteria and were divided into open or thoracoscopic surgery categories. All reviewed study were uncontrolled studies using retrospective data, such as case report or case series (classes of evidence III and rating scales of evidence E) [6]."
Reasoning: The characteristics of the included studies are presented, but individual study citations are not provided.
[No]

P19
Reasoning: Results of the risk of bias assessment for individual studies are not presented.
[No]  

P20
Reasoning: Simple summary data for each group and effect estimates for each study are not provided.
[No]

P21
Reasoning: This is a systematic review without a meta-analysis, so results of meta-analyses are not applicable.
[NA]  

P22
Reasoning: This is a systematic review without a meta-analysis, so results of risk of bias across studies are not applicable.
[NA]

P23
Reasoning: No additional analyses are mentioned.
[NA]

P24
Quotes: "The evidence base in regard to the treatment of H-type TEF, although not negligible, is poor and the skills and preferences of the surgeons guide the choice of the procedure."
"In these children thoracoscopy has proved to be a safe and effective technique, achieving outcome comparable to open surgery, but avoiding the long-term morbidity and scarring associated to thoracotomy."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized, including their relevance to surgeons.
[Yes]  

P25
Quote: "Conclusions: The evidence base in regard to the treatment of H-type fistula in children is poor, and as well stated by Tovar and Fragoso [31], in the absence of evidence-based strategies, "eminence-based" ones are legitimate. Further well-designed pre-operative diagnosis of the fistula, right cervicotomy seems to be the approach of choice in the majority of case, with the thoracic approach appropriate only for fistulae opening below T2."
Reasoning: Limitations of the evidence base are discussed.
[Yes]

P26
Quote: "Further well-designed prospective studies are required to take into account selection and performance bias, and the issue of confounding are strongly required."
Reasoning: Implications for future research are provided.
[Yes]

P27
Quote: "The authors have no financial relationships relevant to this article to disclose."
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review are disclosed.
[Yes]

"Total esophagogastric dissociation (TOGD) is an anti-reflux procedure originally described as a "rescue" procedure for use in children with neurological impairment (NI) by Bianchi [1] in 1997. TOGD is now used as both a primary surgical procedure and as "rescue" therapy following failed fundoplication."
The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known about the procedure.

"One hundred eighty-one patients who had undergone TOGD were identified from 10 articles, personal communication with authors of these articles and data held at our institution (Table 1, Fig. 1) [2–6,9–13]. A two-center study combining data from Manchester and Rome was analyzed to gain the Rome data [5]."
The results mention the total number of patients and articles, and provide citations, but do not present the extracted study characteristics for each study.

A1
"The purpose of this review is to update the use of MIS in pediatric oncological surgery over the past five years."
The review purpose is stated, but there is no mention of an a priori protocol or pre-specified objectives.
[No]

A2
No mention of duplicate study selection or data extraction.
[No]

A3
"The authors conducted a systematic review of papers published between 2009 and 2014 focusing on indications and results of the technique."
Only one database (PubMed) was searched from 2009-2014. No search terms provided.
[No]

A4
No mention of including grey literature.
[No]

A5
No list of included and excluded studies provided.
[No]

A6
"References for this review were identified by PubMed searches using appropriate search terms for each section ("minimally invasive surgery," "laparoscopy," "thoracoscopy," "childhood/children/pediatric cancer")."
Some study characteristics like search terms and populations are provided in aggregate, but no details on individual included studies.
[No]

A7
No mention of assessing study quality.
[No]

A8
No assessment of study quality, so quality could not be used to formulate conclusions.
[No]

A9
"Case control studies comparing MIS to open approach have been published for the first time in more classical indications such as neurogenic tumors, while robot-assisted procedure has shown concern in results about its early experience in solid tumors."
Qualitative statements are made about the results, but no quantitative synthesis was performed.
[NA]

A10
No assessment of publication bias.
[NA]

A11
"Conflict of Interest
None."
The review declares no conflicts of interest, but the funding sources of the included studies are not reported.
[No]

P1
"Minimally Invasive Surgery in Childhood Cancer: A Challenging Future"
The title identifies the article as a review on minimally invasive surgery in childhood cancer.
[Yes]

P2
The abstract has labeled sections for background, methods, results, and conclusion. However, some key elements like participants, interventions, appraisal and synthesis methods are missing.
[No]

P3
"Minimally invasive surgery (MIS) has emerged as an alternative to open approach for cancer diagnosis in children ∼20 years ago, but only recently for tumor resection."
The introduction provides rationale for the review in the context of the emergence of MIS in pediatric oncology.
[Yes]

P4
"The purpose of this review is to update the use of MIS in pediatric oncological surgery over the past five years."
The introduction states the review purpose, but does not explicitly mention the PICOS elements.
[No]

P5
No mention of a review protocol or registration.
[No]

P6
"References for this review were identified by PubMed searches using appropriate search terms for each section ("minimally invasive surgery," "laparoscopy," "thoracoscopy," "childhood/children/pediatric cancer"). Articles were also identified by searching the authors' own files. Only papers published in English language were reviewed."
Eligibility criteria related to databases, years, search terms, language are provided. No rationale is given.
[No]

P7
"References for this review were identified by PubMed searches using appropriate search terms for each section ("minimally invasive surgery," "laparoscopy," "thoracoscopy," "childhood/children/pediatric cancer"). Articles were also identified by searching the authors' own files."
PubMed and authors' files were searched, but no dates of coverage or last search date are provided.
[No]

P8
No search strategy provided.
[No]

P9
No description of the study selection process.
[No]

P10
No description of the data collection process.
[No]

P11
No list of variables for which data were sought.
[No]

P12
No description of assessing risk of bias in individual studies.
[No]

P13
No summary measures specified, as no meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P14
No description of methods for combining results, as no meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P15
No mention of assessing risk of bias across studies.
[NA]

P16
No description of any additional analyses.
[NA]

P17
No PRISMA flow diagram provided showing the number of studies screened, included and excluded.
[No]

P18
No details on individual study characteristics provided.
[No]

P19
No assessment of risk of bias of individual studies reported.
[No]

P20
Some qualitative statements are made summarizing the results of individual studies, but no quantitative summary data or effect estimates are provided.
[No]

P21
No meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P22
No assessment of risk of bias across studies was reported.
[NA]

P23
No additional analyses were reported.
[NA]

P24
"MIS is a promising method for removal of thoracic and abdominal malignancies as long as oncological principles are strictly followed. Long-term follow-up is mandatory to further delineate objective indications."
The discussion summarizes the main findings and their relevance to clinicians.
[Yes]

P25
"Shorter postoperative course, shorter hospital stay, less use of narcotics, early first oral intake, early recovery, less bowel adhesion formation, and decreased risk of wound infections and incisional hernias allow early adjuvant treatment with either chemotherapy or radiotherapy, which is the ultimate goal in the battle against cancer."
Some limitations related to shorter postoperative course and early adjuvant therapy are discussed. Review-level limitations like incomplete retrieval of studies and reporting bias are not mentioned.
[No]

P26
"MIS, regardless of the approach—thoracoscopy, laparoscopy, retroperitoneoscopy, robot-assisted—is a new field in pediatric solid tumors with no randomized trials to date. Only case control studies have shown its noninferiority to open approach, but in experienced hands and with the absolute respect to oncological rules. MIS is a tempting procedure needing further development to precisely define its objective indications and limits in oncological pediatric surgery."
The conclusion provides a general interpretation and implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27
"Conflict of Interest
None."
The review's funding source is reported, but the role of the funder is not described.
[No]

llm_message:
A1
"A systematic literature search was undertaken, using Medline and Pubmed, in order to identify relevant articles. Random effects models were used to estimate pooled complication rates. Meta-regression was performed for each outcome by using mixed effects models with type of hypospadias (primary distal, primary proximal and secondary) as predictors."
The authors describe using a systematic search and pre-specified methods for data synthesis and analysis.
[Yes]

A2
No relevant quotes found. The authors do not mention using at least two independent reviewers for study selection and data extraction.
[No]

A3
"Medline and Pubmed were searched in order to identify articles published between 1994 and 2012. The search terms 'tubularized incised plate urethroplasty/Snodgrass repair/ technique and outcomes/complications ± follow-up/long term follow-up' were used."
The authors searched Medline and PubMed, but do not mention supplementing the search with other methods like reviewing references or consulting experts.
[No]

A4
No relevant quotes found. The authors do not mention whether they included grey literature.
[No]

A5
No relevant quotes found. The authors do not provide a list of included and excluded studies.
[No]

A6
"The following data were extracted independently from each article by two reviewers (M.P and P.C): study size; degree of hypospadias (classified by meatal location: distal — midshaft distally, proximal — proximal shaft proximally); primary or secondary repair; repair type (standard vs modified TIP); modification (if used); mean length of follow-up; study duration; geographical location; and rates of meatal stenosis, fistula, urethral stricture and unplanned re-operation to treat complications."
The authors provide aggregate study characteristics in the methods section.
[Yes]

A7
"Of the 189 studies identified, 49 studies (4675 patients) were included in the analysis. Fistula and re-operation rates were significantly higher in secondary repairs (15.5% and 23.3%) compared to primary proximal (10.3% and 12.2%) and primary distal (5.7% and 4.5%) (P = 0.045 and P < 0.001, respectively). Meatal stenosis rates were significantly higher in primary proximal repairs, with follow-up >1 year (12.7%). Comparison of geographical location showed that complication rates for all but one variable were significantly lower in North America when compared to Europe and the rest of the world."
The authors assessed study quality by comparing complication rates by repair type, follow-up duration, and geographical location.
[Yes]

A8
"This meta-analysis shows the lowest complication rates for the TIP repair when it is applied to primary distal hypospadias, with mean rates of meatal stenosis at 3.6% (range 1.7–7.4%), urethral stricture at 1.3% (range 0.8–2.2%), fistula at 5.7% (range 4.0–8.2%) and re-operation at 4.5% (range 2.7–7.5%). The fistula rate is higher than the reoperation rate as one paper reports spontaneous healing of three fistulae [24]. Several studies, including the review paper by Wilkinson et al. [66] reported a lower fistula rate but similar meatal stenosis rates, and Snodgrass reported a 2% fistula rate for the distal repairs [67]. It should be noted that the mode of evaluating complications varied between papers, with no standardised method of assessment. Performing a meta-analysis of the published data has given a pooled estimate of the complication rates assessed, by encompassing all the documented results showing that the TIP repair is a transferable technique that provides good outcomes in primary distal hypospadias."
The authors consider the study quality assessment in their conclusions, noting the lowest complication rates are for primary distal repairs but acknowledging the variability in how complications were evaluated across studies.
[Yes]

A9
"Analyses were conducted using random and mixed-effects models, with the restricted maximum likelihood (REML) estimator. Proportions were expressed on the logit scale for analysis, and 0.5 was added to the numerator and denominators of outcomes with no events to prevent infinities. Estimated complication rates were calculated using random effects models for each type of hypospadias (primary distal, primary proximal and secondary), location (grouped into North America, Europe and rest of the world), and modified vs standard TIP repair."
The authors used appropriate methods to combine the findings, using random effects models and transforming proportions to the logit scale for analysis.
[Yes]

No relevant quotes found. The authors do not mention assessing publication bias.
[NA]

"None of the authors have any conflicts of interest or funding to declare."
The authors report no conflicts of interest for the systematic review, but do not report on conflicts of interest for the included primary studies.
[No]

llm_message:
A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quote: "The American Pediatric Surgical Association (APSA) Outcomes and Evidence Based Practice (OEBP) committee selected the following questions for this systematic review:"
The research questions were established a priori by the APSA OEBP committee.
[Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
Quote: "Studies selected for inclusion were critically appraised and ranked on their level of evidence based on the type of study (retrospective or prospective, randomized or not) per The Oxford Centre for Evidence Based Medicine (Table 1) [3], which also guided the recommendations generated for each question. Data compiled for each article included sample size, description of the procedures performed or medications used, method of ventilation, use of ECMO, timing of repair, outcomes including mortality and morbidity, and type of patch used."
Two authors independently selected studies and extracted data.
[Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quote: "Separate search terms were applied for each question using the MEDLINE, Embase, Cochrane, and Web of Science databases. Searches were limited to articles published in the English language from January 1, 1980 through January 31, 2014."
At least 2 electronic databases were searched with key terms from 1980-2014.
[Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
No mention of including grey literature or unpublished studies.
[No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
No list of included or excluded studies was provided.
[No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quote: "A total of 3097 abstracts underwent initial title screening. Of these, 189 abstracts were selected for in-depth review of the abstract and/or full manuscript. We selected 98 of these manuscripts for the systematic review (Fig. 1). Most of the selected articles represented single institution experiences and large case series."
The number of included studies and some study characteristics were provided in aggregate form, but no table with detailed characteristics of each included study was provided.
[No]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
Quote: "Studies selected for inclusion were critically appraised and ranked on their level of evidence based on the type of study (retrospective or prospective, randomized or not) per The Oxford Centre for Evidence Based Medicine (Table 1) [3], which also guided the recommendations generated for each question."
The level of evidence of included studies was assessed using the Oxford CEBM criteria and used to guide recommendations.
[Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
Quote: "Based on level 2 evidence, iNO cannot be recommended to routinely treat PHTN in CDH patients (Grade C recommendation)"
The level of evidence was considered when making recommendations.
[Yes]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
The systematic review did not perform any quantitative synthesis or meta-analysis.
[NA]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
The systematic review did not assess publication bias.
[NA]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
Conflicts of interest for the systematic review authors were reported, but not for the included studies.
[No]

P1. Title
Quote: "Management of congenital diaphragmatic hernia: A systematic review from the APSA outcomes and evidence based practice committee"
The title identifies the article as a systematic review.
[Yes]

P2. Abstract
The abstract is structured with labeled sections for background, methods, results, and conclusions.
[Yes]  

P3. Introduction / Rationale
Quote: "Despite significant advances in neonatal and surgical care, the management of newborns with congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) remains a challenge. Significant variations in approach exist with regard to the use of antenatal steroids, ventilation modes, timing of repair, and pulmonary hypertension, the use of extra-corporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO), and the timing and type of surgical repair [1]."
The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of variations in CDH management.
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives
Quote: "The American Pediatric Surgical Association (APSA) Outcomes and Evidence Based Practice (OEBP) committee selected the following questions for this systematic review: 1. What is the optimal ventilator strategy for a newborn with CDH? 2. What is the best way to manage CDH-associated pulmonary hypertension (PHTN)? 3. Is there benefit to the use of pre- or postnatal corticosteroids? 4. Which mode of ECMO is best for CDH, and what is the optimal duration of treatment with ECMO? 5. What is the optimal technique to repair CDH (open versus minimally invasive) and which type of patch has the best outcome? 6. Is early repair or late repair of CDH better?"
The introduction provides explicit questions being addressed.
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration
No mention of a protocol or registration number.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria
Quote: "Studies that did not address the neonatal population were excluded, as were opinion pieces, case reports, and editorial review articles (other than systematic reviews or meta analyses). The automated searches were supplemented by a manual search of additional references from the bibliographies of included studies."
Eligibility criteria regarding study design, population, and supplemental searches were described.
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources
Quote: "Separate search terms were applied for each question using the MEDLINE, Embase, Cochrane, and Web of Science databases. Searches were limited to articles published in the English language from January 1, 1980 through January 31, 2014."
Databases searched and dates of coverage were reported.
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search
No full search strategy was provided.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection
Quote: "Studies that did not address the neonatal population were excluded, as were opinion pieces, case reports, and editorial review articles (other than systematic reviews or meta analyses). The automated searches were supplemented by a manual search of additional references from the bibliographies of included studies."
The process for selecting studies was described.
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process
Quote: "Studies selected for inclusion were critically appraised and ranked on their level of evidence based on the type of study (retrospective or prospective, randomized or not) per The Oxford Centre for Evidence Based Medicine (Table 1) [3], which also guided the recommendations generated for each question. Data compiled for each article included sample size, description of the procedures performed or medications used, method of ventilation, use of ECMO, timing of repair, outcomes including mortality and morbidity, and type of patch used."
The data extraction process was described.
[Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items
Quote: "Data compiled for each article included sample size, description of the procedures performed or medications used, method of ventilation, use of ECMO, timing of repair, outcomes including mortality and morbidity, and type of patch used."
The data items collected were listed.
[Yes]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies
Quote: "Studies selected for inclusion were critically appraised and ranked on their level of evidence based on the type of study (retrospective or prospective, randomized or not) per The Oxford Centre for Evidence Based Medicine (Table 1) [3], which also guided the recommendations generated for each question."
Risk of bias was assessed using the Oxford CEBM levels of evidence.
[Yes]

P13. Methods / Summary measures
No summary measures were specified, as no quantitative synthesis was performed.
[NA]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results
No quantitative synthesis or meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies
No assessment of risk of bias across studies, such as publication bias, was reported.
[No]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses
No additional analyses were reported.
[NA]

P17. Results / Study selection
Quote: "A total of 3097 abstracts underwent initial title screening. Of these, 189 abstracts were selected for in-depth review of the abstract and/or full manuscript. We selected 98 of these manuscripts for the systematic review (Fig. 1)."
The numbers of studies screened and included were reported, but no flow diagram was provided.
[No]

P18. Results / Study characteristics
Quote: "Most of the selected articles represented single institution experiences and large case series."

original_llm_message:
A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quote: "The American Pediatric Surgical Association (APSA) Outcomes and Evidence Based Practice (OEBP) committee selected the following questions for this systematic review:"
The research questions were established a priori by the APSA OEBP committee.
[Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
Quote: "Studies selected for inclusion were critically appraised and ranked on their level of evidence based on the type of study (retrospective or prospective, randomized or not) per The Oxford Centre for Evidence Based Medicine (Table 1) [3], which also guided the recommendations generated for each question. Data compiled for each article included sample size, description of the procedures performed or medications used, method of ventilation, use of ECMO, timing of repair, outcomes including mortality and morbidity, and type of patch used."
Two authors independently selected studies and extracted data.
[Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quote: "Separate search terms were applied for each question using the MEDLINE, Embase, Cochrane, and Web of Science databases. Searches were limited to articles published in the English language from January 1, 1980 through January 31, 2014."
At least 2 electronic databases were searched with key terms from 1980-2014.
[Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
No mention of including grey literature or unpublished studies.
[No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
No list of included or excluded studies was provided.
[No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quote: "A total of 3097 abstracts underwent initial title screening. Of these, 189 abstracts were selected for in-depth review of the abstract and/or full manuscript. We selected 98 of these manuscripts for the systematic review (Fig. 1). Most of the selected articles represented single institution experiences and large case series."
The number of included studies and some study characteristics were provided in aggregate form, but no table with detailed characteristics of each included study was provided.
[No]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
Quote: "Studies selected for inclusion were critically appraised and ranked on their level of evidence based on the type of study (retrospective or prospective, randomized or not) per The Oxford Centre for Evidence Based Medicine (Table 1) [3], which also guided the recommendations generated for each question."
The level of evidence of included studies was assessed using the Oxford CEBM criteria and used to guide recommendations.
[Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
Quote: "Based on level 2 evidence, iNO cannot be recommended to routinely treat PHTN in CDH patients (Grade C recommendation)"
The level of evidence was considered when making recommendations.
[Yes]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
The systematic review did not perform any quantitative synthesis or meta-analysis.
[NA]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
The systematic review did not assess publication bias.
[NA]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
Conflicts of interest for the systematic review authors were reported, but not for the included studies.
[No]

P1. Title
Quote: "Management of congenital diaphragmatic hernia: A systematic review from the APSA outcomes and evidence based practice committee"
The title identifies the article as a systematic review.
[Yes]

P2. Abstract
The abstract is structured with labeled sections for background, methods, results, and conclusions.
[Yes]  

P3. Introduction / Rationale
Quote: "Despite significant advances in neonatal and surgical care, the management of newborns with congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) remains a challenge. Significant variations in approach exist with regard to the use of antenatal steroids, ventilation modes, timing of repair, and pulmonary hypertension, the use of extra-corporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO), and the timing and type of surgical repair [1]."
The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of variations in CDH management.
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives
Quote: "The American Pediatric Surgical Association (APSA) Outcomes and Evidence Based Practice (OEBP) committee selected the following questions for this systematic review: 1. What is the optimal ventilator strategy for a newborn with CDH? 2. What is the best way to manage CDH-associated pulmonary hypertension (PHTN)? 3. Is there benefit to the use of pre- or postnatal corticosteroids? 4. Which mode of ECMO is best for CDH, and what is the optimal duration of treatment with ECMO? 5. What is the optimal technique to repair CDH (open versus minimally invasive) and which type of patch has the best outcome? 6. Is early repair or late repair of CDH better?"
The introduction provides explicit questions being addressed.
[Yes]

No mention of a protocol or registration number.

Quote: "Studies that did not address the neonatal population were excluded, as were opinion pieces, case reports, and editorial review articles (other than systematic reviews or meta analyses). Eligibility criteria regarding study design, population, and supplemental searches were described.

Quote: "Studies that did not address the neonatal population were excluded, as were opinion pieces, case reports, and editorial review articles (other than systematic reviews or meta analyses). A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?

[No]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
Quotes: "Two authors (RR and AN) independently extracted data from the retrieved articles."
Reasoning: Two authors independently extracted data, but no mention of duplicate study selection.
[No]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quotes: "All publications describing both absorbable (SIS) and nonabsorbable (PTFE) materials for CDH repair were sought from the Cochrane Trials Register and the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL) database. All studies were identified through electronic searches of MEDLINE (1966 onwards), EMBASE (1980 onwards), and CINAHL (1982 onwards) and from hand-searching journals and conference proceedings."
Reasoning: Multiple databases and other sources were searched.
[Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No mention of including grey literature or unpublished studies.
[No]

Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No list of included or excluded studies provided.
[No]

Quotes: "Institutional demographic and clinical severity data" (Table 1)
"Outcomes after CDH patch repair—institutional data" (Table 2)
Reasoning: Characteristics of included studies provided in tables.
[Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
Quotes: "Three authors (RR, AN, and JL) independently assessed all published articles and identified as potentially relevant by the literature search for inclusion in the review. Quality criteria used for study inclusion included (1) appropriate selection of comparison/control group; (2) control of factors such as selection bias, observation bias, and confounders; (3) completeness of follow-up; and (4) accurate outcome measurement."
Reasoning: Quality criteria were defined and applied to included studies.
[Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No discussion of study quality when formulating conclusions.

Quotes: "Meta-analysis was performed combining our data with the published literature examining the effect of patch type on recurrence and small bowel obstruction (SBO)."
Reasoning: Meta-analysis was performed to combine study findings.
[Yes]

Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: Publication bias not assessed.
[No]

Reasoning: Affiliations and contact information provided for corresponding author, but no explicit COI statement for review authors or included studies.
[No]

[Yes]

Quote: The abstract contains labeled Background, Methods, Results, and Conclusions sections.
Reasoning: The abstract is structured with distinct labeled sections.
[Yes]

llm_message:
A1 - A priori design
Quote: "We performed a systematic review and meta-analysis of the literature comparing use of a PFS with alternate treatment strategies."
Reasoning: The authors state they performed a systematic review and meta-analysis, implying an a priori design.
[Yes]

A2 - Duplicate study selection and data extraction 
Quote: "Data were extracted and entered into Review Manager (v5.1, The Cochrane Collaboration) and meta-analysis was performed using a random effects model due to anticipated study design and reporting."
Reasoning: Data extraction is mentioned but it is unclear if it was done in duplicate.
[No]

A3 - Comprehensive literature search
Quotes: "We searched Medline, Embase and the Cochrane controlled trials register from inception to July 2014 using the terms 'gastroschisis', 'gastroschisis and silo', 'preformed silo' and 'silastic silo'. Abstracts of the unfiltered literature were reviewed and full text versions of selected publications were assessed for inclusion. Reference lists of these publications were also checked to identify additional relevant reports."
Reasoning: At least 2 databases plus reference checking were searched.
[Yes]

A4 - Inclusion of grey literature
Quote: "Abstracts of the unfiltered literature were reviewed and full text versions of selected publications were assessed for inclusion."
Reasoning: Abstracts were reviewed, suggesting inclusion of grey literature.
[Yes]

A5 - List of included and excluded studies
Reasoning: No list of included or excluded studies is provided.
[No]

A6 - Characteristics of included studies
Quote: "Characteristics of included studies are shown in Table 1."
Reasoning: A table of characteristics of included studies is provided.
[Yes]

A7 - Assessment of scientific quality of included studies
Quote: "The quality of evidence comparing PFS with alternate treatment strategies for gastroschisis is poor."
Reasoning: The authors make a statement about study quality but the methods for assessing quality are not described.
[No]

A8 - Appropriate use of scientific quality in formulating conclusions
Quote: "The quality of evidence comparing PFS with alternate treatment strategies for gastroschisis is poor. Only routine use of PFS is associated with fewer days on a ventilator compared with other strategies. No strong evidence to support a preference for any strategy was demonstrated."
Reasoning: The authors appropriately consider the poor quality of evidence when formulating their conclusions.
[Yes]

A9 - Appropriate methods for combining studies
Quote: "Data were extracted and entered into Review Manager (v5.1, The Cochrane Collaboration) and meta-analysis was performed using a random effects model due to anticipated study design and reporting."
Reasoning: Use of a random effects model was appropriate given the anticipated heterogeneity between studies.
[Yes]

A10 - Assessment of publication bias
Reasoning: Publication bias was not assessed.
[No]

A11 - Conflict of interest stated
Reasoning: Sources of support for the systematic review and included studies are not clearly stated.
[No]

P1 - Title
Quote: "The role of preformed silos in the management of infants with gastroschisis: a systematic review and meta-analysis"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
[Yes] 

P2 - Structured abstract
Reasoning: The abstract has distinct labeled sections for background, methods, results, and conclusion.
[Yes]

P3 - Rationale
Quote: "The optimum surgical treatment of infants born with gastroschisis remains unclear. Following Watkins's description of primary closure of the abdominal wall in 1943 [1], the principle of surgical treatment has remained returning the eviscerated abdominal organs to the abdomen as soon as possible whilst avoiding the potential complications of viscero-abdominal disproportion (i.e. abdominal compartment syndrome and/or need for prolonged ventilation)."
Reasoning: The rationale for the review is provided in the context of what is already known.
[Yes]

P4 - Objectives
Quote: "The aim of this study was to evaluate current evidence comparing the use of a PFS with alternate treatment strategies in infants with gastroschisis."
Reasoning: The aim of the study is stated but without explicit reference to PICOS.
[No]

P5 - Protocol and registration
Reasoning: No mention of a protocol or registration number.
[No]

P6 - Eligibility criteria
Reasoning: Inclusion criteria are not explicitly stated, only that "abstracts of the unfiltered literature were reviewed and full text versions of selected publications were assessed for inclusion."
[No]

P7 - Information sources
Quote: "We searched Medline, Embase and the Cochrane controlled trials register from inception to July 2014"
Reasoning: The databases searched and dates of coverage are provided.
[Yes]

P8 - Search
Reasoning: The full search strategy is not presented.
[No]

P9 - Study selection
Quote: "Abstracts of the unfiltered literature were reviewed and full text versions of selected publications were assessed for inclusion."
Reasoning: The process for selecting studies is described.
[Yes]

P10 - Data collection process
Quote: "Data were extracted and entered into Review Manager (v5.1, The Cochrane Collaboration)"
Reasoning: Data extraction is mentioned but the specific process is not described in detail.
[No]

P11 - Data items
Reasoning: The variables for which data were sought are not defined.
[No]

P12 - Risk of bias in individual studies
Reasoning: The methods for assessing risk of bias are not described.
[No]

P13 - Summary measures
Reasoning: The principal summary measures are not explicitly stated.
[No]

P14 - Synthesis of results
Quote: "Data were extracted and entered into Review Manager (v5.1, The Cochrane Collaboration) and meta-analysis was performed using a random effects model due to anticipated study design and reporting."
Reasoning: The methods for combining results are described, including use of a random effects model.
[Yes]

P15 - Risk of bias across studies
Reasoning: Methods for assessing risk of bias across studies are not specified.
[No]

P16 - Additional analyses
Reasoning: No additional analyses are mentioned.
[NA]

P17 - Study selection
Quote: "One-thousand five-hundred and sixty-seven articles were identified using the specified search criteria and their abstracts reviewed. Following application against our inclusion criteria, 1440 were excluded on the basis of their abstract alone and the full text of 127 publications was scrutinised. One hundred and seven of these were subsequently excluded as they did not report a comparative group, did not use a PFS, or did not report outcomes from a group all treated with a PFS."
Reasoning: The numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included are provided with reasons for exclusions.
[Yes]

P18 - Study characteristics
Reasoning: Study characteristics are provided in Table 1 with citations.
[Yes]

P19 - Risk of bias within studies
Reasoning: Results of the risk of bias assessment are not presented.
[No]

P20 - Results of individual studies
Reasoning: Forest plots are provided showing the results for individual studies for some outcomes.
[Yes]

P21 - Synthesis of results
Reasoning: No meta-analysis results are presented as confidence intervals and measures of consistency are not provided.
[NA]

P22 - Risk of bias across studies
Reasoning: Results of risk of bias assessment across studies are not presented.
[NA]

P23 - Additional analysis
Reasoning: No additional analyses were mentioned.
[NA]

P24 - Summary of evidence
Quote: "The quality of evidence comparing PFS with alternate treatment strategies for gastroschisis is poor. Only routine use of PFS is associated with fewer days on a ventilator compared with other strategies. No strong evidence to support a preference for any strategy was demonstrated."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized including a statement about the strength of evidence.
[Yes]

P25 - Limitations
Quote: "The influence of bias is one of the difficulties encountered when combining data from multiple retrospective series. The key source of bias in this review is indication for treatment with a PFS or alternate strategy."
Reasoning: Some limitations of the review are discussed.
[Yes]

P26 - Conclusions
Quote: "Whilst this approach has the advantage of reducing the impact of selection bias from the group treated with a PFS, it should be noted that it also introduces selection bias in some cases to the comparator group as some of those infants were by definition not suitable for treatment with a PFS. The sole RCT [11] reports two groups without selection bias although it could be claimed that selection bias may exist at the level of trial recruitment as only a small proportion of eligible patients were recruited."
Reasoning: The conclusions provide an interpretation of the results in the context of the limitations and potential biases.
[Yes]

P27 - Funding
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review are not described.
[No]

llm_message:
A1
Quote: "This systematic review reveals that TERPT is a safe and less-invasive procedure with a low incidence of postoperative HAEC."
Reasoning: The research question and inclusion criteria are not explicitly stated to have been established a priori.
[No]

A2
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: There is no mention of duplicate study selection and data extraction.
[No]

A3
Quotes: "PubMed and Medline were searched for all studies that reported cases of patients who had undergone surgical correction of HD on transanal one-stage pull-through operation between 1998 and 2009. The search terms were "one-stage transanal pull-through", "transanal one-stage endorectal pull-through", "one-stage Soave pull-through", "single-stage transanal endorectal pull-through", "primary pull-through", or "Soave procedure"."
Reasoning: At least two databases were searched with the key terms provided, but no supplementary search strategies are mentioned.
[No]

A4
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The inclusion of grey literature is not mentioned.
[No]

A5
Quote: "Out of these 54 articles, 27 articles, identified as reporting entirely TERPT without additional laparotomy, laparoscopy or preoperative colostomy, formed the basis of our study (Table 1)."
Reasoning: A list of included studies is provided in Table 1, but a list of excluded studies is not provided.
[No]

A6
Quote: "There were a total of 899 patients. Information about patient's gender was reported in 760 (84.5%) patients. 563 (74.1%) patients were male and 197 (25.9%) patients were female. A male-to-female ratio of 2.8:1 was observed. Patient's age at the time of operation was reported in 811 (90.2%) patients (median 9.2 months, range 6 days to 14 years)."
Reasoning: Aggregated data on the characteristics of included studies is provided.
[Yes]

A7
Quote: "Despite many studies, the pathogenesis of HAEC is not fully understood. Various hypotheses regarding the etiology have been postulated. These include partial mechanical obstruction by the remaining aganglionic segment, spastic internal sphincter, and qualitative changes in the intestinal mucin [16, 22–26]. Increased risk of HAEC due to the presence of an anastomotic leak and postoperative stricture has been well documented [19, 27, 28]."
Reasoning: The scientific quality of included studies was not assessed.
[No]

A8
[NA]

A9
[NA]

A10
[NA]

A11
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: Conflicts of interest are not reported for the systematic review or the included studies.
[No]

P1
Quote: "Systematic review and meta-analysis of enterocolitis after one-stage transanal pull-through procedure for Hirschsprung's disease"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2
Quote: "Abstract Purpose The transanal one-stage pull-through procedure (TERPT) has gained worldwide popularity over open and laparoscopic-assisted one-stage techniques in children with Hirschsprung's disease (HD). It offers the advantages of avoiding laparotomy, laparoscopy, scars, abdominal contamination, and adhesions. However, enterocolitis associated with Hirschsprung's disease (HAEC) still remains to be a potentially life-threatening complication after pullthrough operation. The reported incidence of HAEC ranges from 4.6 to 54%. This meta-analysis was designed to evaluate postoperative incidence of HAEC following TERPT procedure."
Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary including background, purpose, methods, results and conclusions.
[Yes]

Quote: "The reported incidence of post pull-through HAEC ranges from 4.6 to 54% in various series, which may be partially due to the use of different diagnostic criteria [16–19]. Carneiro et al. report a lower incidence after Duhamel procedure, and Kleinhaus, Ikeda and Moore report a significantly higher incidence of HAEC after Swenson's procedure [1, 18, 34, 35]. However, the majority of recent reports found the incidence of HAEC to be unrelated to type and timing of definitive surgery [15, 19, 30, 34, 36]. In the present review, postoperative HAEC occurred in 92 patients, which lead to an incidence rate of HAEC of 10.2%. The incidence of recurrent HAEC varies from 5.2 to 56% in various reported series [15, 16, 34]. Frequency of bouts of HAEC is supposed to decrease with time [37]. In our present review the rate of recurrent episodes of HAEC was 2%. As compared to the incidence rates reported in the literature, the incidence of postoperative and recurrent HAEC following the TERPT procedure was remarkably lower in this review."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized, including the strength of evidence and relevance to key groups.
Response: [Yes]

Reasoning: Limitations at the study, outcome, and review level are not adequately discussed.

Response: [No]

Response: [No]

However, the majority of recent reports found the incidence of HAEC to be unrelated to type and timing of definitive surgery [15, 19, 30, 34, 36]. In the present review, postoperative HAEC occurred in 92 patients, which lead to an incidence rate of HAEC of 10.2%. The incidence of recurrent HAEC varies from 5.2 to 56% in various reported series [15, 16, 34]. Frequency of bouts of HAEC is supposed to decrease with time [37]. In our present review the rate of recurrent episodes of HAEC was 2%. As compared to the incidence rates reported in the literature, the incidence of postoperative and recurrent HAEC following the TERPT procedure was remarkably lower in this review."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized, including the strength of evidence and relevance to key groups.
Response: [Yes]

P25
Quote: "Prompt diagnosis, rectal washouts, and stoma formation are crucial factors in the prevention of severe morbidity associated with HAEC."
Reasoning: Limitations at the study, outcome, and review level are not adequately discussed.
Response: [No]

P26
Quote: "Considering the fact that the preoperative and postoperative management of HD has been similar over the last decade, it is reasonable to consider the TERPT procedure as a contributor to the observed low rate of postoperative HAEC."
Reasoning: A general interpretation is provided in the context of other evidence, but implications for future research are not clearly stated.
Response: [No]

P27
Quotes: N/A
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review are not described.
Response: [No]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
Quote: "The low incidence of most of the procedures (favoring case series with low level of evidence) and the lack of uniformity in evaluating some measures among surgeons, like pain assessment or cosmesis, for example, are the main contributors to this limitation."
Reasoning: Limitations at the study and review level are discussed.
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
Quote: "A wide experience in SIPES and its feasibility have already been described with good clinical outcomes and low rate of conversion. Appendectomy is the unique procedure in which SIPES has demonstrated to be safe and effective. The majority of SIPES procedures were performed in the "children" and "adolescents" groups. Cosmesis seems to be a self-evident benefit of SIPES, although there is no objective assessment of it among authors in the literature, and it must be carefully weighed against the possibility of affecting the safety of the procedure."
Reasoning: The conclusions provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27. Funding
Quote: "No competing financial interests exist."
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review are described, but not for the individual studies.
[No]
