llm_message:
A1
Quote: "The aim of this systematic review and meta-analysis was to compare clinical outcomes between single-incision laparoscopic appendicectomy and conventional laparoscopic appendicectomy in children."
Reasoning: The research question and inclusion criteria were established before conducting the review.
[Yes]

A2
Quotes: "Two authors independently extracted data from the list of the included studies, and a third reviewer was required for a final decision in the case of any discrepancies." "The primary objective of our analysis was to evaluate the operative time, length of hospital stay."
Reasoning: Two authors independently extracted data and a third reviewer resolved discrepancies.
[Yes]

A3
Quotes: "An electronic search of EMBASE, PubMed, MEDLINE was performed. Operative time, length of hospital stay, postoperative complications including wound infection, intra-abdominal infection, ileus in SILA and CLA were pooled and compared by meta-analysis." "References, reviews and meta-analyses were then scanned for additional articles."
Reasoning: At least 2 electronic databases were searched and references of retrieved articles were scanned.
[Yes]

A4
Reasoning: The authors did not mention whether they searched for reports regardless of publication type or excluded studies based on publication status.
[No]

A5
Quote: "Twelve studies (4 randomized controlled trials, 1 prospective study and 7 retrospective studies) that included 2,109 pediatric patients were studied. Of these patients, 933 and 1,176 patients had undergone SILA and CLA, respectively."
Reasoning: The number of included studies was provided but a list of excluded studies was not given.
[No]

A6
Quote: "Table 1 outlines basic demographic data for the included study, including study style, male:female sex ratio and BMI (kg/m2) or weight (kg) in each group. Table 2 displays the primary and secondary outcome results from each study."
Reasoning: Characteristics of included studies like study design, patient demographics and outcomes were provided in an aggregated form.
[Yes]

A7
Quote: "Twelve studies (4 randomized controlled trials, 1 prospective study and 7 retrospective studies) that included 2,109 pediatric patients were studied."
Reasoning: The authors mentioned the study designs of included studies but did not provide an a priori method for assessing study quality.
[No]

A8
Reasoning: Since study quality was not assessed, the results of methodological rigor could not be considered when formulating conclusions.
[No]

A9
Quotes: "A sensitivity analysis was conducted where four studies were excluded and the meta-analysis of the remaining 6 studies shown a significant increase in mean operative time in SILA (Fig. 2b)." "Statistical Heterogeneity was assessed using the Chi square test with significance set at P < 0.10. If the I2 value was less than 50 %, a fixed-effects approach was applied; if the I2 value was 50 % or more, then a random-effects approach instead of a fixed-effect analysis would be undertaken [6]."
Reasoning: Appropriate methods were used to combine findings, including assessment and handling of heterogeneity.
[Yes]

A10
Quote: "There was no evidence of statistical heterogeneity (I2 = 0 %)."
Reasoning: Publication bias was not assessed, likely because there were fewer than 10 studies, but this was not explicitly stated.
[No]

A11
Reasoning: Sources of funding or support for the systematic review and included studies were not reported.
[No]

P1
Quote: "Single-incision versus conventional laparoscopic appendicectomy in children: a systematic review and meta-analysis"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2
Quote: See the structured abstract on page 1 with labeled sections for background, methods, results, and conclusion.
Reasoning: A structured summary is provided with the required sections.
[Yes]

P3
Quote: "As surgical techniques have developed and the demand for procedures that cause less pain and have better cosmetic outcome, more and more surgeons draw their attention to minimally invasive techniques. The single-incision laparoscopic appendicectomy (SILA) was first reported in 1992 and quickly became a novel member of the minimally invasive surgery [1]."
Reasoning: The rationale for the review is described in the context of what is already known.
[Yes]

P4
Quote: "The aim of this systematic review and meta-analysis was to compare clinical outcomes between single-incision laparoscopic appendicectomy and conventional laparoscopic appendicectomy in children."
Reasoning: An explicit statement of the review question is provided, referring to the participants, interventions and outcomes.
[Yes]

P5
Reasoning: The article does not mention if a review protocol exists or where it can be accessed.
[No]

P6
Quote: "Children with histologically confirmed acute appendicitis who received SILA or CLA were recruited. Inclusion criteria: (1) clinical trials that compared single-incision versus conventional laparoscopic appendicectomy between 2000 and 2014; (2) children younger than 18 years with acute appendicitis; (3) original data included some of the following: operative time, length of hospital stay, postoperative recovery, and postoperative complications. Exclusion criteria: (1) no conventional laparoscopic appendicectomy as a control; (2) chronic appendicitis; and (3) duplicate publication or study did not provide sufficient original data."
Reasoning: Study characteristics used as eligibility criteria are specified.
[Yes]

P7
Quote: "An electronic search was performed using EMBASE, PubMed, MEDLINE from 2000 to 2014. The search terms single-incision, transumbilical, three-port, conventional laparoscopic surgery, children and appendectomy were used individually and in combination. References, reviews and meta-analyses were then scanned for additional articles."
Reasoning: Electronic databases searched and the search date range are described.
[Yes]

P8
Reasoning: The full electronic search strategy is not presented such that it could be repeated.
[No]

P9
Quote: "References, reviews and meta-analyses were then scanned for additional articles. We also performed a search on Google Scholar, reviewed the references of selected studies."
Reasoning: The process for selecting studies, including screening and eligibility, is described.
[Yes]

P10
Quote: "Two authors independently extracted data from the list of the included studies, and a third reviewer was required for a final decision in the case of any discrepancies."
Reasoning: The method of data extraction is described, involving two independent reviewers and a process for resolving discrepancies.
[Yes]

P11
Quote: "The primary objective of our analysis was to evaluate the operative time, length of hospital stay. Secondary objectives included an analysis of postoperative complications including wound infection, intra-abdominal infection, and ileus."
Reasoning: The primary and secondary outcomes for which data were sought are defined.
[Yes]

P12
Reasoning: The article does not describe methods used for assessing risk of bias in individual studies.
[No]

P13
Quote: "For dichotomous variables, we used odds ratios (ORs)."
Reasoning: Odds ratios are stated as the summary measure for dichotomous outcomes.
[Yes]

P14
Quote: "Statistical Heterogeneity was assessed using the Chi square test with significance set at P < 0.10. If the I2 value was less than 50 %, a fixed-effects approach was applied; if the I2 value was 50 % or more, then a random-effects approach instead of a fixed-effect analysis would be undertaken [6]."
Reasoning: The methods for assessing heterogeneity and deciding on a fixed-effect vs random-effects model are described.
[Yes]

P15
Reasoning: The article does not mention any methods for assessing risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence, such as publication bias or selective reporting.
[No]

P16
Quote: "A sensitivity analysis was conducted where four studies were excluded and the meta-analysis of the remaining 6 studies shown a significant increase in mean operative time in SILA (Fig. 2b)."
Reasoning: A sensitivity analysis excluding some studies was described.
[Yes]

P17
Quote: "Twelve studies (4 randomized controlled trials, 1 prospective study and 7 retrospective studies) that included 2,109 pediatric patients were studied. Of these patients, 933 and 1,176 patients had undergone SILA and CLA, respectively."
Reasoning: The number of studies screened, included and the reasons for exclusions are not fully reported. A flow diagram is not provided.
[No]

P18
Quote: "Table 1 outlines basic demographic data for the included study, including study style, male:female sex ratio and BMI (kg/m2) or weight (kg) in each group."
Reasoning: Characteristics of each included study are presented in a table.
[Yes]

P19
Reasoning: Results of the risk of bias assessment for each study are not presented, as risk of bias was not assessed.
[No]

P20
Quotes: "Table 2 displays the primary and secondary outcome results from each study." See Tables 1 and 2 and Figures 2-6 which present the results for each outcome from individual studies.
Reasoning: For each study and outcome, summary data for each group and effect estimates with confidence intervals are presented, some in forest plots.
[Yes]

P21
Quotes: See Figures 2-6 which present forest plots with meta-analysis results and confidence intervals for several outcomes.
Reasoning: The results of each meta-analysis performed are reported with confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
[Yes]

P22
Reasoning: The article does not present any assessment of risk of bias across studies.
[No]

P23
Quote: "A sensitivity analysis was conducted where four studies were excluded and the meta-analysis of the remaining 6 studies shown a significant increase in mean operative time in SILA (Fig. 2b)."
Reasoning: The results of the sensitivity analysis are reported.
[Yes]

P24
Quote: "Although our meta-analysis reveals no significant differences in mean operative time between two groups, a sensitivity analysis revealed a significant increase in mean operative time in SILA. Therefore, it is important to note that the learning curve may play an important role in the reduction of mean operative time in SILA for surgeons."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized, including the strength of evidence and relevance to key groups like surgeons.
[Yes]

P25
Quote: "Our systematic review and meta-analysis does have some limitations. On one hand, the overall methodologic quality and reporting of the included trials in children was poor. Some included studies had rather small sample size."
Reasoning: Limitations at the study and review level are discussed.
[Yes]

P26
Quote: "In conclusion, our study suggests that SILA is a feasible and safe surgical procedure alternative to CLA for pediatric patients with appendicitis. It reveals significantly shorter hospital stay and potential comparable operative time, postoperative complications such as wound infection, intra-abdominal infection, and ileus compared with CLA. However, most of the studies included in our meta-analysis were retrospective studies. Therefore, more prospective randomized controlled trials are needed in children to draw a more convincing conclusion."
Reasoning: A general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research are provided.
[Yes]

P27
Reasoning: Sources of funding or support for the systematic review are not described.
[No]

llm_message:
A1
"To compare the safety and efficacy of MIS with traditional open surgical approach for CDH, we performed an appropriate meta-analysis of the related studies."
The objective is clearly stated in the introduction.
[Yes]

A2
No mention of duplicate study selection and data extraction.

llm_message:
A1
Quote: "We performed a systematic review to examine the effectiveness of surgical interventions to treat obese children and adolescents, and whether they are cost-effective."
Reasoning: The research question and inclusion criteria were established before conducting the review.
[Yes]

A2
Quotes: "Searches were conducted in PubMed, Embase, ISI Web of Science and the Cochrane Library to 6 September 2010, and hand-searched bibliographies. We included articles with English abstracts if they examined subjects aged ≤19 years of age, reported at least one postoperative weight loss measure and at least 1 year of postoperative follow-up."
Reasoning: At least two databases were searched and bibliographies were hand-searched.
[Yes]

A3
Quotes: "Searches were conducted in PubMed, Embase, ISI Web of Science and the Cochrane Library to 6 September 2010, and hand-searched bibliographies. We included articles with English abstracts if they examined subjects aged ≤19 years of age, reported at least one postoperative weight loss measure and at least 1 year of postoperative follow-up."
Reasoning: Multiple databases were searched and bibliographies were hand-searched. Inclusion criteria are stated.
[Yes]

A4
Quote: "We included articles with English abstracts if they examined subjects aged ≤19 years of age, reported at least one postoperative weight loss measure and at least 1 year of postoperative follow-up."
Reasoning: Only articles with English abstracts were included, suggesting publication status was used as an inclusion criterion.
[Yes]

A5
Quote: "Refer to flow diagram in Appendix 2."
Reasoning: A flow diagram of included and excluded studies is provided in Appendix 2.
[Yes]

A6
Quotes: "Thirty-seven relevant papers on bariatric surgery effectiveness in 831 children or adolescents were included, spanning 36 years. Thirteen studies examined gastric banding, with mean body mass index (BMI) reductions ranging from 8.5 to 43 kg m−2."
"All but two papers (35,43) described baseline comorbid conditions, which included amenorrhea, depression, dyslipidaemia, hypertension, insulin resistance, metabolic syndrome, orthopaedic problems, osteoarthritis, sleep apnoea and type 2 diabetes."
Reasoning: Aggregate data on participant characteristics, interventions and outcomes are provided.
[Yes]

A7
Quotes: "We included articles with English abstracts if they examined subjects aged ≤19 years of age, reported at least one postoperative weight loss measure and at least 1 year of postoperative follow-up."
"Existing evidence – although based generally on underpowered, retrospective studies – suggests that bariatric surgery in older children results in significant weight loss and improvements in comorbidities and quality of life."
Reasoning: Inclusion criteria are stated and the quality of included studies is discussed narratively, but no formal quality assessment is reported.
[No]

A8
[NA] - No formal quality assessment was conducted, so this item is not applicable.

A9
[NA] - No meta-analysis was conducted, so assessing the appropriateness of methods for combining studies is not applicable.

A10
[NA] - No meta-analysis was conducted, so assessing publication bias is not applicable.

A11
Quote: "The project that led to this paper was funded by the WHO Health Evidence Network of the World Health Organization. The funder had no role in the design, analysis or interpretation of the study. The views expressed are those of the authors and do not necessarily reflect the position of the funding body."
Reasoning: Sources of support for the systematic review are acknowledged, but sources of support for the included studies are not reported.
[No]

P1
Quote: "Effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of paediatric bariatric surgery: a systematic review"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review.
[Yes]

P2
Quote: See the structured abstract on page 1 of the full text PDF.
Reasoning: A structured abstract with labeled sections is provided.
[Yes]

P3
Quote: "Despite reports of levelling off in some countries (1–3), childhood obesity and its associated morbidities and costs are considerable and increasing in scale in many countries (4,5), particularly among socioeconomically disadvantaged segments of many populations (6). Obese children and adolescents are more likely than their normal weight peers to suffer endocrine, cardiovascular, pulmonary, orthopaedic, psychosocial and other complications associated with excessive weight, many of which persist into adulthood (7–9)."
Reasoning: The rationale for the review is described in the context of the increasing prevalence and health consequences of childhood obesity.
[Yes]

P4
Quote: "We performed a systematic review to examine the effectiveness of surgical interventions to treat obese children and adolescents, and whether they are cost-effective."
Reasoning: The research questions are explicitly stated, referencing the population (obese children and adolescents), intervention (surgical interventions), and outcomes of interest (effectiveness and cost-effectiveness).
[Yes]

P5
[No] - No mention of a review protocol or registration number.

P6
Quotes: "We included articles with English abstracts if they examined subjects aged ≤19 years of age, reported at least one postoperative weight loss measure and at least 1 year of postoperative follow-up."
"At least one postoperative weight loss measure had to be reported, with a minimum follow-up time of 1 year post surgery."
Reasoning: Eligibility criteria for study characteristics (population, intervention, outcomes, follow-up duration) and report characteristics (English abstracts) are specified.
[Yes]

P7
Quote: "Searches were conducted in PubMed, Embase, ISI Web of Science and the Cochrane Library to 6 September 2010, and hand-searched bibliographies."
Reasoning: Information sources (databases with search end date and bibliography searching) are described.
[Yes]

P8
Quotes: "Appendix 1 contains details of the search terms."
"1a. PubMed search terms
#1. obes*[TIAB] OR overweight*[TIAB] OR weight loss[TIAB] OR weight reduc*[TIAB] OR BMI[TIAB] = 172 843
#2. child[TIAB] OR children[TIAB] OR adolescen*[TIAB] OR pediatr*[TIAB] OR paediatr*[TIAB] = 909 583
#3. bariatric[TIAB] OR gastric surgery[TIAB] OR gastroplasty[TIAB] OR gastrectomy[TIAB] OR gastric bypass[TIAB] OR jejunoileal bypass[TIAB] OR gastrointestinal diversion[TIAB] OR gastrointestinal surgery[TIAB] OR biliopancreatic diversion[TIAB] OR biliopancreatic bypass[TIAB] OR gastric band*[TIAB] OR gastrectomy[TIAB] OR LAGB[TIAB] OR stomach stapl*[TIAB] OR lap band*[TIAB] OR lapband*[TIAB] OR roux-en-y[TIAB] OR malabsorptive surgery[TIAB] OR restrictive surgery[TIAB] OR restrictive procedure[TIAB] OR duodenal switch[TIAB] OR antiobesity surgery[TIAB] OR weight loss surgery[TIAB] OR weight reduction surgery[TIAB] OR surgery[TIAB] OR surgical[TIAB] = 973 334
#4. #1 AND #2 AND #3 = 950"
Reasoning: The full electronic search strategy is provided for PubMed.
[Yes]

P9
Quote: "Refer to flow diagram in Appendix 2."
Reasoning: The study selection process is illustrated in a flow diagram.
[Yes]

P10
[No] - The method of data extraction is not described.

P11
[No] - Variables for which data were sought are not explicitly defined.

[No] - Methods for assessing risk of bias in individual studies are not described.

[NA] - No meta-analysis was conducted, so summary measures are not applicable.

[NA] - No meta-analysis was conducted.

[NA] - No meta-analysis was conducted, so assessing risk of bias across studies is not applicable.

P16
[NA] - No additional analyses were reported.

P17
Quote: "Refer to flow diagram in Appendix 2."
Reasoning: A flow diagram illustrating the number of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, included and excluded with reasons is provided.
[Yes]

P18
Quote: "Appendix 3, Table A1"
Reasoning: Study characteristics including country, study type, sample size, follow-up duration, baseline BMI, postop BMI, and whether comorbidities were measured are provided for each included study in Table A1.
[Yes]

P19
[No] - Risk of bias assessments for individual studies are not presented.

P20
[No] - Results for individual studies are not fully reported. Effect estimates and confidence intervals are lacking.

P21
[NA] - No meta-analysis was conducted.

P22
[NA] - No meta-analysis was conducted, so reporting results of risk of bias assessment across studies is not applicable.

P23
[NA] - No additional analyses were reported.

P24
Quote: "Thirty-seven relevant papers on bariatric surgery effectiveness in 831 children or adolescents were included, spanning 36 years. This review serves to update an early systematic review on the topic by Treadwell et al. in 2008 (33), including case studies with less than three patients (n = 11) and 14 articles published after the December 2007 cut-off used by Treadwell et al."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized, including the number of studies, total participants, and key results in relation to a previous review.
[Yes]

P25
Quotes: "Existing evidence – although based generally on underpowered, retrospective studies – suggests that bariatric surgery in older children results in significant weight loss and improvements in comorbidities and quality of life."
"Results were not broadly comparable given a lack of consistency across surgeons, procedures and reported outcomes."
"Accurate information for low frequency outcomes like mortality and complications was sparse."
"No studies on clinical effectiveness reported on costs, and only one study addressed bariatric surgery cost in children."
Reasoning: Limitations at the study level (underpowered retrospective studies), outcome level (lack of comparability) and review level (sparse data on rare outcomes, lack of cost data) are discussed.
[Yes]

P26
Quote: "Bariatric surgery is promoted as a treatment option for children and adolescents for several reasons as outlined above, but these also generate some controversy. Proponents in the surgical community suggest that the procedure is justified by weight loss results from clinical trials in adults, and should form part of a multidisciplinary paediatric weight management strategy to address life-threatening comorbidities seen in morbidly obese children. They add that delaying treatment and allowing comorbid conditions to progress could be equally or more disadvantageous, and that in practice, most adult bariatric centres already perform adolescent surgery (73). It is argued that, in principle, treatment risks are accepted when the benefits of treatment outweigh the risks of withholding treatment, and that the use of bariatric surgery in paediatric weight management should be seen as an extension of age-related, i.e. when the risks of chronic comorbidities should outweigh the risks of surgery for patients at any age."
Reasoning: The results are interpreted in the context of the rationale for bariatric surgery in youth and the risks and benefits at different ages. Implications for practice are discussed.
[Yes]

P27
Quote: "The project that led to this paper was funded by the WHO Health Evidence Network of the World Health Organization. The funder had no role in the design, analysis or interpretation of the study. The views expressed are those of the authors and do not necessarily reflect the position of the funding body."
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review are described and the role of the funder is made explicit.
[Yes]

P25
Quotes: "Existing evidence – although based generally on underpowered, retrospective studies – suggests that bariatric surgery in older children results in significant weight loss and improvements in comorbidities and quality of life."
"Results were not broadly comparable given a lack of consistency across surgeons, procedures and reported outcomes."
"Accurate information for low frequency outcomes like mortality and complications was sparse."
"No studies on clinical effectiveness reported on costs, and only one study addressed bariatric surgery cost in children."
Reasoning: Limitations at the study level (underpowered retrospective studies), outcome level (lack of comparability) and review level (sparse data on rare outcomes, lack of cost data) are discussed.
[Yes]

P26
Quote: "Bariatric surgery is promoted as a treatment option for children and adolescents for several reasons as outlined above, but these also generate some controversy. Proponents in the surgical community suggest that the procedure is justified by weight loss results from clinical trials in adults, and should form part of a multidisciplinary paediatric weight management strategy to address life-threatening comorbidities seen in morbidly obese children. They add that delaying treatment and allowing comorbid conditions to progress could be equally or more disadvantageous, and that in practice, most adult bariatric centres already perform adolescent surgery (73). It is argued that, in principle, treatment risks are accepted when the benefits of treatment outweigh the risks of withholding treatment, and that the use of bariatric surgery in paediatric weight management should be seen as an extension of age-related, i.e. when the risks of chronic comorbidities should outweigh the risks of surgery for patients at any age."
Reasoning: The results are interpreted in the context of the rationale for bariatric surgery in youth and the risks and benefits at different ages. Implications for practice are discussed.
[Yes]

P27
Quote: "The project that led to this paper was funded by the WHO Health Evidence Network of the World Health Organization. The funder had no role in the design, analysis or interpretation of the study. The views expressed are those of the authors and do not necessarily reflect the position of the funding body."
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review are described and the role of the funder is made explicit.
[Yes]

P25 - Limitations:
Quote: "There are limitations to this study. First, all of the data obtained from our institution were collected retrospectively, and thus not specifically collected for research purposes. As for all data reviewed, some of the variables may have been missing or misclassified. Also, differences in trauma management between physicians and institutions may not allow for generalizations to be made. Selection bias may have also affected results, as all EDT were performed at the discretion of the trauma physician."
Reasoning: Discusses several limitations of the study, including retrospective data collection, missing data, differences in management between centers, and selection bias.
[Yes]

P26 - Conclusions:
Quote: "There is growing interest in the use of a resuscitative endovascular balloon occlusion of the aorta (REBOA) to control hemorrhagic shock in trauma patients. To our knowledge, the REBOA remains a new and still controversial tool. There are limited reports regarding its use in trauma patients. Recently, Brenner et al. tested the technical feasibility of REBOA in adult patients in hemorrhagic shock [25]. Although they concluded it is feasible to use, their technique is during the initial phase of aneurysm. Some believe its main use in trauma could be for placement by emergency medical personnel to temporize a patient prior to transfer to definitive care."
Reasoning: The conclusions discuss the growing interest in and limitations of REBOA as an alternative resuscitative measure to EDT in trauma patients.
[Yes]

P27 - Funding:
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: Sources of funding and support are not reported.
[No]

llm_message:
A1
Quotes: "The review was conducted according to a pre-specified protocol. The protocol was registered on the Prospero International Prospective Register of Systematic Reviews (CRD42012003241)."
Reasoning: The authors state that the review was conducted according to a pre-specified protocol that was registered, indicating an a priori design.
[Yes]

A2
Quotes: "Identified titles were assessed for inclusion by two investigators (BA and WT) acting independently. Any conflicts were resolved by a third investigator (MK). Data from included articles were extracted independently by the same two investigators (BA and WT), and any differences resolved by discussion."
Reasoning: Study selection and data extraction were done independently by two investigators with a process for resolving disagreements.
[Yes]

A3
Quotes: "All study designs except expert opinion were included, and no restrictions were made on the basis of study language or geographical location."
Reasoning: The authors searched multiple databases and did not restrict by language or location, but do not provide full details on the search strategy or supplementary sources.
[No]

A4
Quotes: "All study designs except expert opinion were included, and no restrictions were made on the basis of study language or geographical location."
Reasoning: The authors explicitly state that all study designs except expert opinion were included regardless of publication status.
[Yes]

A5
Quotes: "Using the stated search strategy, 3081 papers were identified. After removal of duplicates, 751 unique articles remained. From this, 8 papers were deemed to meet the inclusion criteria, all of which were cohort studies (Fig. 1). No randomised controlled trials were identified that met the inclusion criteria."
Reasoning: The authors provide the numbers of included and excluded studies with reasons for exclusions at each stage in a flow diagram.
[Yes]

A6
Quotes: "Although reporting of baseline characteristics was variably done by the included studies, where it was reported, there were no statistically significant differences in birth-weight, gestational age, or associated anomalies between the OPFC and SR groups."
Reasoning: Some baseline characteristics of included studies are provided, but in an incomplete and aggregated way.
[No]

A7
Quotes: "Methodological quality and risk of bias were assessed using the STROBE checklist and GRADE criteria."
Reasoning: The authors state the tools used to assess study quality and risk of bias.
[Yes]

A8
Quotes: "Our results would appear to suggest a potential benefit to OPFC over SR. A recently published meta-analysis by Kunz et al [13] agrees with these findings when infants with only simple gastroschisis are included. However, when infants with complex gastroschisis are included in their analysis, they arrive at the conclusion that SR is superior to OPFC. This variation in conclusion highlights one of the key limitations of performing meta-analysis in small specialties. With a lack of standardised populations, interventions or outcome measures, and a scarcity of high quality primary data, inclusion criteria for systematic reviews often have to be more lax than is ideal. This leads to the introduction of significant clinical heterogeneity between the included studies, which may lead to a lack of validity for the conclusions of any meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The authors discuss the quality of included studies when interpreting the results and formulating the conclusions of the review.
[Yes]

A9
Quotes: "Data were synthesized using standard methods as described in the Cochrane Reviewers Handbook [8]. The chi-squared test for heterogeneity was used to assess the extent to which the results of the studies were in agreement. Using a conservative cut-off of p<0.01, no statistical heterogeneity was detected and therefore fixed-effect methods were used throughout. Dichotomous outcomes were meta-analysed using Mantel–Haenszel fixed effects methods to produce summary odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals. Continuous variables were meta-analysed using the inverse-variance fixed-effect method to produce weighted mean differences and 95% confidence intervals."
Reasoning: Appropriate methods were used to assess heterogeneity and synthesize the results.
[Yes]

A10
Quotes: "Although we have attempted to address this potential lack of validity with strict inclusion and exclusion criteria, our conclusion that OPFC is superior to SR must still be tempered by the low quality of the available primary data, and the limitations of our study."
Reasoning: The authors acknowledge the potential impact of publication bias on their conclusions, but do not formally assess it.
[No]

A11
Quotes: "Marian Knight is funded by a National Institute for Health Research Professorship. This article presents independent research partly funded by the National Institute for Health Research (NIHR)."
Reasoning: Sources of support for the systematic review are reported, but sources of support for the included studies are not.
[No]

P1
Quote: "Challenges of Improving the Evidence Base in Smaller Surgical Specialties, as Highlighted by a Systematic Review of Gastroschisis Management"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review.
[Yes]

P2
Quote: See structured abstract with labeled sections including background, methods, results, and conclusions.
Reasoning: The article provides a structured abstract with the specified sections.
[Yes]

P3
Quote: "Gastroschisis is an increasingly common paediatric surgical condition [1], with an incidence in the United Kingdom of approximately 3.5/10000 births [2]. Multiple surgical repair strategies have been developed, which vary based upon whether general anesthesia is used to perform the repair, and whether closure is operative or non-operative [3–6]."
Reasoning: The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known about gastroschisis management strategies.
[Yes]

P4
Quote: "The aim of this study, therefore, was to perform a systematic review of the literature comparing outcomes of infants with simple gastroschisis following either OPFC or SR. From this study we aimed to identify some of the reasons why research in paediatric surgery is currently largely unable to provide a strong evidence base to inform clinical practice."
Reasoning: The introduction states the aim of the systematic review, referencing the population (infants with simple gastroschisis), interventions (OPFC and SR), and outcomes of interest.
[Yes]

P5
Quote: "The review was conducted according to a pre-specified protocol. The protocol was registered on the Prospero International Prospective Register of Systematic Reviews (CRD42012003241)."
Reasoning: The methods state that a review protocol exists and provide its registration number.
[Yes]

P6
Quote: "Studies were included if they involved infants born with simple gastroschisis, defined as gastroschisis with an intact continuous bowel that is not compromised or breached at delivery or presentation. Infants with complex gastroschisis, defined as the presence of at least one of intestinal perforation, necrosis, or atresia were excluded from this review, as they only account for approximately 11.5% of infants with gastroschisis, are known to have a worse prognosis than the majority with simple gastroschisis [2], and thus represent a major confounder in any examination of the outcomes of different management techniques."
Reasoning: The methods specify the study characteristics (participants, interventions) used as eligibility criteria and rationale.
[Yes]

P7
Quote: "All study designs except expert opinion were included, and no restrictions were made on the basis of study language or geographical location."
Reasoning: The information sources are not fully described, lacking specific databases, dates, and the date last searched.
[No]

P8
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The full search strategy is not presented for any database.
[No]

P9
Quote: "Identified titles were assessed for inclusion by two investigators (BA and WT) acting independently. Any conflicts were resolved by a third investigator (MK)."
Reasoning: The process for selecting studies is described.
[Yes]

P10
Quote: "Data from included articles were extracted independently by the same two investigators (BA and WT), and any differences resolved by discussion. Where required, unpublished data were requested from the authors of each of the included studies to allow for meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The method of data extraction is described, including obtaining unpublished data from investigators.
[Yes]

P11
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The data items sought are not explicitly defined.
[No]

P12
Quote: "Methodological quality and risk of bias were assessed using the STROBE checklist and GRADE criteria."
Reasoning: The methods for assessing risk of bias of individual studies are described.
[Yes]

P13
Quotes: "Dichotomous outcomes were meta-analysed using Mantel–Haenszel fixed effects methods to produce summary odds ratios with 95% confidence intervals. Continuous variables were meta-analysed using the inverse-variance fixed-effect method to produce weighted mean differences and 95% confidence intervals."
Reasoning: The principal summary measures (odds ratios, mean differences) are stated.
[Yes]

P14
Quote: "Data were synthesized using standard methods as described in the Cochrane Reviewers Handbook [8]. The chi-squared test for heterogeneity was used to assess the extent to which the results of the studies were in agreement. Using a conservative cut-off of p<0.01, no statistical heterogeneity was detected and therefore fixed-effect methods were used throughout."
Reasoning: The methods for synthesizing results and assessing consistency are described.
[Yes]

P15
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: Methods for assessing risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence are not specified.
[No]

P16
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: No additional analyses are mentioned.
[NA]

P17
Quote: See Figure 1 study flow diagram.
Reasoning: A study flow diagram is provided with numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, included, and excluded with reasons.
[Yes]

P18
Quote: "The included studies comprised a total of 804 infants with simple gastroschisis, 488 of whom underwent OPFC and 316 of whom underwent SR. The largest study was Owen 2010 [2] with 290 eligible patients. The majority of the remaining studies included fewer than 50 participants (Table 2)."
Reasoning: Some study characteristics are presented for each included study, but incompletely.
[No]

P19
Quote: "Methodological quality and risk of bias were assessed using the STROBE checklist and GRADE criteria."
Reasoning: Risk of bias assessments are mentioned but the results are not presented for each study.
[No]

P20
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: Simple summary data and effect estimates for each study are not provided for any outcomes.
[No]

P21
Quotes: See Figure 2 forest plots and Table 3 summary outcome measures.
Reasoning: Meta-analysis results including odds ratios, mean differences, and confidence intervals are presented for each outcome.
[Yes]

P22
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: No assessments of risk of bias across studies are reported.
[NA]

P23
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: No additional analyses are reported.
[NA]

P24
Quote: "Our results would appear to suggest a potential benefit to OPFC over SR. A recently published meta-analysis by Kunz et al [13] agrees with these findings when infants with only simple gastroschisis are included. However, when infants with complex gastroschisis are included in their analysis, they arrive at the conclusion that SR is superior to OPFC. This variation in conclusion highlights one of the key limitations of performing meta-analysis in small specialties. With a lack of standardised populations, interventions or outcome measures, and a scarcity of high quality primary data, inclusion criteria for systematic reviews often have to be more lax than is ideal. This leads to the introduction of significant clinical heterogeneity between the included studies, which may lead to a lack of validity for the conclusions of any meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized along with their strength and relevance to key groups.
[Yes]

P25
Quote: "Although we have attempted to address this potential lack of validity with strict inclusion and exclusion criteria, our conclusion that OPFC is superior to SR must still be tempered by the low quality of the available primary data, and the limitations of our study."
Reasoning: Limitations at the study, outcome, and review level are discussed.
[Yes]

P26
Quote: "A National Paediatric Surgical Trials Unit could act both as a centre to facilitate co-operation between individual surgical centres, and as a research unit in its own right. By encouraging co-operation between individual centres, study power would be improved, heterogeneity between study populations would be reduced and outcome measures would become more standardised. With buy-in and co-operation from each of the individual surgical centres, a National Paediatric Surgical Trials Unit would have the ability to develop an overarching research programme that would allow generation of sufficient quality data to not only evaluate existing practice, but to take new surgical ideas through from initial evaluation to assessment with national randomised controlled trials, and on to large scale review of established practice, as outlined by the IDEAL recommendations [15]. A similar national approach could be used in other smaller surgical specialties."
Reasoning: The authors provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27
Quote: "Marian Knight is funded by a National Institute for Health Research Professorship. This article presents independent research partly funded by the National Institute for Health Research (NIHR)."
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review are described.
[Yes]

Continuous variables were meta-analysed using the inverse-variance fixed-effect method to produce weighted mean differences and 95% confidence intervals."
Reasoning: The principal summary measures (odds ratios, mean differences) are stated.
[Yes]

P14
Quote: "Data were synthesized using standard methods as described in the Cochrane Reviewers Handbook [8]. The chi-squared test for heterogeneity was used to assess the extent to which the results of the studies were in agreement. Using a conservative cut-off of p<0.01, no statistical heterogeneity was detected and therefore fixed-effect methods were used throughout."
Reasoning: The methods for synthesizing results and assessing consistency are described.
[Yes]

P15
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: Methods for assessing risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence are not specified.
[No]

P16
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: No additional analyses are mentioned.
[NA]

P17
Quote: See Figure 1 study flow diagram.
Reasoning: A study flow diagram is provided with numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, included, and excluded with reasons.
[Yes]

P18
Quote: "The included studies comprised a total of 804 infants with simple gastroschisis, 488 of whom underwent OPFC and 316 of whom underwent SR. The largest study was Owen 2010 [2] with 290 eligible patients. The majority of the remaining studies included fewer than 50 participants (Table 2)."
Reasoning: Some study characteristics are presented for each included study, but incompletely.
[No]

P19
Quote: "Methodological quality and risk of bias were assessed using the STROBE checklist and GRADE criteria."
Reasoning: Risk of bias assessments are mentioned but the results are not presented for each study.
[No]

P20
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: Simple summary data and effect estimates for each study are not provided for any outcomes.
[No]

P21
Quotes: See Figure 2 forest plots and Table 3 summary outcome measures.
Reasoning: Meta-analysis results including odds ratios, mean differences, and confidence intervals are presented for each outcome.
[Yes]

P22
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: No assessments of risk of bias across studies are reported.
[NA]

P23
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: No additional analyses are reported.
[NA]

P24
Quote: "Our results would appear to suggest a potential benefit to OPFC over SR. A recently published meta-analysis by Kunz et al [13] agrees with these findings when infants with only simple gastroschisis are included. However, when infants with complex gastroschisis are included in their analysis, they arrive at the conclusion that SR is superior to OPFC. This variation in conclusion highlights one of the key limitations of performing meta-analysis in small specialties. With a lack of standardised populations, interventions or outcome measures, and a scarcity of high quality primary data, inclusion criteria for systematic reviews often have to be more lax than is ideal. This leads to the introduction of significant clinical heterogeneity between the included studies, which may lead to a lack of validity for the conclusions of any meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized along with their strength and relevance to key groups.
[Yes]

P25
Quote: "Although we have attempted to address this potential lack of validity with strict inclusion and exclusion criteria, our conclusion that OPFC is superior to SR must still be tempered by the low quality of the available primary data, and the limitations of our study."
Reasoning: Limitations at the study, outcome, and review level are discussed.
[Yes]

P26
Quote: "A National Paediatric Surgical Trials Unit could act both as a centre to facilitate co-operation between individual surgical centres, and as a research unit in its own right. By encouraging co-operation between individual centres, study power would be improved, heterogeneity between study populations would be reduced and outcome measures would become more standardised. With buy-in and co-operation from each of the individual surgical centres, a National Paediatric Surgical Trials Unit would have the ability to develop an overarching research programme that would allow generation of sufficient quality data to not only evaluate existing practice, but to take new surgical ideas through from initial evaluation to assessment with national randomised controlled trials, and on to large scale review of established practice, as outlined by the IDEAL recommendations [15]. A similar national approach could be used in other smaller surgical specialties."
Reasoning: The authors provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27
Quote: "Marian Knight is funded by a National Institute for Health Research Professorship. This article presents independent research partly funded by the National Institute for Health Research (NIHR)."
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review are described.
[Yes]

llm_message:
A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The text does not mention a protocol, ethics approval, or pre-determined research objectives.
[No]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction? 
Quotes: "Data extraction: Retrieved articles were assessed for eligibility and data on patients, intervention, control, outcomes and methodological quality were abstracted independently by two authors. Discrepancies were resolved by discussion and consensus."
Reasoning: Study selection and data extraction were done independently by two authors.
[Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quotes: "The search strategy is summarized in Fig. 1. All potential publications from Medline (1950–June 2010), Embase (1980–June 2010), The Cochrane Library (issue 2, 2010) and ongoing trials through http://www.clinicaltrials.gov website were identified."
Reasoning: At least 2 electronic databases plus a supplementary source were searched.
[Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The text does not state that they searched for reports regardless of publication type or whether they excluded studies based on publication status.
[No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
Quotes: None relevant 
Reasoning: The text does not provide or reference a list of included and excluded studies.
[No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quotes: "Table 1 Comparative studies reporting laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair in infants and children"
Reasoning: Key characteristics of the included studies were provided in an aggregated table.
[Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
Quotes: "The quality of the included comparative studies was assessed independently by two authors. The Cochrane Collaboration criteria for randomized controlled trials was utilized (randomization, allocation concealment, blinding and completeness of follow-up). Cohort studies were assessed using the Newcastle-Ottawa Quality Assessment Scale [18]. The methodological details of the included studies were extracted from the published data."
Reasoning: The methodological quality of included studies was assessed using the Cochrane criteria for RCTs and the Newcastle-Ottawa scale for cohort studies.
[Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
Quotes: "Although our review utilized a very comprehensive search strategy to minimize the effect of publication bias, only two randomized clinical trial was included. Therefore, our review is a summary of the existing evidence with limitation to the conclusions drawn from these data due to the quality of the included studies."
Reasoning: The conclusions acknowledge the limitations due to the quality of the included studies.
[Yes]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
Quotes: "Heterogeneity was defined as a significant test of heterogeneity (p < 0.1) and/or differences in the treatment effects across studies."
Reasoning: Heterogeneity was assessed to determine appropriateness of combining studies, though a meta-analysis was not performed.
[NA]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: Publication bias was not assessed, likely because there were fewer than 10 included studies.
[NA] 

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: Sources of support for the systematic review and included studies were not acknowledged.
[No]

P1. Title
Quotes: "Laparoscopic versus open inguinal herniotomy in infants and children: a meta-analysis"
Reasoning: The title identifies the report as a meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary
Quotes: The abstract contains labeled sections for Purpose, Methods, Results, and Conclusions.
Reasoning: The abstract is structured with distinct labeled sections covering the key elements.
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale
Quotes: "Inguinal hernia repair is one of the most frequently performed pediatric surgical operations [1]. Open repair of an inguinal hernia has been accepted as the method of choice since it was first described more than 50 years ago due to its lower morbidity, good cosmesis, and lower rates of recurrence [2–4]."
Reasoning: The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is known about inguinal hernia repair in children.
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives
Quotes: "Purpose To undertake a meta-analysis of comparative data of laparoscopic versus open inguinal herniotomy in infants and children."
Reasoning: The purpose statement specifies the review question in terms of the population, interventions and comparator.
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The text does not mention a review protocol or registration.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria
Quotes: "Inclusion criteria: All comparative studies of the laparoscopic and open approaches for indirect inguinal hernia in children aged less than 19 years were selected. The primary outcome measure was the recurrence rate. Other clinically important outcomes such as rate of contralateral PPV, operative time, postoperative pain and recovery, cosmesis, postoperative testicular atrophy, postoperative hydrocele and stitch granuloma/abscess were also sought."
Reasoning: The eligibility criteria for included studies are specified.
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources
Quotes: "The search strategy is summarized in Fig. 1. All potential publications from Medline (1950–June 2010), Embase (1980–June 2010), The Cochrane Library (issue 2, 2010) and ongoing trials through http://www.clinicaltrials.gov website were identified."
Reasoning: The information sources searched are described.
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search
Quotes: "The following subject headings (MeSH) and text word terms were utilized: inguinal hernia, laparoscopy, minimal access surgery, infant(s), neonate(s), newborn(s), child, paediatric, pediatric. No language restriction was applied. Additional citations were sought using references in articles retrieved from searches."
Reasoning: The full search strategy is not presented, but the key search terms are provided.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The process for selecting studies is not explicitly described.
[No]

P10. Methods / Data collection process
Quotes: "Data extraction: Retrieved articles were assessed for eligibility and data on patients, intervention, control, outcomes and methodological quality were abstracted independently by two authors. Discrepancies were resolved by discussion and consensus."
Reasoning: The method of data extraction is described, involving two independent authors and a process for resolving discrepancies.
[Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: The text does not explicitly define all variables for which data were sought.
[No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies
Quotes: "The quality of the included comparative studies was assessed independently by two authors. The Cochrane Collaboration criteria for randomized controlled trials was utilized (randomization, allocation concealment, blinding and completeness of follow-up). Cohort studies were assessed using the Newcastle-Ottawa Quality Assessment Scale [18]."
Reasoning: The methods used to assess risk of bias in individual studies are described.
[Yes]

P13. Methods / Summary measures
Quotes: "For dichotomous outcomes, odds ratio (OR) and its associated confidence interval were calculated. For continuous outcomes, treatment effect was expressed as mean difference and its calculated standard deviation."
Reasoning: The principal summary measures are stated.
[Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: Methods for data synthesis are not described, as a meta-analysis was not performed.
[NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: Methods for assessing risk of bias across studies are not described, as a meta-analysis was not performed.
[NA]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses
Quotes: "A sensitivity analysis was conducted where studies limited to girls, and/or with a median follow-up less than 6 months, and/or addressing a complicated hernia, and/or limited to infants were excluded and the meta-analysis of the remaining 6 comparative studies had shown a comparable recurrence rate among the groups [OR = 0.87; 95% CI 0.34–2.23; p = 0.76] (Fig. 2b)."
Reasoning: A sensitivity analysis was conducted.
[Yes]

P17. Results / Study selection
Quotes: "Initial electronic search yielded 290 Medline, 216 Embase, 5 Cochrane Library (issue 2, 2010) and 7 ClinicalTrials.gov potentially relevant citations. After screening the abstracts, 48 articles were reviewed in full texts. Thirty-four articles have met the predefined inclusion criteria (Fig. 1). Ten published studies were identified (Niyogi [19]; Tsai [20]; Koivusalo [21]; Endo [22]; Bharathi [23]; Hassan [24]; Koivusalo [25]; Chan [17]; Oue [26]; Antao [27]) in which the laparoscopic and open approaches for repair of pediatric inguinal hernias were directly compared (Table 1) [17, 19–27]."
Reasoning: A flow diagram of the study selection process is not provided, but the numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included are reported in the text.
[No]

P18. Results / Study characteristics
Quotes: "Table 1 Comparative studies reporting laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair in infants and children"
Reasoning: The characteristics of each included study are presented in Table 1.
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies
Quotes: "Two randomized controlled trial (Koivusalo [21] and Chan [17]), one nonrandomized clinical trial (Tsai [20]) and seven observational comparative studies (Niyogi [19]; Endo [22]; Bharathi [23, 28]; Hassan [24]; Koivusalo [25]; Oue [26]; Antao [27]) were assessed."
Reasoning: The results of the risk of bias assessments for individual studies are summarized.
[Yes]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies
Quotes: "Table 1 Comparative studies reporting laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair in infants and children"
Reasoning: Table 1 presents the key results for each individual study, but does not include effect estimates and confidence intervals.
[No]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: A meta-analysis was not performed so there are no synthesis results to present.
[NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: An assessment of risk of bias across studies is not reported, as a meta-analysis was not performed.
[NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis
Quotes: "A sensitivity analysis was conducted where studies limited to girls, and/or with a median follow-up less than 6 months, and/or addressing a complicated hernia, and/or limited to infants were excluded and the meta-analysis of the remaining 6 comparative studies had shown a comparable recurrence rate among the groups [OR = 0.87; 95% CI 0.34–2.23; p = 0.76] (Fig. 2b)."
Reasoning: The results of the sensitivity analysis are reported.
[Yes]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence
Quotes: "Our review examined the safety and efficacy of the laparoscopic approach in the management of inguinal hernias in infants and children. Ten comparative studies were reviewed. Although the data is limited, the laparoscopic approach was associated with a trend towards higher recurrence rate."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized in the discussion.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
Quotes: "Although our review utilized a very comprehensive search strategy to minimize the effect of publication bias, only two randomized clinical trial was included. Therefore, our review is a summary of the existing evidence with limitation to the conclusions drawn from these data due to the quality of the included studies."
Reasoning: Limitations at the review level are discussed.
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
Quotes: "Despite numerous case series spanning over a decade of surgical practice, only two randomized controlled trials were identified, studying 172 infants and children. The conflicting data revealed by the two randomized controlled trials could be explained partially by the possibility of selection bias and by the presence of potential confounding factors including different operative techniques and lack of standardization of other received treatments [17, 21]."
Reasoning: The conclusions provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of the evidence.
[Yes]

P27. Funding
Quotes: None relevant
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review are not described.
[No]

P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
Quotes: "Laparoscopic treatment of intussusception in children: A systematic review"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review.
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary
Quotes: The abstract contains labeled Background, Methods, Results, and Conclusion sections.
Reasoning: The abstract is structured with the key recommended sections.
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale
Quotes: "The use of laparoscopy in pediatric surgery has increased significantly in the past 20 years [4–6]. In children, recent meta-analyses comparing open to laparoscopic technique for interventions as diverse as appendectomy [7], splenectomy [8], pyloromyotomy [9] and pyeloplasty [10] have unanimously found a significantly reduced length of hospital stay, a better cosmetic result and a comparable or indeed reduced [9] complication rate using laparoscopy."
Reasoning: Provides rationale by discussing the increasing use and potential benefits of laparoscopy in pediatric surgery.
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives
Quotes: "We thus aimed to provide the data needed to challenge current clinical practice in favor of a method that allows for earlier discharge, reduced postoperative pain and decreased risk for postoperative SBO. To this end, we have performed a systematic review to assess the overall safety, success rate, complication rate and potential advantages in the laparoscopic treatment of pediatric intussusception."
Reasoning: Clearly states the objectives and key outcomes of interest for the review.
[Yes]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence
Quotes: "A large number of pediatric and general surgeons consider laparotomy to be the unequivocal gold standard in the surgical treatment of intussusception. Likewise, pediatric laparoscopy has been consistently associated with a significantly reduced length of stay compared to open surgery, regardless of primary pathology [7–10]. Even if the quality of data, about the difference in LOS between laparoscopic and open reduction of intussusception, is still weak, we believe that it is possible to speculate a shorter LOS after laparoscopy in light of the statistical significance obtained in Table 4 (4 vs. 7 days, p < 0.0001) and the previous pediatric laparoscopic literature [7–10]."
Reasoning: Summarizes key findings and their relevance to pediatric surgeons.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
Quotes: "Limitations of the present study includes the lack of prospective randomized controlled trials (RCT) comparing laparoscopic and open reduction of intussusception. In their absence or in the presence of technical difficulties, the threshold to convert to laparotomy should remain low with the aim to be safe and avoid complications."
Reasoning: Discusses limitations at the study level (lack of RCTs) and review level (technical difficulties leading to conversion).
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
Quotes: "In contrast, this systematic review showed laparoscopy to be safe and efficacious in the treatment of pediatric intussusception even responding to radiologic reduction. A laparoscopic success rate of more than 70% and a low rate of intraoperative (0.4%) and postoperative complications (2.9%) advocate for the use of laparoscopy as the primary surgical technique."
Reasoning: Provides an overall interpretation of the results in the context of laparoscopy as a treatment for pediatric intussusception.
[Yes]

P27. Funding
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review are not reported.
[No]

P1. Title
Quotes: "Management of Recurrent Tracheoesophageal Fistulas: A Systematic Review"
Reasoning: Identifies the article as a systematic review in the title.
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary
Quotes: Entire abstract.
Reasoning: Provides a structured abstract with labeled sections covering background, materials and methods, results, and conclusion.
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale
Quotes: "The spectrum of esophageal atresia (EA) and tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) include an isolated EA, EA with a proximal and/or distal TEF and the "H" or "N" type fistula. Since the initial description of the open surgical repair1 and subsequent thoracoscopic approaches2,3 the outcomes have been very encouraging. Anastomotic leaks, esophageal strictures, gastroesophageal reflux, and tracheomalacia are complications pediatric surgeons are familiar with. The incidence of a fistula recurrence range from 1.9 to 11% after open and thoracoscopic repairs.2,4–8 The diagnosis of these recurrent tracheoesophageal fistulas (RTEF) can often be elusive to the unsuspecting physician and the ideal approach to their management is still in debate."
Reasoning: Describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known about recurrent tracheoesophageal fistulas.
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives
Quotes: "We aim to comparatively review all published treatment options, and outcomes, for managing RTEF."
Reasoning: Provides an explicit statement of the review objective.
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No mention of a review protocol or registration.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria
Quotes: "All English language articles published by August 2013, describing the management of RTEF in children were reviewed."
Reasoning: Specifies eligibility criteria of language, publication date, population and condition.
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources
Quotes: "A Medline, Embase, and web of science searches were performed using the keywords recurrent tracheoesophageal fistula. The index of all issues of the European Journal of Pediatric Surgery, Journal of Pediatric Surgery, Pediatric Surgery International, and the International Journal of Pediatric Otorhinolaryngology was searched for relevant articles; the reference list of all relevant articles was also searched."
Reasoning: Describes the databases searched and the journals hand-searched.
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search
Quotes: "A Medline, Embase, and web of science searches were performed using the keywords recurrent tracheoesophageal fistula."
Reasoning: Provides the search terms used but not the full search strategy.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection
Quotes: "All English language articles describing the management of RTEF in children were reviewed."
Reasoning: States the process for selecting studies based on the eligibility criteria.
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No description of the data extraction process.
[No]

P11. Methods / Data items
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: Variables for which data were sought are not defined.
[No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No assessment of risk of bias in individual studies.
[No]

P13. Methods / Summary measures
[NA] - No meta-analysis was performed.

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results
[NA] - No meta-analysis was performed.

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies
[NA] - No meta-analysis was performed.

P16. Methods / Additional analyses
[NA] - No meta-analysis was performed.

P17. Results / Study selection
Quotes: "A total of 44 papers between 1955 and 2013 described 165 patients; 57 ET and 108 OS. Of the 57 ET patients, there was an 84% success rate compared with 93.5% of 108 OS patients; the failed ET cases were all successfully treated by OS."
Reasoning: Provides the number of studies and patients included, but no flow diagram or reasons for exclusions.
[No]

P18. Results / Study characteristics
Quotes: See Table 2.
Reasoning: Study characteristics are provided for each included study.
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies
[NA] - No assessment of risk of bias was performed.

P20. Results / Results of individual studies
Quotes: See Tables 1-4.
Reasoning: Results are provided for individual studies and groups.
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results
[NA] - No meta-analysis was performed.

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies
[NA] - No assessment of risk of bias across studies was performed.

P23. Results / Additional analysis
[NA] - No additional analyses were performed.

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence
Quotes: "OS for RTEF has a low morbidity and mortality, a higher success rate, and requires fewer treatments than an endoscopic repair. The ideal ET is undecided but it remains a viable alternative provided treatment failures are anticipated and prompt redo treatments initiated to prevent ongoing respiratory morbidity."
Reasoning: Summarizes the main findings and their relevance to key groups.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
Quotes: "The major complications after OS were 17 (16%) leaks and 4 (3.7%) deaths; while for ET 3 (5%) suffered respiratory distress postoperatively and there was 1 (1.7%) death reported in 2005; this occurred 3 days postprocedure and the cause was unspecified."
Reasoning: Discusses some limitations at the study level but not at the review level.
[No]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
Quotes: "Minimally invasive techniques are widely accepted to be better tolerated by patients and whenever possible such options should be explored, thus supporting the case for ET; however, the outcomes should be comparable. Several authors have used a variety of techniques for ET, summarized above, all hoping to achieve better outcomes. There have been three literature reviews on ET. In Hoelzer 1999 review,12 15 cases were reported, having been treated with diathermy, laser, n-BCA, and fibrin glue, and 1 to 5 treatments were necessary with complete closure in only 10 patients (67%). Meier et al in 200726 reported an overall success rate of 60% of 62 patients culled from the literature (fibrin glue 55% [n = 22], n-BCA 48% [n = 29], laser 80% [n = 5], diathermy 50% [n = 10], n-BCA + sclerosant100% [n = 5]); the mean number of applications ranged from 1 to 5.5. They concluded that ET is safe, effective, has less morbidity than OS and recommended fibrin glue but advised close follow-up. Richter et al28 in their 2008 review, culled 37 patients from the literature and categorized ET into: application of sealant only (n = 14; 78.6% success), de-epithelialization of the fistula tract only (n = 8; 62.5% success), de-epithelialization combined with sealant (n = 15; 93.3%). Overall there was an 81.1% success rate (48.6% after a single attempt) and they concluded that de-epithelialization with diathermy combined with fibrin glue sealant will yield the best results; fibrin glue by nature would work better if the opposing surfaces are closely apposed and not epithelialized.21 The failures seen with ET may be partly because the sealants fibrin glue and n-BCA are biodegradable. Aproninin, an antifibrinolytic, prolongs the stability of fibrin glue in vivo for up to 10 days only96; however, the fibrin clot formed has a loose scaffold that encourages in-growth of fibroblasts. n-BCA, commonly used for skin closure, is not recommended for mucosal application by most manufacturers, as its stability and possible absorption in such environments is not yet fully determined. Willets et al (1998)55 also appreciating the possibility of late refistulation after ET, and the limited follow-up period of the reported cases managed endoscopically, decided to evaluate the long-term outcome of these patients by contacting the respective authors. They concluded that of 22 patients initially reported to have had successful ET, only 12 (55%) remained closed after a median follow-up of 107 months; there was however no morbidity or mortality directly related to these procedures."
Reasoning: Provides a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27. Funding
Quotes: "None."
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review are reported.
[Yes]

[NA] - No meta-analysis was performed.

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies
[NA] - No assessment of risk of bias across studies was performed.

P23. Results / Additional analysis
[NA] - No additional analyses were performed.

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence
Quotes: "OS for RTEF has a low morbidity and mortality, a higher success rate, and requires fewer treatments than an endoscopic repair. The ideal ET is undecided but it remains a viable alternative provided treatment failures are anticipated and prompt redo treatments initiated to prevent ongoing respiratory morbidity."
Reasoning: Summarizes the main findings and their relevance to key groups.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
Quotes: "The major complications after OS were 17 (16%) leaks and 4 (3.7%) deaths; while for ET 3 (5%) suffered respiratory distress postoperatively and there was 1 (1.7%) death reported in 2005; this occurred 3 days postprocedure and the cause was unspecified."
Reasoning: Discusses some limitations at the study level but not at the review level.
[No]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
Quotes: "Minimally invasive techniques are widely accepted to be better tolerated by patients and whenever possible such options should be explored, thus supporting the case for ET; however, the outcomes should be comparable. Several authors have used a variety of techniques for ET, summarized above, all hoping to achieve better outcomes. There have been three literature reviews on ET. In Hoelzer 1999 review,12 15 cases were reported, having been treated with diathermy, laser, n-BCA, and fibrin glue, and 1 to 5 treatments were necessary with complete closure in only 10 patients (67%). Meier et al in 200726 reported an overall success rate of 60% of 62 patients culled from the literature (fibrin glue 55% [n = 22], n-BCA 48% [n = 29], laser 80% [n = 5], diathermy 50% [n = 10], n-BCA + sclerosant100% [n = 5]); the mean number of applications ranged from 1 to 5.5. They concluded that ET is safe, effective, has less morbidity than OS and recommended fibrin glue but advised close follow-up. Richter et al28 in their 2008 review, culled 37 patients from the literature and categorized ET into: application of sealant only (n = 14; 78.6% success), de-epithelialization of the fistula tract only (n = 8; 62.5% success), de-epithelialization combined with sealant (n = 15; 93.3%). Overall there was an 81.1% success rate (48.6% after a single attempt) and they concluded that de-epithelialization with diathermy combined with fibrin glue sealant will yield the best results; fibrin glue by nature would work better if the opposing surfaces are closely apposed and not epithelialized.21 The failures seen with ET may be partly because the sealants fibrin glue and n-BCA are biodegradable. Aproninin, an antifibrinolytic, prolongs the stability of fibrin glue in vivo for up to 10 days only96; however, the fibrin clot formed has a loose scaffold that encourages in-growth of fibroblasts. n-BCA, commonly used for skin closure, is not recommended for mucosal application by most manufacturers, as its stability and possible absorption in such environments is not yet fully determined. Willets et al (1998)55 also appreciating the possibility of late refistulation after ET, and the limited follow-up period of the reported cases managed endoscopically, decided to evaluate the long-term outcome of these patients by contacting the respective authors. They concluded that of 22 patients initially reported to have had successful ET, only 12 (55%) remained closed after a median follow-up of 107 months; there was however no morbidity or mortality directly related to these procedures."
Reasoning: Provides a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27. Funding
Quotes: "None."
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review are reported.
[Yes]

We used exploded Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) and keywords to search for the following themes: pediatrics, open gastrostomy, percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy, interventional radiologically guided gastrostomy, and laparoscopic gastrostomy (Appendix 1 for detailed search strategy). We applied the search strategy to the following databases: MEDLINE (PubMed, PubMIsd in Process and Ovid), EMBASE, Cumulative Index of Nursing and Allied Health Literature (CINAHL), Scopus and Cochrane Library."

Reasoning: Risk of bias across studies was not assessed.

Reasoning: No additional analyses were reported.

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence
Quotes: "Gastrostomy tube placement remains a highly popular intervention with a number of indications, in both adult and pediatric populations. Since initially introduced in 1986 as an open surgical approach, it has evolved into a procedure performed using multiple different techniques by several different operators, including surgeons, gastroenterestinal endoscopists and interventional radiologists."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized, considering their relevance to key stakeholders.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
Quotes: "Selection of older, heavier children for the open procedure may be explained by the lack of evidence documenting safety of PEG in infants at the time of study completion. The first large pediatric review reporting safety of PEG in small (<6 kg) neonates with failure to thrive was in 2011 [38]. As there is currently no literature supporting patient age or weight as a predictive factor for success and safety of tube placement, we are unable to draw conclusions on the influence of these discrepancies of baseline demographics on the results. Additionally, the other 7 studies failed to report patient demographic information."
Reasoning: Limitations at the study and review level are discussed.
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
Quotes: "The placement of a gastrostomy tube in a pediatric patient often represents a seminal moment for the child, his/her family and the medical team providing care. The implications of the procedure resonate for years to follow as care plans shift to outpatient management and nutritional needs become definitively addressed. Ultimately, the technique chosen for gastrostomy tube placement should rest with the implicated health care team, individualized for each unique patient circumstance and be based on individual/institutional expertise."
Reasoning: The conclusions provide a general interpretation of the results with implications for practice.
[Yes]

P27. Funding
Quotes: "We would like to thank Robin Featherstone from the McGill Faculty of Medicine Library for her assistance with the literature search and the retrieval of articles."
Reasoning: Sources of support for the review are acknowledged, but funding sources for the individual studies are not reported.
[No]

P2 - Abstract: Structured summary
Quote: "Abstract Introduction Esophageal strictures refractory to conservative treatment represent a major problem in children. The application of Mitomycin C to the site of stricture has been introduced, but the experience with this novel approach remains very limited. Methods Systematic review of publications on the topical application of Mitomycin C in children with persistent esophageal stricture. Results We identified 11 publications including 31 cases."
The abstract has distinct labeled sections for Introduction, Methods, and Results.

Quote: "For centuries, esophageal strictures have been recognized as an important health problem in children.1–3 The etiology includes surgery for malformations of the foregut such as esophageal atresia (EA) and tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF), the ingestion of caustic agents, severe gastroesophageal reflux, and other disease entities."
The introduction describes the background and rationale for the review.

[No]
