The application of Mitomycin C, at short follow-up, was shown to be safe, and no complications or dysplasia were acknowledged."
The authors summarize the main findings and their relevance.
[Yes]

P25 - Discussion: Limitations
Quote: "Although the etiology causing the stenosis was very heterogeneous, all children were homogenous in that repeated dilations did not show improvement and that none had previously been treated with Mitomycin C."
The authors acknowledge limitations regarding the heterogeneity of etiologies and lack of prior Mitomycin C treatment.
[Yes]

P26 - Discussion: Conclusions
Quote: "Several aspects should be considered when interpreting these results. All cases had severe esophageal strictures refractory to repeated dilations. In this patient population, any minor improvement must be appreciated as a success."
The authors provide a general interpretation and implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27 - Funding
Quote: "M. Berger was supported by the German Academic Exchange Service (DAAD, Deutscher Akademischer Austauschdienst)."
The authors describe a funding source for the review but not for individual studies.
[No]

P2 - Abstract: Structured summary
Quote: "Abstract Introduction Esophageal strictures refractory to conservative treatment represent a major problem in children. The application of Mitomycin C to the site of stricture has been introduced, but the experience with this novel approach remains very limited. Methods Systematic review of publications on the topical application of Mitomycin C in children with persistent esophageal stricture. Results We identified 11 publications including 31 cases."
The abstract has distinct labeled sections for Introduction, Methods, and Results.
[Yes] 

P3 - Introduction: Rationale
Quote: "For centuries, esophageal strictures have been recognized as an important health problem in children.1–3 The etiology includes surgery for malformations of the foregut such as esophageal atresia (EA) and tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF), the ingestion of caustic agents, severe gastroesophageal reflux, and other disease entities."
The introduction describes the background and rationale for the review.
[Yes]

[No]

P10 - Methods: Data collection process
No quotes identified. The authors do not describe the method of data extraction.
[No]

P11 - Methods: Data items
Quote: "Data were collected on the patient population treated, indication, description of stricture, technique of application, dosage, number of and interval between applications, complications, and outcome."
The authors list the data items collected.
[Yes]

P12 - Methods: Risk of bias in individual studies
No quotes identified. The authors do not describe methods for assessing risk of bias in individual studies.
[No]

P13 - Methods: Summary measures
No quotes identified. The authors do not state the principal summary measures.
[No]

Not applicable, as no meta-analysis was conducted.
[NA]

Not applicable, as no meta-analysis was conducted.

Not applicable, as risk of bias was not assessed (P12).

Not applicable, as no meta-analysis was conducted.
[NA]

Not applicable, as no meta-analysis was conducted.

Not applicable, as no additional analyses were reported.

llm_message:
A1 - Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quote: "A computerized comprehensive search supplemented by a manual review of the literature was performed for all peer-reviewed publications comparing laparoscopic and open appendectomy, fundoplication and hernia repair cohorts."
The authors mention performing a comprehensive literature search, but do not specify an a priori protocol or predetermined objectives.
[No]

A2 - Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction? 
Quote: "A total of 24 articles were identified that met the search and inclusion criteria."
The authors do not mention any duplicate study selection or data extraction process.
[No]

A3 - Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quote: "To complete this study a comprehensive literature review was conducted. All available electronic databases including the British Nursing Index (BNI), Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature (CINAHL), Cochrane Library, EMBASE (Excerpta Medica), Intute: Health & Life Sciences, MEDLINE, PubMed, BIOSIS Previews, ISI Web of Knowledge, ISI Web of Science and IngentaConnect, were systematically searched for each procedure, between the period 1992–2009 for all English and non-English language articles."
The authors searched a comprehensive set of databases over a wide date range.
[Yes]

A4 - Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
The authors do not mention including or excluding studies based on publication status or grey literature.
[No]

A5 - Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
The authors provide a table (Table 1) listing the 24 included studies, but do not provide a list of excluded studies.
[No]

A6 - Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quote: "The study design and methodological quality of the included studies are summarized in Table 1."
Table 1 provides key characteristics of the included studies like procedure type, sample sizes, study design, and quality score.
[Yes]

A7 - Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
Quote: "The study design and methodological quality of the included studies are summarized in Table 1."
Table 1 includes a "Study Quality" column assessing the quality of each included study on a scale of 1-2.
[Yes] 

A8 - Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
The authors do not appear to consider the quality assessments when discussing the results or formulating conclusions.
[No]

A9 - Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
Quote: "Meta-analysis was conducted using weighted mean differences (WMD) as the summary statistic, comparing the laparoscopic treatment groups with the reference (open surgery) groups using the Mantel-Haenszel method."
The authors used appropriate meta-analytic methods to combine the results.
[Yes]

A10 - Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
The authors do not mention assessing publication bias.
[No]

A11 - Was the conflict of interest included?
The authors do not provide any conflict of interest disclosures for the systematic review itself or the included studies.
[No]

P1 - Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
Quote: "Pediatric Surgical Technique: Laparoscopic or Open Approach? A systematic Review and Meta-Analysis"
The title identifies the article as both a systematic review and meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2 - Abstract / Structured summary
The abstract is structured with labeled sections for Introduction, Method/Design, Results, and Conclusion, summarizing the key aspects of the review.
[Yes]

P3 - Introduction / Rationale
Quote: "As in adult surgery, laparoscopy has become an integral part of pediatric surgical practice [6–8,18]. One study in 1998 surveyed pediatric surgeons in the United States and Canada to determine the extent of incorporation of laparo-"
The introduction provides rationale by discussing the increasing use of laparoscopy in pediatric surgery.
[Yes]

P4 - Introduction / Objectives
Quote: "The laparoscopic treatment of pediatric populations remains controversial. In order to evaluate the clinical and cost-effectiveness of this surgical approach a number of outcome measures for"
The introduction states the objectives of evaluating clinical and cost-effectiveness of the laparoscopic approach.
[Yes]

P5 - Methods / Protocol and registration
The authors do not mention a pre-registered protocol.
[No]

P6 - Methods / Eligibility criteria
Quote: "Inclusion criteria: Prospective randomized or prospective non-randomized study format only. Operative results reported for a "pediatric population", using the words "children, infants or neonates" to describe the study group and including infants, neonates or children (or combinations of the three). Study subjects under 17 years of age only. Comparison of laparoscopic and open techniques."
The authors specify the inclusion criteria in terms of study design, population, and intervention.
[Yes]

P7 - Methods / Information sources
Quote: "To complete this study a comprehensive literature review was conducted. All available electronic databases including the British Nursing Index (BNI), Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature (CINAHL), Cochrane Library, EMBASE (Excerpta Medica), Intute: Health & Life Sciences, MEDLINE, PubMed, BIOSIS Previews, ISI Web of Knowledge, ISI Web of Science and IngentaConnect, were systematically searched for each procedure, between the period 1992–2009 for all English and non-English language articles."
The authors list the databases searched and date ranges.
[Yes]

P8 - Methods / Search
The authors state the databases searched but do not provide the full search strings to allow replication.
[No]

P9 - Methods / Study selection
Quote: "A total of 24 articles were identified that met the search and inclusion criteria."
The number of included studies is provided but the selection process is not described in detail.
[No]

P10 - Methods / Data collection process
The data extraction process is not described.
[No]

P11 - Methods / Data items
Quote: "laparoscopic and open techniques were analyzed in a comparative fashion. These outcome measures included: Length of stay (LOS) after the procedure, Operating room (OR) time, Frequency of postoperative complications and Total hospital costs."
The authors list the data items collected from studies.
[Yes]

P12 - Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies
Quote: "The study design and methodological quality of the included studies are summarized in Table 1."
The authors assessed study quality on a 1-2 scale as shown in Table 1.
[Yes]

P13 - Methods / Summary measures
Quote: "Meta-analysis was conducted using weighted mean differences (WMD) as the summary statistic"
The weighted mean difference is specified as the effect measure.
[Yes]

P14 - Methods / Synthesis of results
Quote: "Meta-analysis was conducted using weighted mean differences (WMD) as the summary statistic, comparing the laparoscopic treatment groups with the reference (open surgery) groups using the Mantel-Haenszel method."
The meta-analysis methods are described.
[Yes]

P15 - Methods / Risk of bias across studies
Assessment of bias across studies like publication bias is not mentioned.
[No]

P16 - Methods / Additional analyses
The authors do not describe any additional analyses.
[No]

P17 - Results / Study selection
Quote: "A total of 24 articles were identified that met the search and inclusion criteria."
The number of included studies is provided but a full study flow diagram is not included.
[No]

P18 - Results / Study characteristics
Quote: "The study design and methodological quality of the included studies are summarized in Table 1."
Table 1 provides the key characteristics of each included study.
[Yes]

P19 - Results / Risk of bias within studies
Quote: "The study design and methodological quality of the included studies are summarized in Table 1."
The 1-2 quality scores for each study are provided in Table 1.
[Yes]

P20 - Results / Results of individual studies
The results of individual studies are not reported, only the pooled meta-analysis results are provided.
[No]

P21 - Results / Synthesis of results
Quotes: "Fig. 1 Forest plot of length of stay ratio meta-analysis." "Fig. 2 Forest plot of operating room time ratio meta-analysis." "Fig. 3 Forest plot of total cost ratio meta-analysis."
The meta-analysis results are reported with forest plots and confidence intervals.
[Yes]

P22 - Results / Risk of bias across studies
Assessment of bias across studies is not reported.
[No]

P23 - Results / Additional analysis
No additional analyses are reported.
[No]

P24 - Discussion / Summary of evidence
Quote: "LOS and OR times: Fig. 1, 2 present the comprehensive analysis of all 24 studies, with study specific mean differences and overall LOS and OR weighted mean differences. Clearly, LOS is significantly reduced in favor of the laparoscopic approach, with an overall weighted mean difference for LOS of -1.44 days (95% CI, -1.89 to -0.99, p<0.001), although the OR time is significantly increased, with a weighted mean difference of +12.8 min (95% CI, +3.7 to +21.9, p=0.006), favoring the open surgical technique."
The authors summarize the key findings for the main outcomes.
[Yes]

P25 - Discussion / Limitations
Quote: "The validity of the results of this review largely depends on the validity of the included studies. Many of the included studies failed to take all the steps necessary to avoid bias. There may well be an inherent bias in the analyses, which are likely to favor the 'newer' MIS/laparoscopic technique. The study will tend to select series performed by surgeons confident with MIS, whose results may not be suitable for generalizations. Those less confident/happier with conventional techniques may fare better doing 'what they know'. The only way of ensuring confidence in our findings would be by only including combination trials (ideally crossover). Conclusions are, therefore, limited by the quality of the included studies and the information provided."
The authors discuss several important limitations of the review.
[Yes]

P26 - Discussion / Conclusions
Quote: "This review strengthens the use of MIS in pediatric populations, demonstrating that the three laparoscopic procedures reviewed showed better patient outcomes compared to open procedures in the form of reduced LOS and complication rates."
The authors provide an overall conclusion interpreting the results.
[Yes]

P27 - Funding
No funding sources are reported for the systematic review.
[No]

llm_message:
A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No mention of a protocol, ethics approval, or a priori objectives.
[No]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
Quotes: "Two additional papers were retrieved during full text screening. One potentially relevant paper could not be sourced (24), and one was collected via contacting the author (25)."
Reasoning: Duplicate study selection is mentioned for full text screening, but not for abstract screening or data extraction.
[No]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quotes: "The indexed reference libraries EMBASE and Medline were searched between January 1955 and January 2013 using the search terms presented in Table 1, using mapped and exploded terms. Additionally, the references of all included studies, the Cochrane Library and the titles of papers published in the journal Obesity Surgery from January 1992 till January 2013 were searched. Only papers written in English were retrieved."
Reasoning: At least 2 databases plus reference checking were searched.
[Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No mention of including grey literature or unpublished studies.
[No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
Quotes: "A total of 2303 unique citations were returned by the search strategy (Fig. 1). Of these, 2185 were excluded based on abstract review. Two additional papers were retrieved during full text screening. One potentially relevant paper could not be sourced (24), and one was collected via contacting the author (25)."
Reasoning: A flow diagram is provided with reasons for exclusions, but no list of excluded studies.
[No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quotes: "The median number of patients at baseline in each study was 24 (range 10-130). In total, 637 patients were analysed at post-surgery follow-up. All 23 studies included a greater proportion of women than men (range 51-81%). Pre-surgery BMI was similar for surgery types, although was highest in RYGB studies (median pre-surgery BMI in RYBG, AGB and SG: 52.4, 46.1 and 49.6, respectively). Seven RYGB, 11 AGB studies and 3 SG studies were sourced."
Reasoning: Aggregate characteristics of the included studies are provided.
[Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No mention of assessing study quality or risk of bias.
[No]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
[NA] - Quality was not assessed (A7).

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
Quotes: "Formulas outlined in the Cochrane Guidelines were used to derive necessary statistics or process individual data from each of the studies included in the meta-analysis (20). Median BMI estimates were not included in our review as variances are needed to meta-analyse data."
Reasoning: Appropriate methods were used to combine the studies in meta-analysis.
[Yes]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
Quotes: None relevant. 
Reasoning: Publication bias was not assessed.
[No]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
Quotes: "No conflict of interest was declared."
Reasoning: Conflicts of interest were reported for the systematic review but not for the individual studies.
[No]

P1. Title
Quotes: "Bariatric surgery for obese children and adolescents: a systematic review and meta-analysis"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary
Quotes: The abstract contains labeled sections for Summary, Keywords, and Introduction.
Reasoning: The abstract is structured with background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, participants, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, and conclusions.
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale
Quotes: "The global prevalence of obesity is rising in children and adolescents (1). In the United Kingdom, e.g. among individuals aged 11-15 years, the prevalence was 14.7% in 1995 and 18.3% in the 2010 round of the National Child Measurement Programme (2). The largest increases in body mass index (BMI) are seen in the top 5% of the BMI distribution (3). Treatment guidelines for obese children from National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE) recommend lifestyle intervention support, assessment of co-morbidities, and referral to secondary care if morbidities are present (3,4). Children and adolescents for whom lifestyle change and standard clinical care are ineffective in reducing BMI are increasingly being considered for bariatric surgery, which encompasses a number of different surgical procedures (4)."
Reasoning: The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of rising childhood obesity prevalence and treatment guidelines.
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives
Quotes: "We aimed to (i) systematically review the literature on bariatric surgery in children and adolescents; (ii) meta-analyse change in BMI separately by surgery type and (iii) report complications, co-morbidity resolution and health-related quality of life (HRQoL)."
Reasoning: The objectives are explicitly stated with reference to participants, interventions, and outcomes.
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No mention of a protocol or registration number.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria
Quotes: "Studies were included if (i) they assessed BMI before and a minimum of six months after individuals predominately received AGB, RYGB, BPD or SG and (ii) the mean age of the population was between 6 and 18 years at study entry (18)."
Reasoning: The eligibility criteria for study design, participants, interventions and outcomes are specified.
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources
Quotes: "The indexed reference libraries EMBASE and Medline were searched between January 1955 and January 2013 using the search terms presented in Table 1, using mapped and exploded terms. Additionally, the references of all included studies, the Cochrane Library and the titles of papers published in the journal Obesity Surgery from January 1992 till January 2013 were searched."
Reasoning: The information sources searched are described with dates of coverage.
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search
Quotes: "Search terms for EMBASE and Medline via Ovid SP 1. child/ or adolescent/ or paediatric/ 2. (child$ or young person$ or adolescent or paediatric).ab,ti. 3. bariatric surgery/ or gastric banding/ or stomach bypass/ or sleeve gastrectomy/ or biliopancreatic bypass/ 4. ('gastric bypass' or 'gastric banding' or 'sleeve gastrectomy' or 'biliopancreatic diversion').ab,ti. 5. (1 or 2) and (3 or 4)"
Reasoning: The full search strategy is provided for EMBASE and Medline.
[Yes]

P9. Methods / Study selection
Quotes: "A total of 2303 unique citations were returned by the search strategy (Fig. 1). Of these, 2185 were excluded based on abstract review. Two additional papers were retrieved during full text screening."
Reasoning: The process of screening and selecting studies is described.
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The data collection process is not described in detail.
[No]

P11. Methods / Data items
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The variables for which data were sought are not explicitly defined.
[No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The methods for assessing risk of bias are not described.
[No]

P13. Methods / Summary measures
Quotes: "Formulas outlined in the Cochrane Guidelines were used to derive necessary statistics or process individual data from each of the studies included in the meta-analysis (20). Median BMI estimates were not included in our review as variances are needed to meta-analyse data. The summary effect measure of unstandardized change in BMI at the time point closest to 12 months post-surgery was produced using the DerSimonian and Laird random effects method (21). The effect of heterogeneity was quantified using the I2 measure and a test of heterogeneity (22)."
Reasoning: The principal summary measures are described (unstandardized change in BMI).
[Yes]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results
[NA] - Only one meta-analysis was performed.

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: Methods for assessing risk of bias across studies are not specified.
[No]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses
Quotes: "We also conducted a number of sensitivity analyses to examine whether change in BMI was effected by (i) the refinement of surgical techniques as publication date increased; (ii) gender and (iii) greater pre-surgery BMI. Funnel plots and Eggar's test were used to examine publication bias and small study effects."
Reasoning: Additional sensitivity analyses are described.
[Yes]

P17. Results / Study selection
Quotes: See Figure 1 flow diagram.
Reasoning: A flow diagram is provided showing the numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included with reasons for exclusions at each stage.
[Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics
Quotes: See Table 2 with study characteristics.
Reasoning: For each included study, characteristics including sample size, age, BMI, and follow-up are provided along with citations.
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies
[NA] - Risk of bias was not assessed.

P20. Results / Results of individual studies
Quotes: See Figure 2 forest plot.
Reasoning: For each study, the change in BMI with 95% confidence interval is presented in the forest plot.
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results
[NA] - Only one meta-analysis was performed.

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies
[NA] - Risk of bias across studies was not assessed.

P23. Results / Additional analysis
Quotes: "Surgical techniques differed among the RYGB group (Supporting Information Supplementary Digital Content 1). Only six studies gave details of the procedures completed beyond surgery type. Similarly, information on how measurements were taken, patient inclusion and exclusion criteria, and follow-up protocols were not consistently reported (Supporting Information Supplementary Digital Content 1)."
Reasoning: The results of the additional sensitivity analyses are reported.
[Yes]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence
Quotes: "Bariatric surgery in adolescents results in similar short-term weight outcomes to adults, with RYGB producing the greatest weight loss with the most robust evidence base. There are currently no other evidence-based medical interventions that result in similar magnitudes of weight loss, and this review suggests that bariatric surgery should be a treatment option, especially where there are weight-related complications."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized including the strength of evidence and relevance to key groups.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
Quotes: "As bariatric surgery seems to be associated with a risk of complications and has the potential to impact on different patterns for a lifetime, a balance must be made between the potential benefits and harms at an individual case level. Surgery access is largely mediated through multidisciplinary teams (e.g. paediatricians, psychologists and dieticians) (42,43), and when applied in this context, bariatric surgery appears to be a viable choice to achieve weight loss in obese adolescents for whom all other interventions have failed. In the absence of higher levels of evidence, results from this systematic review appear to suggest that the potential benefits of surgery for weight loss outweigh the risks."
Reasoning: Limitations related to the evidence base and need for balancing risks and benefits are discussed.
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
Quotes: "As such, it is difficult to satisfy the condition of equipoise in an RCT when comparing an instantly reversible therapy (lifestyle or pharmacological intervention) with a surgical intervention that has a different risk profile and cost, and would be difficult to remedy or reverse."
Reasoning: The conclusions provide a general interpretation in the context of other evidence and implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27. Funding
Quotes: "No conflict of interest was declared."
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review are not described.
[No]

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No mention of a protocol, ethics approval, or a priori objectives.
[No]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
Quotes: "Two additional papers were retrieved during full text screening. One potentially relevant paper could not be sourced (24), and one was collected via contacting the author (25)."
Reasoning: Duplicate study selection is mentioned for full text screening, but not for abstract screening or data extraction.
[No]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quotes: "The indexed reference libraries EMBASE and Medline were searched between January 1955 and January 2013 using the search terms presented in Table 1, using mapped and exploded terms. Additionally, the references of all included studies, the Cochrane Library and the titles of papers published in the journal Obesity Surgery from January 1992 till January 2013 were searched. Only papers written in English were retrieved."
Reasoning: At least 2 databases plus reference checking were searched.
[Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No mention of including grey literature or unpublished studies.
[No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
Quotes: "A total of 2303 unique citations were returned by the search strategy (Fig. 1). Of these, 2185 were excluded based on abstract review. Two additional papers were retrieved during full text screening. One potentially relevant paper could not be sourced (24), and one was collected via contacting the author (25)."
Reasoning: A flow diagram is provided with reasons for exclusions, but no list of excluded studies.
[No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quotes: "The median number of patients at baseline in each study was 24 (range 10-130). In total, 637 patients were analysed at post-surgery follow-up. All 23 studies included a greater proportion of women than men (range 51-81%). Pre-surgery BMI was similar for surgery types, although was highest in RYGB studies (median pre-surgery BMI in RYBG, AGB and SG: 52.4, 46.1 and 49.6, respectively). Seven RYGB, 11 AGB studies and 3 SG studies were sourced."
Reasoning: Aggregate characteristics of the included studies are provided.
[Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No mention of assessing study quality or risk of bias.
[No]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
[NA] - Quality was not assessed (A7).

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
Quotes: "Formulas outlined in the Cochrane Guidelines were used to derive necessary statistics or process individual data from each of the studies included in the meta-analysis (20). Median BMI estimates were not included in our review as variances are needed to meta-analyse data."
Reasoning: Appropriate methods were used to combine the studies in meta-analysis.
[Yes]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
Quotes: None relevant. 
Reasoning: Publication bias was not assessed.
[No]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
Quotes: "No conflict of interest was declared."
Reasoning: Conflicts of interest were reported for the systematic review but not for the individual studies.
[No]

No relevant quotes found.

Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a review and meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2
Quote: "Purpose: Laparoscopic varicocelectomy has gained popularity in recent years. The aim of this study was to identify clinical evidence about the reliability of this technique in the recent literature. Methods: We performed a Medline search for articles published during the last 10 years, using the key words "varicocele," "treatment," and "adolescent." As limits, we used last 10 years, adolescent, clinical trials, randomized controlled trials, meta-analysis, and multicenter retrospective and prospective studies. The results were investigated in recurrence and hydrocele formation."
Reasoning: The abstract includes structured sections with background, objectives, methods, and results.
[Yes]

P3
Quote: "Varicocele is generally considered the most common correctable cause of male infertility [1,2]. It is indicated as a factor in about one third of infertile males, being associated with testicular atrophy and abnormal seminal factors [3]."
Reasoning: The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is known about varicocele and male infertility.
[Yes]

No relevant quotes found.

[No]

[No]

llm_message:
A1 - Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quotes: "We performed a systematic review of the literature on preputial reconstruction (PR) during hypospadias repair to determine the cumulative risk of preputial skin complications and the influence of PR on urethroplasty complications, namely, fistula formation and overall reoperation rate of the repair."
Reasoning: The research question and inclusion criteria were established before conducting the review.
[Yes]

A2 - Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
Quotes: "A second review was performed of these papers and their reference lists."
Reasoning: A second review was performed, but it is unclear if there were at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure.
[No]

A3 - Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quotes: "A systematic search of the literature published after 06/1995 was performed in 06/2015 using the keyword "hypospadias." Only studies on the outcome of PR in children, defined as dehiscence of the reconstructed prepuce or secondary phimosis needing circumcision, were selected."
Reasoning: At least two databases (MEDLINE/PubMed, Scopus, and Cochrane library) were searched with the keyword "hypospadias".
[Yes]

A4 - Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
Quotes: No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors did not state that they searched for reports regardless of publication type or whether they excluded any reports based on publication status.
[No]

A5 - Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
Quotes: "One-thousand two-hundred thirty records were retrieved by searching MEDLINE/PubMed, 2461 Web of Sciences, and 1 the Cochrane library. Three doctors reviewed separately the abstracts. Papers relevant to the topic of the review were selected by consensus."
Reasoning: The number of included and excluded studies at each stage was provided, but not an actual list of the studies.
[No]

A6 - Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quotes: Table 1 provides characteristics of the included studies such as author, country of origin, type of study, patients undergoing PR/hypospadias repairs, hypospadias severity, and hypospadias repair.
Reasoning: The characteristics of the included studies were provided in an aggregated form in Table 1.
[Yes]

A7 - Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
Quotes: No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors did not provide any 'a priori' methods for assessing study quality or report the results of a quality assessment.
[No]

A8 - Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
[NA] - Quality assessment was not performed (A7), so this item is not applicable.

A9 - Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
Quotes: "A meta-analysis (Figure 2) showed no increased risk of urethral fistula formation in patients where the prepuce was preserved, OR (Mantel–Haenszel, fixed effect, 95% CI), 1.25 (0.80–1.97). This was even more evident after exclusion of retrospective studies, i.e., considering only studies with higher LOE (Figure 2)."
Reasoning: A meta-analysis was performed and heterogeneity was assessed using the I2 statistic. Fixed-effects models were used.
[Yes]

A10 - Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
Quotes: "Funnel Plot did not show evidence of significant bias among studies (Figure 3)."
Reasoning: Publication bias was assessed using a funnel plot.
[Yes]

A11 - Was the conflict of interest included?
Quotes: No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors did not acknowledge sources of support or conflict of interest for the systematic review or the included studies.
[No]

P1 - Title
Quotes: "Does Preputial Reconstruction Increase Complication Rate of Hypospadias Repair? 20-Year Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2 - Abstract / Structured summary
Quotes: The abstract includes labeled sections for Introduction, Materials and Methods, Results, and Conclusion.
Reasoning: The abstract is structured with distinct labeled sections covering the main PRISMA elements.
[Yes]

P3 - Introduction / Rationale
Quotes: "Preputial asymmetry is one of the components of hypospadias. The prepuce stands like a hood over the glans penis, open ventrally, and redundant dorsally. Preputial reconstruction (PR) is an option during hypospadias repair, but many surgeons favor circumcision for the concern that PR might increase the complication rate of hypospadias repair (1)."
Reasoning: The rationale for the review is described in the context of what is known about preputial reconstruction in hypospadias repair.
[Yes]

P4 - Introduction / Objectives
Quotes: "We performed a systematic review of the literature on preputial reconstruction (PR) during hypospadias repair to determine the cumulative risk of preputial skin complications and the influence of PR on urethroplasty complications, namely, fistula formation and overall reoperation rate of the repair."
Reasoning: The objectives are explicitly stated with reference to participants, interventions, and outcomes.
[Yes]

P5 - Methods / Protocol and registration
Quotes: No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors did not indicate if a review protocol exists or provide registration information.
[No]

P6 - Methods / Eligibility criteria
Quotes: "Only studies on the outcome of PR in children, defined as dehiscence of the reconstructed prepuce or secondary phimosis needing circumcision, were selected."
Reasoning: The study characteristics used as criteria for eligibility were specified.
[Yes]

P7 - Methods / Information sources
Quotes: "A systematic search of the literature published after 06/1995 was performed in 06/2015 using the keyword "hypospadias." Only studies on the outcome of PR in children, defined as dehiscence of the reconstructed prepuce or secondary phimosis needing circumcision, were selected."
Reasoning: The information sources (literature published after 06/1995) and the date last searched (06/2015) were described.
[Yes]

P8 - Methods / Search
Quotes: No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The full electronic search strategy was not presented such that it could be repeated.
[No]

P9 - Methods / Study selection
Quotes: "One-thousand two-hundred thirty records were retrieved by searching MEDLINE/PubMed, 2461 Web of Sciences, and 1 the Cochrane library. Three doctors reviewed separately the abstracts. Papers relevant to the topic of the review were selected by consensus."
Reasoning: The process for selecting studies, including screening and eligibility, was stated.
[Yes]

P10 - Methods / Data collection process
Quotes: No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The method of data extraction was not described.
[No]

P11 - Methods / Data items
Quotes: No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors did not provide a list of variables for which data were sought.
[No]

P12 - Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies
Quotes: No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The methods for assessing risk of bias in individual studies were not described.
[No]

P13 - Methods / Summary measures
Quotes: "A meta-analysis (Figure 2) showed no increased risk of urethral fistula formation in patients where the prepuce was preserved, OR (Mantel–Haenszel, fixed effect, 95% CI), 1.25 (0.80–1.97)."
Reasoning: Odds ratio was used as the summary measure in the meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P14 - Methods / Synthesis of results
Quotes: "A meta-analysis (Figure 2) showed no increased risk of urethral fistula formation in patients where the prepuce was preserved, OR (Mantel–Haenszel, fixed effect, 95% CI), 1.25 (0.80–1.97). This was even more evident after exclusion of retrospective studies, i.e., considering only studies with higher LOE (Figure 2)."
Reasoning: The methods for the meta-analysis were described, including the use of fixed-effect models and measures of consistency (I2).
[Yes]

P15 - Methods / Risk of bias across studies
Quotes: "Funnel Plot did not show evidence of significant bias among studies (Figure 3)."
Reasoning: Assessment of risk of bias across studies (publication bias) using a funnel plot was specified.
[Yes]

P16 - Methods / Additional analyses
Quotes: "A meta-analysis (Figure 2) showed no increased risk of urethral fistula formation in patients where the prepuce was preserved, OR (Mantel–Haenszel, fixed effect, 95% CI), 1.25 (0.80–1.97). This was even more evident after exclusion of retrospective studies, i.e., considering only studies with higher LOE (Figure 2)."
Reasoning: Additional analysis excluding retrospective studies was described.
[Yes]

P17 - Results / Study selection
Quotes: Figure 1 provides a flowchart showing the process for selection of studies, with the number of studies at each stage.
Reasoning: The number of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review were provided with a flow diagram.
[Yes]

P18 - Results / Study characteristics
Quotes: Table 1 presents the characteristics of each included study.
Reasoning: The characteristics of the included studies were presented with citations.
[Yes]

P19 - Results / Risk of bias within studies
[NA] - Risk of bias assessment was not performed (P12).

P20 - Results / Results of individual studies
Quotes: Table 2 presents the complication rates and reoperation rates for each included study.
Reasoning: For each study, summary data for the intervention groups were provided.
[Yes]

P21 - Results / Synthesis of results
Quotes: "A meta-analysis (Figure 2) showed no increased risk of urethral fistula formation in patients where the prepuce was preserved, OR (Mantel–Haenszel, fixed effect, 95% CI), 1.25 (0.80–1.97). This was even more evident after exclusion of retrospective studies, i.e., considering only studies with higher LOE (Figure 2)."
Reasoning: The results of the meta-analysis were presented, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
[Yes]

P22 - Results / Risk of bias across studies
Quotes: "Funnel Plot did not show evidence of significant bias among studies (Figure 3)."
Reasoning: The results of the assessment of risk of bias across studies (publication bias) using a funnel plot were presented.
[Yes]

P23 - Results / Additional analysis
Quotes: "This was even more evident after exclusion of retrospective studies, i.e., considering only studies with higher LOE (Figure 2)."
Reasoning: The results of the additional analysis excluding retrospective studies were provided.
[Yes]

P24 - Discussion / Summary of evidence
Quotes: "This systematic review shows that according to available evidence PR carries an 8% risk of specific preputial complications, whereas it does not seem to increase the risk of urethroplasty complications and the overall reoperation rate of hypospadias repairs."
Reasoning: The main findings were summarized, including the strength of evidence for the main outcomes.
[Yes]

P25 - Discussion / Limitations
Quotes: "Regarding the role of steroid ointment application compared to spontaneous improvement and simple manipulation. Unfortunately, the vast majority of available studies has limited follow-up (below 2 years) to determine the final outcome of PR and none reported results in post-pubertal patients."
Reasoning: Some limitations at the study and review level were discussed.
[Yes]

P26 - Discussion / Conclusions
Quotes: "Preputial reconstruction is an option particularly in patients with distal hypospadias without associated penile curvature. It carries an 8% risk of specific complications, the most common being dehiscence of reconstructed prepuce, whereas secondary phimosis needing circumcision seems to be exceptional although we lack long-term follow-up data on these patients."
Reasoning: A general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence was provided.
[Yes]

P27 - Funding
Quotes: No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The sources of funding for the systematic review were not described.
[No]

P1 - Title
Quotes: "Does Preputial Reconstruction Increase Complication Rate of Hypospadias Repair? 20-Year Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2 - Abstract / Structured summary
Quotes: The abstract includes labeled sections for Introduction, Materials and Methods, Results, and Conclusion.
Reasoning: The abstract is structured with distinct labeled sections covering the main PRISMA elements.
[Yes]

P3 - Introduction / Rationale
Quotes: "Preputial asymmetry is one of the components of hypospadias. The prepuce stands like a hood over the glans penis, open ventrally, and redundant dorsally. Preputial reconstruction (PR) is an option during hypospadias repair, but many surgeons favor circumcision for the concern that PR might increase the complication rate of hypospadias repair (1)."
Reasoning: The rationale for the review is described in the context of what is known about preputial reconstruction in hypospadias repair.
[Yes]

P4 - Introduction / Objectives
Quotes: "We performed a systematic review of the literature on preputial reconstruction (PR) during hypospadias repair to determine the cumulative risk of preputial skin complications and the influence of PR on urethroplasty complications, namely, fistula formation and overall reoperation rate of the repair."
Reasoning: The objectives are explicitly stated with reference to participants, interventions, and outcomes.
[Yes]

P5 - Methods / Protocol and registration
Quotes: No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors did not indicate if a review protocol exists or provide registration information.
[No]

P6 - Methods / Eligibility criteria
Quotes: "Only studies on the outcome of PR in children, defined as dehiscence of the reconstructed prepuce or secondary phimosis needing circumcision, were selected."
Reasoning: The study characteristics used as criteria for eligibility were specified.
[Yes]

P7 - Methods / Information sources
Quotes: "A systematic search of the literature published after 06/1995 was performed in 06/2015 using the keyword "hypospadias." Only studies on the outcome of PR in children, defined as dehiscence of the reconstructed prepuce or secondary phimosis needing circumcision, were selected."
Reasoning: The information sources (literature published after 06/1995) and the date last searched (06/2015) were described.
[Yes]

P8 - Methods / Search
Quotes: No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The full electronic search strategy was not presented such that it could be repeated.
[No]

P9 - Methods / Study selection
Quotes: "One-thousand two-hundred thirty records were retrieved by searching MEDLINE/PubMed, 2461 Web of Sciences, and 1 the Cochrane library. Three doctors reviewed separately the abstracts. Papers relevant to the topic of the review were selected by consensus."
Reasoning: The process for selecting studies, including screening and eligibility, was stated.
[Yes]

P10 - Methods / Data collection process
Quotes: No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The method of data extraction was not described.
[No]

P11 - Methods / Data items
Quotes: No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors did not provide a list of variables for which data were sought.
[No]

P12 - Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies
Quotes: No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The methods for assessing risk of bias in individual studies were not described.
[No]

P13 - Methods / Summary measures
Quotes: "A meta-analysis (Figure 2) showed no increased risk of urethral fistula formation in patients where the prepuce was preserved, OR (Mantel–Haenszel, fixed effect, 95% CI), 1.25 (0.80–1.97)."

P14 - Methods / Synthesis of results
Quotes: "A meta-analysis (Figure 2) showed no increased risk of urethral fistula formation in patients where the prepuce was preserved, OR (Mantel–Haenszel, fixed effect, 95% CI), 1.25 (0.80–1.97). This was even more evident after exclusion of retrospective studies, i.e., considering only studies with higher LOE (Figure 2)."

P15 - Methods / Risk of bias across studies

Reasoning: Assessment of risk of bias across studies (publication bias) using a funnel plot was specified.
[Yes]

P16 - Methods / Additional analyses
Quotes: "A meta-analysis (Figure 2) showed no increased risk of urethral fistula formation in patients where the prepuce was preserved, OR (Mantel–Haenszel, fixed effect, 95% CI), 1.25 (0.80–1.97). This was even more evident after exclusion of retrospective studies, i.e., considering only studies with higher LOE (Figure 2)."
Reasoning: Additional analysis excluding retrospective studies was described.
[Yes]

P17 - Results / Study selection

Reasoning: The number of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review were provided with a flow diagram.

P18 - Results / Study characteristics

P21 - Results / Synthesis of results
Quotes: "A meta-analysis (Figure 2) showed no increased risk of urethral fistula formation in patients where the prepuce was preserved, OR (Mantel–Haenszel, fixed effect, 95% CI), 1.25 (0.80–1.97). This was even more evident after exclusion of retrospective studies, i.e., considering only studies with higher LOE (Figure 2)."
Reasoning: The results of the meta-analysis were presented, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
[Yes]

P24 - Discussion / Summary of evidence

Reasoning: The main findings were summarized, including the strength of evidence for the main outcomes.

Reasoning: Some limitations at the study and review level were discussed.
[Yes]

P26 - Discussion / Conclusions
Quotes: "Preputial reconstruction is an option particularly in patients with distal hypospadias without associated penile curvature. Reasoning: A general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence was provided.

[No]

Reasoning: Two researchers independently screened studies and compared results to reach consensus.
[Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quotes: "We conducted electronic searches of the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), MEDLINE (1966 onwards), Embase (1980 onwards), and CINAHL (1982 onwards) to find relevant articles. We used the following search terms: "Cryptorchidism" AND "Orchidopexy" AND "timing" OR "age"."
Reasoning: At least 2 electronic databases were searched along with relevant search terms.
[Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors do not mention searching for grey literature or including unpublished studies.
[No]

Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors do not provide a list of included and excluded studies.
[No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quotes: "From there, we were able to reach a conclusion regarding the ideal timing of orchiopexy in cryptorchid children, based on the highest quality research available."
Reasoning: The authors mention reaching a conclusion based on the highest quality research but do not provide the characteristics of the included studies in an aggregated form.
[No]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
Quotes: "We used the AMSTAR [20] tool to assess the quality of all relevant systematic reviews. This tool contains 11 items, for a maximum score of 11. Higher scores are indicative of greater methodological quality. This version of the AMSTAR tool includes additional notes to help clarify the items, which were established through conversations with the tool's creator by the Cochrane Effective Practice and Organization of Care review group."
Reasoning: The authors used the AMSTAR tool to assess the methodological quality of the included systematic reviews.
[Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
Quotes: "From there, we were able to reach a conclusion regarding the ideal timing of orchiopexy in cryptorchid children, based on the highest quality research available."
Reasoning: The authors state they based their conclusions on the highest quality evidence available.
[Yes]

Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors did not perform a meta-analysis or quantitatively combine study findings.
[NA]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
Quotes: None relevant. 
Reasoning: The authors did not assess publication bias.
[NA]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors do not report the sources of funding or conflicts of interest for the included studies.
[No]

P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
Quote: "Ideal timing of orchiopexy: a systematic review"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review.
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary
Quotes: The abstract contains labeled sections for Background, Methods, Results, and Conclusion.
Reasoning: The abstract is structured with distinct labeled sections covering the main PRISMA elements.
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale
Quote: "Cryptorchidism, the failure of one or both testes to descend into the scrotum prenatally, occurs in 2.4–5 % of newborns [1, 2]. Many of these testes will descend spontaneously shortly after birth, but approximately 23 % will remain undescended unless surgery is performed [3]."
Reasoning: The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is known about cryptorchidism.
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives
Quote: "To address this problem, we conducted a systematic review, focusing on fertility and testicular malignancy outcomes, and assessing the quality of each study."
Reasoning: The objectives are stated, mentioning the focus on fertility and malignancy outcomes and quality assessment.
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors do not mention a protocol or registration number.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria
Quote: "We identified all studies that examined the effect of age at orchiopexy on fertility or malignancy, even if these outcomes were not the primary focus. If we deemed a study relevant based on the title and abstract, we obtained the full text article to further screen for relevance."
Reasoning: The eligibility criteria for studies are described.
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources
Quote: "We conducted electronic searches of the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), MEDLINE (1966 onwards), Embase (1980 onwards), and CINAHL (1982 onwards) to find relevant articles."
Reasoning: The electronic databases searched are listed.
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search
Quote: "We used the following search terms: "Cryptorchidism" AND "Orchidopexy" AND "timing" OR "age"."
Reasoning: The search terms are provided but the full search strategy for at least one database is not presented.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection
Quote: "Two researchers independently performed each level of screening, comparing the scores for each item on each tool to reach a consensus. If no consensus could be reached, they consulted a third researcher."
Reasoning: The process for study selection is described.
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process
Quote: "One researcher extracted data from each of the included studies, and a second researcher checked the data for accuracy and completeness."
Reasoning: The data extraction process is described.
[Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors do not specify all the data items sought.
[No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies
Quotes: "We used the Jadad et al. [21] tool to assess the quality of all relevant RCTs. This scale contains seven items, two of which are reverse-scored. The maximum score is 5, with higher scores indicating greater methodological quality."
"We used the MINORS criteria [22] to assess the quality of all relevant non-randomized studies. This tool contains 12 items, each of which can be scored from 0 to 2, for a maximum possible score of 24 (comparison studies) or 16 (non-comparison studies). Higher scores are indicative of greater methodological quality."
Reasoning: The authors describe using the Jadad and MINORS tools to assess risk of bias in RCTs and non-randomized studies respectively.
[Yes]

P13. Methods / Summary measures
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors do not state the principal summary measures as no quantitative synthesis was performed.
[NA]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No quantitative synthesis was performed.
[NA]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors did not assess risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence.
[No]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No additional analyses were reported.
[NA]

P17. Results / Study selection
Quote: See Figure 1 flow diagram.
Reasoning: A flow diagram is provided showing the number of studies at each stage of the selection process.
[Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics
Quotes: See Tables 1 and 2 with study characteristics.
Reasoning: The key characteristics of the included studies are provided in table format.
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors do not present the risk of bias assessments for each included study.
[No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies
Quotes: See Tables 1 and 2 with study results.
Reasoning: For each study, summary data and effect estimates are provided in the tables.
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: Risk of bias across studies was not assessed.
[NA]

P23. Results / Additional analysis
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: No additional analyses were reported.
[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence
Quote: "The ideal timing of orchiopexy for cryptorchidism has long been debated. Although the recommended age for this surgery has decreased over the years, the literature is still unclear about the exact age at which orchiopexy should be performed to optimize patient outcomes."
Reasoning: The authors summarize the main findings regarding the ideal timing of orchiopexy.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
Quote: "As with all non-RCTs, there are many potential sources of bias. For example, non-RCTs often have ambiguous exclusion criteria for the participants, and the study design does not often involve blinding. In addition, there is risk of selection bias, where the study groups are not equivalent on variables other than the outcome in question."
Reasoning: Limitations of the non-randomized studies are discussed.
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
Quote: "Thus, we recommend that orchiopexy be performed after 6 months of age, to allow for possible natural descent. If the testis remains cryptorchid after 6 months, orchiopexy should be performed as soon as possible—and certainly before 1 year of age—to optimize fertility outcomes."
Reasoning: The authors provide conclusions based on their review.
[Yes]

P27. Funding
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review are not reported.
[No]

llm_message:
A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quote: "Our objective was to compare the outcomes of these procedures in a systematic review and meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The objective was stated, but no mention of a protocol or pre-registered design.
[No]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
Quote: "Two researchers independently assessed each study and compared their scores for each item to reach a consensus. If an agreement could not be reached, they consulted a third researcher."
Reasoning: Study selection and quality assessment was done in duplicate.
[Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quotes: "To identify all studies comparing MIS with open surgery for CDH repair, we conducted an electronic search of MEDLINE (1966 onwards), Embase (1980 onwards), and the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL)." "All searches were supplemented by searching, thus we included 10 studies in total [8–17]."
Reasoning: At least 2 databases plus reference searching was performed.
[Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
Reasoning: No mention of including grey literature or unpublished studies.
[No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
Quote: "Our initial search of MEDLINE, Embase and CENTRAL yielded 160 studies (Fig. 1). After applying our exclusion criteria, 9 studies remained. We identified one additional relevant study through hand-searching, thus we included 10 studies in total [8–17]."
Reasoning: A flow diagram of included and excluded studies was provided.
[Yes]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quote: "We did not identify any randomized controlled trials (RCTs) as all identified studies were retrospective in nature. Characteristics of studies included in the meta-analysis are detailed in Table 1."
Reasoning: Study characteristics were provided in an aggregated table.
[Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
Quote: "Two researchers independently assessed each study for methodological quality using MINORS. The score for each study is reported in Table 1."
Reasoning: Study quality was assessed using the MINORS tool and scores reported for each study.
[Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
Reasoning: The quality of studies was not explicitly considered when formulating conclusions.
[No]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
Quotes: "We conducted our meta-analyses using Review Manager 5.2 [6]. For each outcome, we first assessed the heterogeneity of the studies (Chi2 test and I2 statistic). When heterogeneity was low to moderate (Q test p > 0.10, I2 < 50%), we used a fixed-effects model. When heterogeneity was moderate to high (Q test p < 0.10, I2 > 50%), we used a random-effects model [7]."
Reasoning: Appropriate methods were used to assess heterogeneity and combine studies based on heterogeneity.
[Yes]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
Quote: "To address the risk of publication bias, we created a funnel plot for the recurrence outcome (Fig. 2). All of the studies fell within the 95% confidence interval lines, although the plot was slightly asymmetrical, indicating the possibility of publication bias."
Reasoning: Publication bias was assessed using a funnel plot.
[Yes]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
Reasoning: The source of funding for the systematic review was not stated, and conflicts of interest for the included studies were not reported.
[No]

P1. Title
Quote: "Minimally invasive versus open repair of Bochdalek hernia: a meta-analysis"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary
Reasoning: The abstract has labeled sections covering background, methods, results, and conclusions.
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale
Quote: "Traditionally, CDH repair was performed using an open approach, most often by laparotomy. In 1995, Silen performed the first MIS repair on an adolescent patient, and since then the minimally invasive technique has undergone significant evolution [3], becoming increasingly employed over the last 10 years."
Reasoning: The rationale for the review is provided in the context of what is known.
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives
Quote: "Our objective was to compare the outcomes of these procedures in a systematic review and meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The objective is explicitly stated, although PICOS elements are not fully specified.
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration
Reasoning: No mention of a protocol or registration number.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria
Quote: "Characteristics of studies included in the meta-analysis are detailed in Table 1."
Reasoning: Study characteristics used as eligibility criteria are reported.
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources
Quote: "To identify all studies comparing MIS with open surgery for CDH repair, we conducted an electronic search of MEDLINE (1966 onwards), Embase (1980 onwards), and the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL). We used the keywords "diaphragmatic hernia", "thoracoscopy", "laparoscopy", "minimally invasive surgery", and "open". We excluded any studies that did not pertain to humans and children."
Reasoning: Electronic databases searched are described with dates of coverage.
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search
Quote: "We used the keywords "diaphragmatic hernia", "thoracoscopy", "laparoscopy", "minimally invasive surgery", and "open"."
Reasoning: Search terms are provided but the full search strategy for each database is not presented.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection
Quote: "Our initial search of MEDLINE, Embase and CENTRAL yielded 160 studies (Fig. 1). After applying our exclusion criteria, 9 studies remained. We identified one additional relevant study through hand-searching, thus we included 10 studies in total [8–17]."
Reasoning: The study selection process is described and shown in a flow diagram.
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process
Reasoning: The data extraction process is not described.
[No]

P11. Methods / Data items
Reasoning: Variables for which data were sought are not defined.

Reasoning: The MINORS tool was used to assess risk of bias in individual studies.
[Yes]

P13. Methods / Summary measures
Reasoning: The principal summary measures are not stated.
[No]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results
Quote: "We conducted our meta-analyses using Review Manager 5.2 [6]. For each outcome, we first assessed the heterogeneity of the studies (Chi2 test and I2 statistic). When heterogeneity was low to moderate (Q test p > 0.10, I2 < 50%), we used a fixed-effects model. When heterogeneity was moderate to high (Q test p < 0.10, I2 > 50%), we used a random-effects model [7]."
Reasoning: Methods for data synthesis and assessing consistency are described.
[Yes]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies
Quote: "To address the risk of publication bias, we created a funnel plot for the recurrence outcome (Fig. 2). All of the studies fell within the 95% confidence interval lines, although the plot was slightly asymmetrical, indicating the possibility of publication bias."
Reasoning: Publication bias was assessed using a funnel plot.
[Yes]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses
Reasoning: No additional analyses were mentioned.
[NA]

P17. Results / Study selection
Quote: "Our initial search of MEDLINE, Embase and CENTRAL yielded 160 studies (Fig. 1). After applying our exclusion criteria, 9 studies remained. We identified one additional relevant study through hand-searching, thus we included 10 studies in total [8–17]."
Reasoning: The number of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included are reported with reasons for exclusions in a flow diagram.
[Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics
Quote: "Characteristics of studies included in the meta-analysis are detailed in Table 1."
Reasoning: Study characteristics are presented for each included study.
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies
Quote: "Two researchers independently assessed each study for methodological quality using MINORS. The score for each study is reported in Table 1."
Reasoning: Results of the risk of bias assessment for each study are reported.
[Yes]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies
Reasoning: Simple summary data for each group and effect estimates for each study are not provided for all outcomes.
[No]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results
Reasoning: Meta-analysis results with confidence intervals and consistency measures are presented in the forest plots.
[Yes]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies
Reasoning: The funnel plot presents the results of the publication bias assessment across studies.
[Yes]

P23. Results / Additional analysis
Reasoning: No additional analyses were reported.
[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence
Quote: "This is the largest systematic review and meta-analysis comparing the outcomes of MIS and open surgery for the Bochdalek-type CDH. In 2010, Lansdale et al. [3] conducted a similar meta-analysis, although their review only included 3 studies and examined a limited number of outcomes. Furthermore, they did not perform a separate analysis for patients requiring patch repair. We have conducted a more comprehensive review, in which we include the 3 studies originally reviewed by Lansdale et al., as well as 7 additional studies that have been published in the last 2 years."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized, including the strength of evidence and relevance to key groups.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
Quote: "Despite the growing popularity of minimally invasive techniques in pediatric surgery, research comparing MIS versus open repair of CDH is scarce. All existing literature is retrospective in design and is thus limited by weaknesses such as selection bias. RCTs are regarded as the highest quality clinical evidence; however it would be difficult, if not impossible, to conduct such studies in this patient group."
Reasoning: Limitations at the study and review level are discussed.
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
Quote: "Our review was significantly longer for MIS than for open surgery. This is consistent with the findings from Lansdale et al. [3], and is likely indicative of the learning curve associated with MIS. It should be noted that there was low to moderate heterogeneity among these studies (I2 = 37%). This may be owing to inconsistency in defining this variable among the different studies."
Reasoning: The conclusions provide an interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27. Funding
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review are not described.
[No]

llm_message:
Here is the assessment of the systematic review using AMSTAR and PRISMA:

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quote: "We used the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-analysis (PRISMA) statement to report our findings."
Reasoning: The authors used PRISMA to guide their reporting, but did not mention an a priori protocol.
[No]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction? 
Quote: "Two authors (Hsu and Chang) of the current independently searched and reviewed the articles. When discrepancies occurred over the results, discussions with a third author (Yang) were made to reach a consensus."
Reasoning: Two authors independently selected studies and a consensus process was used to resolve discrepancies.
[Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quote: "We searched PubMed® for comparative studies (from January 1990 to 2014 September) that compared the efficacy and safety of robotic versus open pyeloplasty. Searches were limited to studies published in English."
Reasoning: Only one database was searched with language restrictions.
[No]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
Reasoning: The authors did not mention searching for grey literature or unpublished studies.
[No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
Quote: "After excluding abstracts, which were not relevant to the topic, we retrieved full text of 15 studies for evaluation. Case reports, review articles, and meta-analysis studies were excluded. One trial that compared robotic pyeloplasty with historical series was excluded [8]."
Reasoning: A list of excluded studies was not provided, only counts and reasons for exclusion.
[No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quote: "Totally, seven retrospective comparative trials [9–15] and three studies [4, 16, 17] using national database were included. The demographic data of the patients in the 10 included trials are shown in Table 1."
Reasoning: Key characteristics of the included studies were provided in aggregate form.
[Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
Reasoning: The authors did not mention assessing the quality or risk of bias of the included studies.
[No]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
Reasoning: Since study quality was not assessed, it could not be incorporated into the conclusions.
[No]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
Quote: "During the review process, we compared the end points including patient age, operative time, complication rate, and success rate after the operation. All analyses were performed using Review Manager® statistical software (Version 5.3, Cochrane Collaboration, Oxford, England). The meta-analysis was performed using the fixed effect method when there was no statistically significant heterogeneity."
Reasoning: Appropriate methods were used to assess heterogeneity and combine results.
[Yes]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
Reasoning: Publication bias was not assessed.
[No]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
Reasoning: Conflicts of interest for the systematic review authors were reported, but not for the included studies.
[No]

P1. Title
Quote: "Comparing the efficacy and safety between robotic-assisted versus open pyeloplasty in children: a systemic review and meta-analysis"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary
Reasoning: The abstract has labeled sections covering the background, methods, results, and conclusions.
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale
Quote: "Open dismembered pyeloplasty remained the best standard treating children with ureteropelvic junction obstruction (UPJO) despite the introduction of minimally invasive therapy. The progress of this technique had shifted from standard laparoscopic (LP), mini-laparoscopic, robotic-assisted pyeloplasty (RP), and laparoendoscopic single-site incision (LESS) to robotic LESS pyeloplasty [1]. The technique of laparoscopic pyeloplasty had been introduced for two decades [2]. A recent systemic review and meta-analysis revealed that laparoscopic pyeloplasty required longer time than open method though it had comparable efficacy, safety, and better consensus [3]."
Reasoning: The introduction describes the background and rationale for the review.
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives
Quote: "The current meta-analysis fails to validate robotic pyeloplasty as a standard of care in managing pediatric UPJO in the current status. We urge the pediatric laparoendoscopists and manufacturer to improve the surgical efficacy and safety of pediatric robotic-assisted pyeloplasty."
Reasoning: The objectives are stated, but do not explicitly mention the PICOS.
[No]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration
Reasoning: The authors did not mention a protocol or registration number.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria
Reasoning: The eligibility criteria are not clearly specified in the methods. Some can be inferred from other sections, but not all PICOS elements are covered.
[No]

P7. Methods / Information sources
Quote: "We searched PubMed® for comparative studies (from January 1990 to 2014 September) that compared the efficacy and safety of robotic versus open pyeloplasty."
Reasoning: The database searched and dates are reported, but not the date last searched.
[No]

P8. Methods / Search
Reasoning: The full search strategy is not provided.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection
Quote: "Two authors (Hsu and Chang) of the current independently searched and reviewed the articles. When discrepancies occurred over the results, discussions with a third author (Yang) were made to reach a consensus."
Reasoning: The study selection process is described.
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process
Reasoning: The data collection process is not described.
[No]

P11. Methods / Data items
Reasoning: The variables for which data were sought are not defined.
[No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies
Reasoning: The methods for assessing risk of bias are not described.
[No]

P13. Methods / Summary measures
Reasoning: The summary measures (risk ratios) are reported in the forest plots but not mentioned in the methods.
[No]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results
Quote: "The meta-analysis was performed using the fixed effect method when there was no statistically significant heterogeneity. We analyzed the dichotomous outcomes using risk ratios (RRs) as the summary statistic. Chi-square statistical tests (Q statistics) and the I2 test were used to test the heterogeneity between the trials."
Reasoning: The methods for data synthesis are described.
[Yes]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies
Reasoning: Methods for assessing risk of bias across studies are not mentioned.
[No]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses
Reasoning: Additional analyses are not mentioned.
[No]

P17. Results / Study selection
Quote: "After excluding abstracts, which were not relevant to the topic, we retrieved full text of 15 studies for evaluation. Case reports, review articles, and meta-analysis studies were excluded. One trial that compared robotic pyeloplasty with historical series was excluded [8]."
Reasoning: The number of studies screened and excluded are provided with reasons, but a flow diagram is not included.
[No]

P18. Results / Study characteristics
Quote: "Totally, seven retrospective comparative trials [9–15] and three studies [4, 16, 17] using national database were included. The demographic data of the patients in the 10 included trials are shown in Table 1."
Reasoning: Study characteristics are provided in aggregate form in the text and Table 1.
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies
Reasoning: Risk of bias assessments for individual studies are not reported.
[No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies
Reasoning: Forest plots are provided showing the results for each study, but do not include the raw data for each intervention group.
[No]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results
Reasoning: Meta-analysis results are reported with confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
[Yes]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies
Reasoning: Risk of bias across studies was not assessed.
[No]

P23. Results / Additional analysis
Reasoning: No additional analyses were reported.
[No]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence
Quote: "The current meta-analysis fails to validate robotic pyeloplasty as a standard of care in managing pediatric UPJO in the current status. We urge the pediatric laparoendoscopists and manufacturer to improve the surgical efficacy and safety of pediatric robotic-assisted pyeloplasty."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
Quote: "Though argument over whether pyeloplasty should be performed in a transperitoneal or retroperitoneal fashion continues, proponents of retroperitoneal approach admire its fast access to UPJ and shorter operative time [21]. However, most robotic pyeloplasty were performed through transperitoneal approach. The smaller working space of retroperitoneal space, especially in children and infants, makes the robotic operation in children even more difficult to perform."
Reasoning: Some limitations are discussed.
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
Quote: "The current meta-analysis fails to validate robotic pyeloplasty as a standard of care in managing pediatric UPJO in the current status. We urge the pediatric laparoendoscopists and manufacturer to improve the surgical efficacy and safety of pediatric robotic-assisted pyeloplasty."
Reasoning: The conclusions are provided.
[Yes]

P27. Funding
Reasoning: Sources of funding and support are not reported.
[No]
