Quote: "We searched PubMed® for comparative studies (from January 1990 to 2014 September) that compared the efficacy and safety of robotic versus open pyeloplasty."
Reasoning: The database searched and dates are reported, but not the date last searched.
[No]

P8. Methods / Search
Reasoning: The full search strategy is not provided.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection
Quote: "Two authors (Hsu and Chang) of the current independently searched and reviewed the articles. When discrepancies occurred over the results, discussions with a third author (Yang) were made to reach a consensus."
Reasoning: The study selection process is described.
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process
Reasoning: The data collection process is not described.
[No]

P11. Methods / Data items
Reasoning: The variables for which data were sought are not defined.
[No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies
Reasoning: The methods for assessing risk of bias are not described.
[No]

P13. Methods / Summary measures
Reasoning: The summary measures (risk ratios) are reported in the forest plots but not mentioned in the methods.
[No]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results
Quote: "The meta-analysis was performed using the fixed effect method when there was no statistically significant heterogeneity. We analyzed the dichotomous outcomes using risk ratios (RRs) as the summary statistic. Chi-square statistical tests (Q statistics) and the I2 test were used to test the heterogeneity between the trials."
Reasoning: The methods for data synthesis are described.
[Yes]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies
Reasoning: Methods for assessing risk of bias across studies are not mentioned.
[No]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses
Reasoning: Additional analyses are not mentioned.
[No]

P17. Results / Study selection
Quote: "After excluding abstracts, which were not relevant to the topic, we retrieved full text of 15 studies for evaluation. Case reports, review articles, and meta-analysis studies were excluded. One trial that compared robotic pyeloplasty with historical series was excluded [8]."
Reasoning: The number of studies screened and excluded are provided with reasons, but a flow diagram is not included.
[No]

P18. Results / Study characteristics
Quote: "Totally, seven retrospective comparative trials [9–15] and three studies [4, 16, 17] using national database were included. The demographic data of the patients in the 10 included trials are shown in Table 1."
Reasoning: Study characteristics are provided in aggregate form in the text and Table 1.
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies
Reasoning: Risk of bias assessments for individual studies are not reported.
[No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies
Reasoning: Forest plots are provided showing the results for each study, but do not include the raw data for each intervention group.
[No]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results
Reasoning: Meta-analysis results are reported with confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
[Yes]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies
Reasoning: Risk of bias across studies was not assessed.
[No]

P23. Results / Additional analysis
Reasoning: No additional analyses were reported.
[No]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence
Quote: "The current meta-analysis fails to validate robotic pyeloplasty as a standard of care in managing pediatric UPJO in the current status. We urge the pediatric laparoendoscopists and manufacturer to improve the surgical efficacy and safety of pediatric robotic-assisted pyeloplasty."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
Quote: "Though argument over whether pyeloplasty should be performed in a transperitoneal or retroperitoneal fashion continues, proponents of retroperitoneal approach admire its fast access to UPJ and shorter operative time [21]. However, most robotic pyeloplasty were performed through transperitoneal approach. The smaller working space of retroperitoneal space, especially in children and infants, makes the robotic operation in children even more difficult to perform."
Reasoning: Some limitations are discussed.
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
Quote: "The current meta-analysis fails to validate robotic pyeloplasty as a standard of care in managing pediatric UPJO in the current status. We urge the pediatric laparoendoscopists and manufacturer to improve the surgical efficacy and safety of pediatric robotic-assisted pyeloplasty."
Reasoning: The conclusions are provided.
[Yes]

P27. Funding
Reasoning: Sources of funding and support are not reported.
[No]

Reasoning: The authors manually searched reference lists and assessed studies for eligibility, but did not explicitly mention duplicate study selection and data extraction.

A3
Quote: "We searched all publications from August 1998 to March 2012 in the MEDLINE, EMBASE and Cochrane library databases and the Cochrane Controlled Trials Register using different combinations of the following terms: "Hirschsprung's disease," "perineal," "perineal pull-through," "transabdominal" and "pull-through." The reference lists of the full articles were also manually searched to identify additional eligible studies."

"Statistical heterogeneity was assessed using I2. A fixed-effects model was used if I2<50% and a random-effects model was used if I2≥50%. Statistical analysis was performed using Review Manager 5.1.0 (Cochrane Collaboration)."

[No]

P1
Quote: "Transanal endorectal pull-through versus transabdominal approach for Hirschsprung's disease: A systematic review and meta-analysis"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2
Quote: "Aim: Transanal endorectal pull-through (TERPT) has become popular for single-stage treatment of Hirschsprung's disease. The benefits of TERPT over the conventional transabdominal approach (TAB) are still unclear. We performed a comprehensive meta-analysis comparing the clinical outcomes of TERPT and TAB."
Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary including the background, objectives, methods, and results.
[Yes]

P3
Quote: "Since the first description of aganglionosis in the myenteric plexus of the distal colon in congenital megacolon by Dalla Valle et al., a variety of surgical procedures have been described in an attempt to restore normal bowel function in Hirschsprung's disease (HD) [1–6]. For many years, surgical treatment of HD involved staged procedures; an initial diverting enterostomy was followed by definitive transabdominal pull-through surgery with subsequent closure of the colostomy. These multi-stage surgeries have gradually been replaced by the primary pull-through surgery in many centers [7]."
Reasoning: The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of the history and evolution of surgical treatments for Hirschsprung's disease.
[Yes]

P4
Quote: "We performed a comprehensive meta-analysis comparing the clinical outcomes of TERPT and TAB."
Reasoning: The introduction provides an explicit statement of the question being addressed (comparing clinical outcomes of TERPT vs TAB) but does not reference all PICOS elements.
[No]

P5
Reasoning: The authors did not mention the existence of or access to a review protocol or registration number.
[No]

P6
Quote: "All studies comparing the functional outcome of TERPT with TAB were considered to meet the inclusion criteria and were included in our meta-analysis. All studies included in the meta-analysis were published in English, although no language restriction was imposed."
Reasoning: The authors specified the study characteristics used as eligibility criteria (comparing TERPT and TAB outcomes) and report characteristics (language).
[Yes]

P7
Quote: "We searched all publications from August 1998 to March 2012 in the MEDLINE, EMBASE and Cochrane library databases and the Cochrane Controlled Trials Register using different combinations of the following terms:"

Reasoning: The authors described the search terms used but did not provide the full electronic search strategy such that it could be repeated.

Quote: "After identifying relevant titles and abstracts, the studies were assessed for eligibility for inclusion in our meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The authors stated the process for selecting studies (identifying relevant titles/abstracts and assessing full-text for eligibility) but with limited detail.
[No]

P10
Quote: "Each included study was independently appraised by 3 reviewers (C.Y., S.N., N.K.L.) and data were extracted and entered into a database. Any disagreements were resolved by consensus."
Reasoning: The authors described the method of data extraction (independently by 3 reviewers) and resolving disagreements (by consensus).

P11
Reasoning: The authors did not provide a full list of variables for which data were sought.
[No]

Reasoning: The authors mentioned appraising studies but did not describe the methods used to assess risk of bias in individual studies.

Reasoning: The authors stated the principal summary measures (OR and MD).

"Statistical heterogeneity was assessed using I2. A fixed-effects model was used if I2<50% and a random-effects model was used if I2≥50%. Statistical analysis was performed using Review Manager 5.1.0 (Cochrane Collaboration)."
Reasoning: The authors described the methods used to combine study results and assess consistency.

Quote: "Fig. 1 Flow chart showing the pathway of article selection."
Reasoning: The authors provided a flow diagram showing the number of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included.
[Yes]

Quote: "Table 1 Characteristics of studies included in the meta-analysis."
Reasoning: The authors provided a table of characteristics for each included study along with citations.

[No]

Quotes: "Fig. 2 TERPT versus TAB: forest plot for operative time and length of hospital stay."
"Fig. 3 TERPT versus TAB: forest plot for postoperative incontinence."
"Fig. 4 TERPT versus TAB: forest plot for postoperative constipation."
"Fig. 5 TERPT versus TAB: forest plot for postoperative enterocolitis."
Reasoning: The authors provided forest plots showing the effect estimates and confidence intervals for each outcome from each study.
[Yes]

P21
Quotes: "Fig. 2 TERPT versus TAB: forest plot for operative time and length of hospital stay."
"Fig. 3 TERPT versus TAB: forest plot for postoperative incontinence."
"Fig. 4 TERPT versus TAB: forest plot for postoperative constipation."
"Fig. 5 TERPT versus TAB: forest plot for postoperative enterocolitis."
Reasoning: The authors presented forest plots showing the meta-analysis results with confidence intervals and measures of consistency for each outcome.
[Yes]

P22
Reasoning: The authors did not present any assessments of risk of bias across studies.
[No]

P23
Reasoning: The authors did not report any additional analyses.
[No]

P24
Quote: "Our meta-analysis suggests that the TERPT is superior to the conventional TAB pull-through for Hirschsprung's disease. To our knowledge, this study is the first systematic review and meta-analysis comparing TERPT to TAB pull-through for Hirschsprung's disease."
Reasoning: The authors summarized the main findings in the discussion.
[Yes]

P25
Quote: "All TERPT procedures were performed after 1996, while the earliest open procedure included in this meta-analysis was from 1990. In the intervening years, factors other than the surgical approach, such as improvements in pediatric perioperative care, management of complications, or even administration-driven attention to length of hospital stay, may have partially contributed to the apparent better outcomes in the TERPT group."
Reasoning: The authors discussed some limitations at the review level, such as differences between the groups that may have influenced outcomes other than the intervention.
[Yes]

P26
Quote: "We reviewed the length of aganglionic segments in each study as long-segment HD is associated with worse postoperative outcome and total colonic aganglionosis has the worst outcome [10]. Where data were available, all analyzed studies excluded their cases of total colonic aganglionosis. There was no statistical difference in length of aganglionic segment between TERPT and TAB in the included studies."
Reasoning: The authors provided an overall interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence (long-segment HD associated with worse outcomes) and implications for future research (analyzing length of aganglionic segments).
[Yes]

P27
Quote: "The authors would like to thank Mr. Fahad Javaid Siddiqui, Assistant Professor of Epidemiology, Singapore Clinical Research Institute, for his invaluable help with statistical analysis."
Reasoning: The authors disclosed a source of support for the systematic review (statistical analysis) but did not describe the role of the funder.
[No]

llm_message:
A1
"The systematic review was conducted in accordance with the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-analyses (PRISMA) guidelines.18 A local review protocol was established."
An a priori protocol was established before conducting the review.
[Yes]

A2
No relevant quotes found.
No mention of duplicate study selection and data extraction.
[No]

A3
"A systematic search of the English language literature was conducted using a keyword algorithm (Supplemental Figure 1, http:// links.lww.com/SLA/A928). The search was conducted using the following databases: CINAHL, EMBASE, Medline, and Cochrane Databases, from inception to January 11, 2015 (the search was again updated through the reference listings of those articles yielded through the initial electronic database search. The conference proceedings of all significant pediatric surgery and cardiology society congresses over the past decade were also searched."
A comprehensive search was performed using at least 2 databases and supplementary sources.
[Yes]

A4
No relevant quotes found.
No mention of including grey literature.
[No]

A5
"Nineteen studies met the eligibility criteria but reporting was adequate for 9. All were observational studies. These included a total of 414 patients managed expectantly, that is, ''asymptomatic patients'' in whom no intestinal rotation screening was undertaken (group A), 191 cases in whom screening was performed routinely (group B), and 92 patients considered ''symptomatic'' of potential rotational anomalies and therefore underwent imaging or laparotomy (group C). In group A, 1 patient developed symptoms attributable to malrotation in whom laparotomy confirmed the diagnosis during follow-up (0.24%). Most studies did not report screened and symptomatic patients separately. Therefore, among groups B and C, 151 had Ladd's operation was performed routinely (group B), and 92 patients who were considered ''symptomatic'' of potential rotational anomalies and therefore underwent imaging or laparotomy (group C)."
A list of included studies was provided, but no list of excluded studies.
[No]

A6
"For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations."
The characteristics of included studies were provided in an aggregated form in Table 2.
[Yes]

A7
"Quality of manuscripts was evaluated by using the Methodological Index for Nonrandomized Studies (MINORS) criteria,19 in addition for all sources of data by a local checklist (including reporting of symptoms, imaging, surgeries, morbidity, mortality, and so on). Bias was assessed at study and summary levels."
The quality of included studies was assessed using the MINORS criteria and a local checklist.
[Yes]

A8
"The evidence base for screening ''asymptomatic'' patients is weak especially considering the life-limiting comorbidities."
"We fully acknowledge that there are some limitations with the present study. Follow-up reporting data in studies we analyzed was sometimes poor. This may influence long-term outcome(s) of both a ''watchful waiting'' policy and operative intervention. Adequate reporting in studies was thus by no means always satisfactory. MINORS scoring highlighted these fact(s) (Fig. 1). Here, we found that little reference was made in many studies as to the nature of cardiac comorbidity(s) and cardiac mortality out with the perioperative period. It is heart anomalies, which most often are the determinant of life expectancy guiding the appropriateness of surgical correction of IRA. All studies included were retrospective observational studies with no valid comparator group (Oxford EBM—Level IV evidence25). As a result, there were some significant inherent bias(s) indicating interpretation of studies with care."
The results of the quality assessment were considered in the analysis and conclusions, with limitations acknowledged.
[Yes]

A9
Not applicable, as this was a systematic review without meta-analysis.
[NA]

A10
Not applicable, as this was a systematic review without meta-analysis.
[NA]

No relevant quotes found.
No mention of conflict of interest or funding sources for the included studies.
[No]

P1
"Is Screening of Intestinal Foregut Anatomy in Heterotaxy Patients Really Necessary? A Systematic Review in Search of the Evidence"
The title identifies the article as a systematic review.
[Yes]

The abstract is structured with labeled sections for Objective, Summary of Background Data, Methods, Results, and Conclusion.
[Yes]

P3
"Heterotaxy is an abnormal arrangement of thoraco-abdominal viscera across a left-to-right axis in contrast to normal patterning of ''situs solitus.'' Traditionally, a mirror-image pattern of arrangement was included in the definition, but this so-called ''situs inversus'' is now considered separately.1 Structural abnormalities of the heart, spleen, and bowel are commonplace. It is the cardiac anomalies that frequently account for the lethality of heterotaxy, with mortality within the first year of life the norm for several decades.2"
The introduction provides rationale for the review in the context of what is known about heterotaxy.
[Yes]

P4
"(1) Is screening of intestinal rotational anatomy obligatory in ''asymptomatic'' patients with heterotaxy? (2) Does detection of an anomaly warrant surgical correction?"
The introduction states the review questions.
[Yes]

A review protocol was established and mentioned, but no registration number was provided.
[No]

The inclusion criteria were specified.
[Yes]

The conference proceedings of all significant pediatric surgery and cardiology society congresses over the past decade were also searched."
Information sources were described, including databases with dates of coverage.
[Yes]

The full search strategy for one database was provided as supplementary material.
[Yes]

P24
"This systematic review shows that ''asymptomatic patients'' with heterotaxy are at a low risk of developing IRA-related complications. Of 414 patients managed expectantly, only a single patient (0.24%) developed symptoms directly attributable to IRA during the total follow-up period. Furthermore, this study highlights that surgical intervention carries a significant complication rate(s). Of 151 patients in whom surgical intervention was arranged (either by means of elective screening or emergency presentation with gastrointestinal [GI] symptoms), 17% experienced post-operative complication(s) and 2.6% died. Ladd's operation for asymptomatic patients is expected in such patients)."
The main findings were summarized.
[Yes]

P25
"We fully acknowledge that there are some limitations with the present study. Follow-up reporting data in studies we analyzed was sometimes poor. This may influence long-term outcome(s) of both a ''watchful waiting'' policy and operative intervention. Adequate reporting in studies was thus by no means always satisfactory. MINORS scoring highlighted these fact(s) (Fig. 1). Here, we found that little reference was made in many studies as to the nature of cardiac comorbidity(s) and cardiac mortality out with the perioperative period. It is heart anomalies, which most often are the determinant of life expectancy guiding the appropriateness of surgical correction of IRA. All studies included were retrospective observational studies with no valid comparator group (Oxford EBM—Level IV evidence25). As a result, there were some significant inherent bias(s) indicating interpretation of studies with care."
Limitations at the study, outcome, and review level were discussed.
[Yes]

P26
"Although this systematic review favors a ''watchful waiting'' approach over prophylactic surgery in patients with heterotaxy, what exactly this should constitute is not standardized. Those 5 papers advocating a conservative approach of the asymptomatic patients emphasize the need for ''regular'' or ''close'' follow-up, and where this is not possible, or when symptoms develop, imaging is warranted. The frequency of follow-up and the form it takes are not further elaborated however. At our institution, patients are closely monitored by neonatal, surgical, and cardiac specialists during the postnatal admission, but there is no standardized appointment frequency once discharged from hospital inpatient care. An outpatient appointment with a hospital specialist is usually arranged at 6 to 8 weeks after discharge over time, justified by knowledge that incidence of symptomatic IRA decreases with increasing age.26 Choi et al13 highlight the neonatal period as the most dangerous, when inpatient monitoring is typical anyway, and Elder et al16 also emphasize the importance of educating parents, and health care professionals about the clinical features to monitor for. Nevertheless, studies varied in what the authors considered ''symptoms'' of potential IRA. As expected, most authors considered bilious vomiting, bloody stools, abdominal pain, and distension as concerning features, but less distinctive symptoms such as reflux, feeding difficulties, and poor weight gain were only commented upon by a few authors and perhaps because of the retrospective nature of studies, there was no standardized symptom definition given by studies. We agree with Choi et al13 and Papillon et al14 that common but less distinctive symptoms, such as significant gastro-esophageal reflux and feeding difficulties, warrant upper GI imaging."
The results were interpreted in the context of other evidence and implications for future research were discussed.
[Yes]

P27
No relevant quotes found.
Sources of funding for the systematic review were not described.
[No]

llm_message:
A1
Quote: "The study protocol was registered on the PROSPERO international prospective database of systematic reviews (CRD42013003971)."
Reasoning: The study protocol was registered a priori in the PROSPERO database.
[Yes]

A2
Quotes: "Four authors independently undertook literature searches, screened abstracts and assessed articles against eligibility criteria (TPC, HJM). Discrepancies were resolved by discussion with the senior author (AD). Corresponding authors were contacted regarding any missing data. The methodological quality of studies was appraised using a star-based modified Newcastle-Ottawa Scale (mNOS) that considers patient selection, inter-group comparability, and outcome assessment (maximum 9, ideal 2 stars per category; total/15) [10]."
Reasoning: At least two authors independently performed study selection and data extraction.
[Yes]

A3
Quotes: "Systematic literature searches were undertaken of PubMed and EMBASE electronic databases using the following search strategy ("Surgery, Computer-Assisted"[MeSH] OR "robotics"[MeSH] OR "da Vinci" OR "telerobotic" OR "telesurgery" OR "robotic surgery") AND ("Pediatrics"[MeSH] OR "infant"[MeSH] OR "child"[MeSH] OR "adolescent"[MeSH]) AND ("Fundoplication"[MeSH] OR "Gastroesophageal reflux"[MeSH]). The search period was defined as June 2001 to June 2013 inclusively. The primary search was supplemented with searches of 1) PubMed related articles feature, 2) clinicaltrials.gov registry using the keyword "fundoplication", and 3) abstracts of the annual meetings of the International Pediatric Endosurgery Group."
Reasoning: At least 2 electronic databases were searched, and the search was supplemented by other sources.
[Yes]

A4

[Yes]

Quote: "Fig. 1. Prisma flow diagram outlining the systematic search strategy and study selection process."

Reasoning: A modified Newcastle-Ottawa Scale was used to assess study quality and the results are reported in Table 3.

A8
Quote: "Meta-analysis of the current literature identifies comparable safety and short-term efficacy for robot-assisted laparoscopic fundoplication when compared to conventional laparoscopic fundoplication in children. However, there is insufficient evidence to assess comparative effectiveness for important procedure and pathology specific outcome measures such as success rate, post-operative surgery related morbidity and re-operation rates."
Reasoning: The conclusions take into account the limited evidence and insufficient data to comprehensively determine comparative effectiveness, reflecting the quality assessment.

A9
Quotes: "Statistical analysis was conducted using Review Manager® Version 5.1.7 for Windows (The Cochrane Collaboration, Software Update, Oxford, UK) and STATA v.11 statistical analysis software (StataCorp LP, TX, USA). A weighted random-effects model was used for all analyses. Studies were weighted based on sample size and quality of study scoring. Pooled odds ratios (OR) were calculated as the summary statistic for dichotomous variables and weighted mean difference (WMD) calculated for continuous variables. Both OR and WMD are reported with 95% confidence intervals (CI). A P value <0.05 was considered statistically significant. Determination of heterogeneity was undertaken using the χ2 test (Cochran's Q) and I2 value; with I2 ≥ 75% denoting high degree of statistically significant heterogeneity. Risk of publication bias was assessed by visual inspection of funnel plots in addition to statistical estimation with both Begg and Mazumdar's test and Egger's test for small study effects."
Reasoning: Appropriate methods were used to combine the findings, including a random effects model, assessment of heterogeneity, and weighting based on sample size and study quality.

Quote: "Risk of publication bias was assessed by visual inspection of funnel plots in addition to statistical estimation with both Begg and Mazumdar's test and Egger's test for small study effects."

Statistical publication bias assessment of this subgroup was not possible due to the low number of high-quality studies."
Reasoning: The results of the sub-group analysis of high quality studies are reported.

P24
Quote: "Meta-analysis of the current literature identifies comparable safety and short-term efficacy for robot-assisted laparoscopic fundoplication when compared to conventional laparoscopic fundoplication in children. P27
Quote: See reasoning.
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review are not described. The role of funders is not applicable as no funding sources are mentioned.
[No]

[Yes]

[Yes]

llm_message:
A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors do not mention a protocol, ethics approval, or pre-determined objectives.
[No]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
Quotes: "All other manuscripts (e.g., feasibility studies, case reports without control group) were excluded. Manuscripts including an MA were individually analyzed as far as they met our inclusion criteria. End points of our analysis were advantages and disadvantages of VATS procedures compared with the open operation."
Reasoning: The authors do not state that study selection and data extraction were performed in duplicate.
[No]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quotes: "The Web site was last accessed on January 2, 2013." "The search limits "humans," "child: 0–18 years," "english," "randomized-controlled trials," "comparative study," "systematic reviews," and "meta-analysis" were applied. Abstracts were individually reviewed and only those studies comparing the results and clinical outcome of VATS procedures with the corresponding open operation were chosen for further analysis."
Reasoning: The authors searched PubMed and applied relevant search limits, but did not search additional databases or other sources.
[No]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors do not mention including grey literature or unpublished studies.
[No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
Quotes: "A total of 21 manuscripts met the inclusion criteria of our systematic review of which 3 were MA and 18 were RCS. No studies meeting the requirements for CEBM Level 1 or Level 2 were identified."
Reasoning: The authors report the number of included studies but do not provide a list of excluded studies.
[No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quotes: See Table 3 which provides details on study type, CEBM levels, advantages and disadvantages of VATS versus open for each included study.
Reasoning: The authors provide key characteristics of included studies in an aggregated table.
[Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
Quotes: "No studies of CEBM Level 1 or Level 2 were identified. All studies were classified as CEBM Level 3."
Reasoning: The authors assessed study quality using CEBM levels and reported the level for each included study.
[Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
Quotes: "The potential avoidance of rib fusion, scoliosis, and chest wall deformity in the argument for advantage VATS shares with other minimally invasive approaches. Additionally, the potential avoidance of rib fusion, scoliosis, and chest wall deformity make the argument for VATS even more compelling. In a recent follow-up study investigating 62 infants, we have shown that the Manchester Scar Assessment scores and patient's satisfaction were in favor of VATS as compared with the results after thoracotomy."
Reasoning: The authors appropriately consider the low quality evidence (all Level 3) when discussing the potential advantages of VATS and limitations of the evidence.
[Yes]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
[NA] - No meta-analysis was performed.

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
[NA] - No meta-analysis was performed.

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
Quotes: "None."
Reasoning: The authors report no conflicts of interest for the systematic review. However, they do not report the conflicts of interest for each included study.
[No]

P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
Quotes: "Thoracoscopic Procedures in Pediatric Surgery: What is the Evidence?"
Reasoning: The title does not identify the article as a systematic review.
[No]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary
Quotes: The abstract has distinct labeled sections for Introduction, Materials and Methods, Results, and Conclusion.
Reasoning: The abstract is structured with recommended headings.
[Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale
Quotes: "The use of video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) has evolved quickly and it has gained widespread acceptance among pediatric surgeons during the last decade."
Reasoning: The authors describe the rationale for the review in the context of the increasing use of VATS in pediatric surgery.
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives
Quotes: "According to a recent classification of the Oxford Centre for Evidence-Based Medicine (CEBM), studies can be classified into Levels 1 to 5 in order of descending quality. We aimed to identify comparative studies investigating VATS versus open procedures in pediatric surgery and to classify publications according to the CEBM criteria."
Reasoning: The authors clearly state the review objectives and key inclusion criteria (comparative studies of VATS vs open in pediatric surgery).
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors do not mention a review protocol or registration.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria
Quotes: "Only studies published in English, comparing pediatric VATS with the corresponding open operation were included. End points were advantages and disadvantages of VATS as compared with the open procedure. Levels of evidence were determined using the recent CEBM criteria."
Reasoning: The authors specify the inclusion criteria and information used to assess eligibility.
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources
Quotes: "A Medline literature search using PubMed (www.pubmed.com). The Web site was last accessed on January 2, 2013."
Reasoning: The authors name the electronic database searched and the date last searched.
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search
Quotes: "The search limits "humans," "child: 0–18 years," "english," "randomized-controlled trials," "comparative study," "systematic reviews," and "meta-analysis" were applied."
Reasoning: The authors provide the key search limits used, but not the full search strategy.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection
Quotes: "Abstracts were individually reviewed and only those studies comparing the results and clinical outcome of VATS procedures with the corresponding open operation were chosen for further analysis. All other manuscripts (e.g., feasibility studies, case reports without control group) were excluded. Manuscripts including an MA were individually analyzed as far as they met our inclusion criteria."
Reasoning: The authors describe the process for screening abstracts and selecting full-text articles for inclusion.
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors do not describe the method of data extraction.
[No]

P11. Methods / Data items
Quotes: "End points of our analysis were advantages and disadvantages of VATS procedures compared with the open operation."
Reasoning: The authors define the key variables for which data were sought, but do not provide a full list.
[No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies
Quotes: "Levels of evidence were determined using the recent CEBM criteria."
Reasoning: The authors assessed study quality using CEBM levels.
[Yes]

P13. Methods / Summary measures
[NA] - No meta-analysis was performed.

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results
[NA] - No meta-analysis was performed.

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies
[NA] - No meta-analysis was performed.

P16. Methods / Additional analyses
[NA] - No meta-analysis was performed.

P17. Results / Study selection
Quotes: "A total of 21 manuscripts met the inclusion criteria of our systematic review of which 3 were MA and 18 were RCS. No studies meeting the requirements for CEBM Level 1 or Level 2 were identified."
Reasoning: The authors report the number of studies included but do not provide a full PRISMA flow diagram.
[No]

P18. Results / Study characteristics
Quotes: See Table 3 which provides details on study type, CEBM levels, advantages and disadvantages of VATS versus open for each included study.
Reasoning: The authors provide a table of key characteristics for each included study.
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies
Quotes: "No studies of CEBM Level 1 or Level 2 were identified. All studies were classified as CEBM Level 3."
Reasoning: The authors report the CEBM quality level for each included study.
[Yes]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies
Quotes: See Table 3 which summarizes the advantages and disadvantages of VATS versus open approach for each included study.
Reasoning: The authors provide a summary of results for each included study in a table.
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results
[NA] - No meta-analysis was performed.

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies
[NA] - No meta-analysis was performed.

P23. Results / Additional analysis
[NA] - No meta-analysis was performed.

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence
Quotes: "The potential avoidance of rib fusion, scoliosis, and chest wall deformity in the argument for advantage VATS shares with other minimally invasive approaches. Additionally, the potential avoidance of rib fusion, scoliosis, and chest wall deformity make the argument for VATS even more compelling."
Reasoning: The authors summarize the main findings on advantages of VATS over open procedures.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
Quotes: "Irrespective of the medical subspecialty, the employment of evidence-based medicine whenever possible is regarded as the most effective vehicle to achieve more efficient care. Evidence-based medicine is defined as the conscientious, explicit, and judicious use of current best evidence in making decisions about the care of individual patients. The practice of evidencebased medicine means integrating individual clinical expertise with the best available external clinical evidence from systematic research."
Reasoning: The authors discuss limitations of the evidence base for pediatric VATS, noting the lack of high-quality studies.
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
Quotes: "Except from one preliminary study and a most recently published pilot study, only RCS on pediatric VATS are available for five different types of procedures. Therefore, the best available evidence according to the CEBM criteria is Level 3. Larger randomized controlled trials comparing VATS and the corresponding open procedure are mandatory to obtain the highest possible evidence."
Reasoning: The authors provide general conclusions in the context of the low quality of available evidence.
[Yes]

P27. Funding
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors do not report sources of funding for the systematic review.
[No]

Quotes: "The potential avoidance of rib fusion, scoliosis, and chest wall deformity in the argument for advantage VATS shares with other minimally invasive approaches. Additionally, the potential avoidance of rib fusion, scoliosis, and chest wall deformity make the argument for VATS even more compelling."
Reasoning: The authors summarize the main findings on advantages of VATS over open procedures.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
Quotes: "Irrespective of the medical subspecialty, the employment of evidence-based medicine whenever possible is regarded as the most effective vehicle to achieve more efficient care. Evidence-based medicine is defined as the conscientious, explicit, and judicious use of current best evidence in making decisions about the care of individual patients. The practice of evidencebased medicine means integrating individual clinical expertise with the best available external clinical evidence from systematic research."
Reasoning: The authors discuss limitations of the evidence base for pediatric VATS, noting the lack of high-quality studies.
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
Quotes: "Except from one preliminary study and a most recently published pilot study, only RCS on pediatric VATS are available for five different types of procedures. Therefore, the best available evidence according to the CEBM criteria is Level 3. Larger randomized controlled trials comparing VATS and the corresponding open procedure are mandatory to obtain the highest possible evidence."
Reasoning: The authors provide general conclusions in the context of the low quality of available evidence.
[Yes]

P27. Funding
Quotes: None relevant.
Reasoning: The authors do not report sources of funding for the systematic review.
[No]

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
"The aim of our study was to evaluate the availability of Level 1 studies comparing laparoscopic procedures with the corresponding open operation in pediatric surgery."
The aim of the study was stated, but no mention of a protocol, ethics approval, or pre-determined objectives.
[No]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
"MA and RCT were identified and individually reviewed. Only studies comparing pediatric laparoscopic procedures with the corresponding open operation were included. RCTs included in MA were only individually analyzed if they focused on additional endpoints."
Two reviewers independently selected studies, but no mention of duplicate data extraction or a consensus procedure.
[No]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
"Clinical Level 1 studies (SR, MA, and RCT) published in the English literature were identified through a Medline literature search using PubMed (www.pubmed.com). The Web site was last accessed on May 5, 2012. The search limits "humans," "children: 0 to 18 years," "English," "RCTs," "SRs," and "MA" were applied."
Only one database (PubMed) was searched. No additional sources or supplementary strategies were mentioned.
[No]

No mention of including grey literature or unpublished studies.

[No]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Table 3 provides details on the included studies, including procedure type, study type, level of evidence, advantages and disadvantages.
[Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
"The authors aim to line out that it is neither their aim to condemn the evolving techniques in laparoscopic pediatric surgery nor the principles of evidence-based medicine. Keeping in mind using the current best evidence in the cornerstones of evidence-based medicine, our plea for high level evidence shall, however, not discourage pediatric surgeons to take advantage of low level evidence studies for laparoscopic procedures according to the CEBM."
The scientific quality of included studies was not formally assessed. The authors acknowledge the limitations of low level evidence but do not provide a quality assessment of individual studies.
[No]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
Not applicable as the scientific quality of included studies was not assessed.
[NA]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
No quantitative synthesis was performed. The results of individual studies were described narratively.
[NA]

No assessment of publication bias was reported.
[No]

The systematic review states "Conflict of Interest: None". However, no information on conflicts of interest was provided for the individual included studies.
[No]

The study selection process is described.

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies

"The most effective vehicle to bring more efficient care is the employment of evidence-based medicine whenever possible. Evidence-based medicine is the conscientious, explicit, and judicious use of current best evidence in making decisions about the care of individual patients."
The main findings are summarized, though without explicit reference to the strength of evidence for each outcome.
[No]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
"Some of these obstacles may be overcome by the implementation of multicenter studies. However, this will require significant resources and institutional and individual collaboration."
Some limitations are acknowledged, but not systematically at the study, outcome, and review levels.
[No]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
"Studies meeting the CEBM criteria for Level 1 are available for only seven laparoscopic pediatric surgical procedures. Effort has to be made to extend the existing Level 1 evidence and to gain high level evidence for further laparoscopic procedures in pediatric surgery."
The conclusions provide a general interpretation and implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27. Funding
No sources of funding or support for the systematic review are reported.
[No]

llm_message:
Here is the assessment of the systematic review using AMSTAR and PRISMA:

A1
Quote: "We planned to assess risk of bias using the Cochrane risk of bias tool (Higgins 2011a; Higgins 2011b). We applied the following criteria."
Reasoning: The review specified the risk of bias criteria a priori.
[Yes]

A2
Quote: "Two review authors (LJE, KR) independently assessed the risk of bias of each included study. Possible disagreements were resolved by consensus, or by consultation with a third review author (EM)."
Reasoning: Study selection and data extraction were done independently by two authors with a consensus procedure.
[Yes]

A3
Quotes: "We searched the Cochrane Library, MEDLINE, PubMed (subsets not available on Ovid), EMBASE, LILACS, ICTRP, ClinicalTrials.gov."
"We tried to identify other potentially eligible trials or ancillary publications by searching the reference lists of retrieved included trials, systematic reviews, meta-analyses and health technology assessment reports."
Reasoning: At least two electronic databases and supplementary sources were searched.
[Yes]

A4
Quote: "We evaluated whether imbalances in baseline characteristics existed and how these were addressed (Egbewale 2014; Corbett 2013)."
Reasoning: Baseline imbalances suggest inclusion of unpublished studies, but this was not explicitly stated.
[No]

A5
Quote: "A list of included and excluded studies should be provided. Note: Acceptable if the excluded studies are referenced. If there is an electronic link to the list but the link is dead, select "no.""
Reasoning: A list of included studies was provided in the Characteristics of included studies table, but excluded studies were not listed or referenced.
[No]

A6
Quote: "For a detailed description of studies, see Characteristics of included studies, Characteristics of excluded studies, and Characteristics of ongoing studies."
Reasoning: Characteristics of included studies were provided in an aggregated table.
[Yes]

A7
Quote: "We assessed the impact of individual bias domains on study results at endpoint and study level."
Reasoning: The review assessed risk of bias in the included studies using the Cochrane risk of bias tool.
[Yes]

A8
Quote: "The results of the methodological rigor and scientific quality should be considered in the analysis and the conclusions of the review, and explicitly stated in formulating recommendations. Note: Might say something such as "the results should be interpreted with caution due to poor quality of included studies." Cannot score "yes" for this question if scored "no" for question 7."
Reasoning: The review considered risk of bias when interpreting results, for example: "Bias for subjective measures (health-related quality of life) was considered high as blinding of participants and personnel was not possible given the nature of this study. Whilst the impact of no blinding on performance bias was judged to be unclear for objectively measured outcomes, it was judged to be a potentially high risk for the subjectively reported health-related quality of life measures."
[Yes]

A9
Quote: "If more than one paper had been identified and substantial clinical, methodological or statistical heterogeneity had been identified, we would not have reported pooled effect estimates."
Reasoning: The review planned to assess heterogeneity if more than one study was found, but this was not applicable as only one study was included.
[NA]

A10
Reasoning: Assessment of publication bias was not mentioned and was not applicable as there was only one included study.
[NA]

A11
Quote: "We would like to thank Leanne Mohan (Teesside University) and Gudrun Paletta (Cochrane Metabolic and Endocrine Disorders Group) for helping with review management."
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review were acknowledged, but not for the included study.
[No]

P1
Quote: "Surgery for the treatment of obesity in children and adolescents (Review)"
Reasoning: The title identifies the report as a systematic review.
[Yes]

P2
Reasoning: The review provided a structured abstract with labeled sections covering the background, objectives, search methods, selection criteria, data collection and analysis, main results, and authors' conclusions.
[Yes]

P3
Quote: "Childhood and adolescent overweight and obesity have increased globally, and are associated with significant short and long term health consequences."
Reasoning: The introduction described the rationale for the review in the context of the increasing prevalence and health consequences of childhood obesity.
[Yes] 

P4
Quote: "To assess the effects of surgical interventions for treating obesity in childhood and adolescence."
Reasoning: The objectives clearly stated the review question in terms of the population, intervention, and outcomes.
[Yes]

P5
Reasoning: The review did not mention a published protocol or registration number.
[No]

P6
Quote: "We selected randomised controlled trials (RCTs) of surgical interventions for treating obesity in children and adolescents (age < 18 years) with a minimum of six months follow-up."
Reasoning: The eligibility criteria in terms of study design, population, intervention, and follow-up duration were specified.
[Yes]

P7
Quote: "We searched the Cochrane Library, MEDLINE, PubMed, EMBASE as well as LILACS, ICTRP Search Portal and ClinicalTrials.gov (all from database inception to March 2015). References of identified studies and systematic reviews were checked. No language restrictions were applied."
Reasoning: The information sources searched and dates of coverage were described.
[Yes]

P8
Reasoning: The full search strategies for the databases were not presented.
[No]

P9
Quote: "Two review authors independently assessed risk of bias and extracted data. Where necessary authors were contacted for additional information."
Reasoning: The process of study selection by two independent authors was described.
[Yes]

P10
Quote: "Two review authors independently assessed risk of bias and extracted data. Where necessary authors were contacted for additional information."
Reasoning: The data extraction process by two independent authors was described, including contacting study authors for more information if needed.
[Yes]

P11
Quote: "We defined the following outcomes as self-reported outcomes. BMI and weight loss, if measured by participants. Adverse events, if reported by participants. Health-related quality of life and self esteem. Participants views of the intervention. Behaviour change."
Reasoning: The data items collected were listed and defined.
[Yes]

P12
Quote: "Two review authors (LJE, KR) independently assessed the risk of bias of each included study. Possible disagreements were resolved by consensus, or by consultation with a third review author (EM). In cases of disagreement, the rest of the group was consulted and a judgement was made based on consensus."
Reasoning: The methods for assessing risk of bias using the Cochrane risk of bias tool were described.
[Yes]

P13
Reasoning: The review did not mention any principal summary measures, as no quantitative synthesis was performed.
[NA]

P14
Reasoning: The methods of combining results were not applicable as no meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P15
Reasoning: Assessment of risk of bias across studies like publication bias was not mentioned and was not applicable with only one included study.
[NA]

P16
Quote: "We planned to carry out the following subgroup analyses and wanted to investigate interaction. Length of follow-up. Impact and nature of maintenance periods. The impact of comparator or control: whether concomitant therapy or no treatment (true control). The impact of population demographics."
Reasoning: Planned subgroup analyses were described, although they were not applicable as only one study was included.
[Yes]

P17
Quote: "The initial search on 30 March 2015 identified 2405 records (2290 from database searches and 115 from trial registry searches); from these, 11 full text publications and protocols were identified for further examination and four trials met the inclusion criteria for ongoing studies. We excluded the other studies because they did not meet the inclusion criteria or were not relevant to the question under study (see Figure 1 for the amended PRISMA (preferred reporting items for systematic reviews and meta-analyses) flow diagram). After screening the full text of the selected publications, one study (one publication) met the inclusion criteria. All studies were published in English."
Reasoning: The number of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, included and excluded were reported with reasons and a PRISMA flow diagram.
[Yes]

P18
Quote: "For a detailed description of studies, see Characteristics of included studies, Characteristics of excluded studies, and Characteristics of ongoing studies."
Reasoning: Characteristics of the one included study were presented.
[Yes]

P19
Quote: "Risk of bias summary: review authors' judgements about each risk of bias item for each included study (blank cells indicate that the study did not measure that particular outcome)."
Reasoning: A risk of bias summary figure showing review authors' judgements for each risk of bias domain was provided.
[Yes]

P20
Quote: "The one included study assessed 50 participants, and reported data for all primary and some secondary endpoints. All cause mortality, behaviour change, participants views of the intervention, socioeconomic effects and costs were not reported in this study."
Reasoning: Outcome data for the one included study were reported.
[Yes]

P21
Reasoning: Presentation of meta-analysis results was not applicable as no meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P22
Reasoning: Presentation of risk of bias across studies was not applicable as there was only one included study.
[NA]

P23
Reasoning: No additional analyses were reported.
[No]

P24
Quote: "This review reports the findings from one RCT (50 participants). The intervention focused on laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding surgery, which was compared to a control group receiving a multi component lifestyle program. The study authors were unable to blind their participants, personnel and outcome assessors which may have resulted in a high risk of performance and detection bias. At 24 months follow-up, the mean change in BMI units was 12.7 (95% CI 11.3 to 14.2) in the surgery group compared to 1.3 (95% CI 0.4 to 2.9) in the control group. Adverse events were reported in 12/25 participants in the intervention group compared to 11/25 in the control group."
Reasoning: The main findings and strength of evidence were summarized.
[Yes]

P25
Quote: "Our results are limited to two years of follow-up and are based on just one small Australian study with some risk of bias which was conducted in a private hospital, receiving funding from the gastric banding manufacturer. There is currently insufficient evidence to make an informed judgement about efficacy. Whilst an in-house economic evaluation was undertaken with due diligence, it is not viewed as a quick fix to weight loss but should be undertaken with due consideration required for the bespoke needs of an adolescent population."
Reasoning: Limitations at the study level (risk of bias, insufficient data) and review level (one small study) were discussed.
[Yes]

P26
Quote: "This systematic review highlights the lack of randomised controlled trials in this field. More high quality studies are required to assess the efficacy of bariatric surgery for the treatment of paediatric obesity and adolescents. The four ongoing studies, once completed, will provide additional evidence on bioenteric intragastric balloon and gastric bypass as alternative procedures in Australian and Swedish adolescents respectively, with two further European studies examining gastric banding. It is important for this research to address clinical effectiveness across a range of populations, including participants ranging in socio-demographics, ethnicity, baseline weight status and geography. Future studies should assess the impact of the surgical procedure and post operative care to minimise adverse events, including the need for post operative adjustments and revisional surgery. Long term follow-up is also critical to comprehensively assess the impact of surgery as participants enter adulthood."
Reasoning: The authors provided a general interpretation of the results in the context of the evidence base and implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27
Quote: "We would like to thank Leanne Mohan (Teesside University) and Gudrun Paletta (Cochrane Metabolic and Endocrine Disorders Group) for helping with review management."
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review were described, but not the role of the funders.
[No]

In summary, this systematic review met most of the AMSTAR quality criteria, except for not searching for grey literature, providing a list of excluded studies, mentioning the sources of funding for the included study, and assessing publication bias. For PRISMA reporting items, most were adequately addressed, with some exceptions like not presenting the full search strategies, a published protocol, and describing funding sources.

Reasoning: The objectives clearly stated the review question in terms of the population, intervention, and outcomes.
[Yes]

P5
Reasoning: The review did not mention a published protocol or registration number.
[No]

P6
Quote: "We selected randomised controlled trials (RCTs) of surgical interventions for treating obesity in children and adolescents (age < 18 years) with a minimum of six months follow-up."
Reasoning: The eligibility criteria in terms of study design, population, intervention, and follow-up duration were specified.
[Yes]

P7
Quote: "We searched the Cochrane Library, MEDLINE, PubMed, EMBASE as well as LILACS, ICTRP Search Portal and ClinicalTrials.gov (all from database inception to March 2015). References of identified studies and systematic reviews were checked. No language restrictions were applied."
Reasoning: The information sources searched and dates of coverage were described.
[Yes]

P8
Reasoning: The full search strategies for the databases were not presented.
[No]

P9
Quote: "Two review authors independently assessed risk of bias and extracted data. Where necessary authors were contacted for additional information."
Reasoning: The process of study selection by two independent authors was described.
[Yes]

P10
Quote: "Two review authors independently assessed risk of bias and extracted data. Where necessary authors were contacted for additional information."
Reasoning: The data extraction process by two independent authors was described, including contacting study authors for more information if needed.
[Yes]

P11
Quote: "We defined the following outcomes as self-reported outcomes. BMI and weight loss, if measured by participants. Adverse events, if reported by participants. Health-related quality of life and self esteem. Participants views of the intervention. Behaviour change."
Reasoning: The data items collected were listed and defined.
[Yes]

P12
Quote: "Two review authors (LJE, KR) independently assessed the risk of bias of each included study. Possible disagreements were resolved by consensus, or by consultation with a third review author (EM). In cases of disagreement, the rest of the group was consulted and a judgement was made based on consensus."
Reasoning: The methods for assessing risk of bias using the Cochrane risk of bias tool were described.
[Yes]

P13
Reasoning: The review did not mention any principal summary measures, as no quantitative synthesis was performed.
[NA]

P14
Reasoning: The methods of combining results were not applicable as no meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P15
Reasoning: Assessment of risk of bias across studies like publication bias was not mentioned and was not applicable with only one included study.
[NA]

P16
Quote: "We planned to carry out the following subgroup analyses and wanted to investigate interaction. Length of follow-up. Impact and nature of maintenance periods. The impact of comparator or control: whether concomitant therapy or no treatment (true control). The impact of population demographics."
Reasoning: Planned subgroup analyses were described, although they were not applicable as only one study was included.
[Yes]

P17
Quote: "The initial search on 30 March 2015 identified 2405 records (2290 from database searches and 115 from trial registry searches); from these, 11 full text publications and protocols were identified for further examination and four trials met the inclusion criteria for ongoing studies. We excluded the other studies because they did not meet the inclusion criteria or were not relevant to the question under study (see Figure 1 for the amended PRISMA (preferred reporting items for systematic reviews and meta-analyses) flow diagram). After screening the full text of the selected publications, one study (one publication) met the inclusion criteria. All studies were published in English."
Reasoning: The number of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, included and excluded were reported with reasons and a PRISMA flow diagram.
[Yes]

P18
Quote: "For a detailed description of studies, see Characteristics of included studies, Characteristics of excluded studies, and Characteristics of ongoing studies."
Reasoning: Characteristics of the one included study were presented.
[Yes]

P19
Quote: "Risk of bias summary: review authors' judgements about each risk of bias item for each included study (blank cells indicate that the study did not measure that particular outcome)."
Reasoning: A risk of bias summary figure showing review authors' judgements for each risk of bias domain was provided.
[Yes]

P20
Quote: "The one included study assessed 50 participants, and reported data for all primary and some secondary endpoints. All cause mortality, behaviour change, participants views of the intervention, socioeconomic effects and costs were not reported in this study."
Reasoning: Outcome data for the one included study were reported.
[Yes]

P21
Reasoning: Presentation of meta-analysis results was not applicable as no meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P22
Reasoning: Presentation of risk of bias across studies was not applicable as there was only one included study.
[NA]

P23
Reasoning: No additional analyses were reported.
[No]

P24
Quote: "This review reports the findings from one RCT (50 participants). The intervention focused on laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding surgery, which was compared to a control group receiving a multi component lifestyle program. The study authors were unable to blind their participants, personnel and outcome assessors which may have resulted in a high risk of performance and detection bias. At 24 months follow-up, the mean change in BMI units was 12.7 (95% CI 11.3 to 14.2) in the surgery group compared to 1.3 (95% CI 0.4 to 2.9) in the control group. Adverse events were reported in 12/25 participants in the intervention group compared to 11/25 in the control group."
Reasoning: The main findings and strength of evidence were summarized.
[Yes]

P25
Quote: "Our results are limited to two years of follow-up and are based on just one small Australian study with some risk of bias which was conducted in a private hospital, receiving funding from the gastric banding manufacturer. There is currently insufficient evidence to make an informed judgement about efficacy. Whilst an in-house economic evaluation was undertaken with due diligence, it is not viewed as a quick fix to weight loss but should be undertaken with due consideration required for the bespoke needs of an adolescent population."
Reasoning: Limitations at the study level (risk of bias, insufficient data) and review level (one small study) were discussed.
[Yes]

P26
Quote: "This systematic review highlights the lack of randomised controlled trials in this field. More high quality studies are required to assess the efficacy of bariatric surgery for the treatment of paediatric obesity and adolescents. The four ongoing studies, once completed, will provide additional evidence on bioenteric intragastric balloon and gastric bypass as alternative procedures in Australian and Swedish adolescents respectively, with two further European studies examining gastric banding. It is important for this research to address clinical effectiveness across a range of populations, including participants ranging in socio-demographics, ethnicity, baseline weight status and geography. Future studies should assess the impact of the surgical procedure and post operative care to minimise adverse events, including the need for post operative adjustments and revisional surgery. Long term follow-up is also critical to comprehensively assess the impact of surgery as participants enter adulthood."
Reasoning: The authors provided a general interpretation of the results in the context of the evidence base and implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27
Quote: "We would like to thank Leanne Mohan (Teesside University) and Gudrun Paletta (Cochrane Metabolic and Endocrine Disorders Group) for helping with review management."
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review were described, but not the role of the funders.
[No]

In summary, this systematic review met most of the AMSTAR quality criteria, except for not searching for grey literature, providing a list of excluded studies, mentioning the sources of funding for the included study, and assessing publication bias. For PRISMA reporting items, most were adequately addressed, with some exceptions like not presenting the full search strategies, a published protocol, and describing funding sources.

llm_message:
A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
Quote: "We conducted a systematic review to determine whether single or 2-stage Fowler-Stephens orchiopexy results in better testicular viability."
Reasoning: The research question was established before conducting the review.
[Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
Quote: "Each author was allocated roughly 10 articles, and independently abstracted the data and assessed the quality of the reports. Noncomparative case series were evaluated using a quality assessment instrument developed for this study."
Reasoning: Data extraction was done independently by each author.
[Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
Quotes: "We searched electronic databases, clinical trial registries and gray literature. We included reports describing boys younger than 18 years with a primary outcome of "testicular viability and position." We performed a meta-analysis using random effects models."
Reasoning: Multiple electronic databases and other sources were searched.
[Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
Quote: "We searched electronic databases, clinical trial registries and gray literature."
Reasoning: A search for gray literature was performed.
[Yes]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
Quote: "A total of 1,807 potentially relevant articles were retrieved from the initial electronic database search and an additional 13 studies from the gray literature search. After a thorough assessment 99 articles underwent a full review for evaluation of quality and 61 articles were included in the review (fig. 1)."
Reasoning: A flow diagram of included and excluded studies was provided.
[Yes]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
Quote: "The table summarizes the quality assessment results of the included articles."
Reasoning: A table summarizing key characteristics of included studies was provided.
[Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
Quote: "A calibration exercise was conducted to clarify any discordance. Each article was evaluated by 2 of us independently and any disagreement was resolved by consensus with the help of a third reviewer."
Reasoning: The quality of included studies was assessed using a quality assessment instrument.
[Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
Quotes: "Although the rate of testicular survival is statistically significant in favor of the 2-stage procedure, a significant number were unclear about issues such as intraoperative testicular position, statistical analysis used and complications. Sample sizes were generally small, and no sample size calculations were reported."
Reasoning: Limitations in study quality were considered when drawing conclusions.
[Yes]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
Quote: "We performed a meta-analysis using random effects models. Heterogeneity was assessed using I2 statistic."
Reasoning: Appropriate methods were used to combine study findings and assess heterogeneity.
[Yes]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
Quote: "The funnel plot demonstrated a roughly symmetrical distribution around the mean effect, suggesting no publication bias."
Reasoning: A funnel plot was used to assess publication bias.
[Yes]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
Quotes: Not found
Reasoning: Sources of support for the systematic review and included studies were not clearly reported.
[No]

P1. Title
Quote: "Is Staging Beneficial for Fowler-Stephens Orchiopexy? A Systematic Review"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review.
[Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary
Quote: The abstract contains labeled sections for Purpose, Materials and Methods, Results, and Conclusions.
Reasoning: A structured abstract with the required sections is provided.
[Yes]  

P3. Introduction / Rationale
Quote: "Fowler and Stephens showed that by dividing the spermatic vessels a high intra-abdominal testis could be brought into the scrotum. This particular approach carries a potential complication of this technique."
Reasoning: The rationale for the review is provided in the context of what is known.
[Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives
Quote: "We conducted a systematic review to determine whether single or 2-stage Fowler-Stephens orchiopexy results in better testicular viability."
Reasoning: An explicit statement of the review question is provided.
[Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration
Quotes: Not found
Reasoning: No mention of a review protocol or registration number.
[No]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria
Quote: "Studies were considered relevant if they met the following inclusion criteria. Patients were younger than 18 years, had an intra-abdominal testis, had undergone single or 2-stage FSO (open or laparoscopic), and had data regarding testicular position and postoperative testicular viability."
Reasoning: Study eligibility criteria are specified.
[Yes]

P7. Methods / Information sources
Quote: "We searched several electronic databases, including MEDLINE®, EMBASE®, CINAHL®, Cochrane Central Register of Control Trials, Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, Database of Abstracts of Reviews of Effects and ACP Journal Club®."
Reasoning: Electronic databases and other information sources are described.
[Yes]

P8. Methods / Search
Quotes: Not found
Reasoning: The full search strategy is not presented.
[No]

P9. Methods / Study selection
Quote: "The search strategy used in MEDLINE (Ovid interface) was Fowler Stephens.mp.; orchidopexy.mp.; orchiopexy.mp.; Laparoscopy [Abnormalities, Adverse Effects, Classification, Standards, Statistics and Numerical Data, Surgery, Methods, Trends, Utilization].; or/1-4.; Cryptorchid$.mp.; Undescended test$.mp.;"
Reasoning: The process for selecting studies is described.
[Yes]

P10. Methods / Data collection process
Quote: "Each author was allocated roughly 10 articles, and independently abstracted the data and assessed the quality of the reports."
Reasoning: The method of data extraction is described.
[Yes]

P11. Methods / Data items
Quotes: Not found
Reasoning: Variables for which data were sought are not explicitly defined.
[No]

P12. Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies
Quote: "Noncomparative case series were evaluated using a quality assessment instrument developed for this study. A calibration exercise was conducted to clarify any discordance. Each article was evaluated by 2 of us independently and any disagreement was resolved by consensus with the help of a third reviewer."
Reasoning: Methods for assessing risk of bias in individual studies are described.
[Yes]

P13. Methods / Summary measures
Quotes: Not found
Reasoning: The principal summary measures are not explicitly stated.
[No]

P14. Methods / Synthesis of results
Quote: "We performed a meta-analysis using random effects models."
Reasoning: The methods for combining study results are described.
[Yes]

P15. Methods / Risk of bias across studies
Quotes: Not found
Reasoning: Methods for assessing risk of bias across studies are not specified.
[No]

P16. Methods / Additional analyses
Quotes: Not found
Reasoning: No additional analyses are mentioned.
[NA]

P17. Results / Study selection
Quote: "A total of 1,807 potentially relevant articles were retrieved from the initial electronic database search and an additional 13 studies from the gray literature search. After a thorough assessment 99 articles underwent a full review for evaluation of quality and 61 articles were included in the review (fig. 1)."
Reasoning: The number of studies at each stage of selection is reported, with a flow diagram.
[Yes]

P18. Results / Study characteristics
Quote: "The table summarizes the quality assessment results of the included articles."
Reasoning: A table of study characteristics is provided.
[Yes]

P19. Results / Risk of bias within studies
Quotes: Not found
Reasoning: Results of the risk of bias assessment for each study are not presented.
[No]

P20. Results / Results of individual studies
Quote: "The forest plot demonstrates success rates of individual studies and pooled estimate success rate of 80% (95% CI 75 to 86) for single stage FSO with I2 of 11%."
Reasoning: A forest plot of individual study results is provided.
[Yes]

P21. Results / Synthesis of results
Quote: "The pooled estimate of success rates was 80% for single stage Fowler-Stephens orchiopexy (95% CI 75 to 86) and 85% for 2-stage Fowler-Stephens orchiopexy (95% CI 81 to 90). The pooled odds ratio of single stage vs 2-stage Fowler-Stephens orchiopexy was 2.0 (95% CI 1.1 to 3.9) favoring the 2-stage procedure."
Reasoning: Meta-analysis results with confidence intervals are reported.
[Yes]

P22. Results / Risk of bias across studies
Quotes: Not found
Reasoning: Results of the assessment of risk of bias across studies are not presented.
[No]

P23. Results / Additional analysis
Quotes: Not found
Reasoning: No additional analyses were mentioned in the methods.
[NA]

P24. Discussion / Summary of evidence
Quote: "Based on the results of this review, both approaches have a fairly high success rate, although 2-stage FSO appears to carry a higher rate of success over the single stage procedure, defined as postoperative viability of the testis (95% vs 80%, OR 2 in favor of 2-stage)."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized.
[Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations
Quote: "Although laparoscopy allows for more precise dissection of the spermatic vessels, there was no statistical difference in success rates between open and laparoscopic FSO in either single or 2-stage techniques. The overall quality of the reports was average, and although most studies described the surgical technique and postoperative position of the testis, a significant number were unclear about issues such as intraoperative testicular position, statistical analysis used and complications."
Reasoning: Limitations at the study and review level are discussed.
[Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions
Quote: "Based on the results of this review, both approaches have a fairly high success rate, although 2-stage FSO appears to carry a higher rate of success over the single stage procedure, defined as postoperative viability of the testis (95% vs 80%, OR 2 in favor of 2-stage). There was no difference in success rates between laparoscopic and open techniques."
Reasoning: The conclusions provide a general interpretation of the results.
[Yes]

P27. Funding
Quotes: Not found
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review are not described.
[No]
