llm_message:
A1
Quote: "All published articles until August 31, 2010 were searched with the terms "laparoscopic orchiopexy", "open orchiopexy", and "children" from Medline (using PubMed as the search engine), Embase, Ovid, Web of Science, and Cochrane databases."
Reasoning: The authors specified the databases and search terms used, indicating an a priori design.
[Yes]

A2
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors did not mention any independent screening or data extraction.
[No]

A3
Quote: "All published articles until August 31, 2010 were searched with the terms "laparoscopic orchiopexy", "open orchiopexy", and "children" from Medline (using PubMed as the search engine), Embase, Ovid, Web of Science, and Cochrane databases. No lower date limit was applied. After identifying relevant titles, the abstracts of these studies were read to decide if the study was eligible."
Reasoning: The authors searched multiple databases and provided the search terms used.
[Yes]

A4
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors did not specify whether they searched for grey literature.
[No]

A5
Quote: "After screening 129 abstracts, 97 studies were excluded due to review article or reports in adult. The number of studies was reduced to 97 by limiting the laparoscopic management of NPT in children with the keywords "laparoscopy", "non-palpable testis", and "children"."
Reasoning: The authors provided the number of excluded studies but did not provide a list of the excluded studies.
[No]

A6
Quote: "Two hundred and twenty-six studies were initially found to report the laparoscopy in the management of NPT using the keywords "laparoscopy" and "non-palpable testis". Two hundred and three were published as complete manuscripts and 23 as abstracts."
Reasoning: The authors provided aggregate information on the included studies.
[Yes]

A7
Quote: "Each included article was appraised by three reviewers (GJ, LZL and TQS), who assessed the methodological quality of the selected studies independently. A critical review checklist of the Dutch Cochrane Centre was used to appraise the RCTs [de-Cochrane-centrum.nl, Last updated July 2010]. This checklist was also considered valid to assess the quality of non-RCTs."
Reasoning: The authors used a checklist to independently assess the methodological quality of included studies.
[Yes]

A8
Quote: "Precise localization of the undescended testis has long been considered mandatory before performing any surgical procedure [18]. Traditionally, an intra-abdominal testis has been managed through an open-groin exploration, followed by an extensive retroperitoneal dissection or laparotomy [19]."
Reasoning: The authors considered the methodological quality when formulating conclusions.
[Yes]

A9
Quote: "Statistical analyses were performed using the Review Manager 4.2.10 Software (The Cochrane Collaboration, Oxford, UK). Statistical heterogeneity was assessed using the I2 statistics. If the I2 value was less than 50%, a fixed effects meta-analysis was applied; if the I2 value was 50% or more, the random effects meta-analysis was used [16, 17]."
Reasoning: The authors used appropriate methods to combine the findings based on assessment of heterogeneity.
[Yes]

A10
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors did not assess the likelihood of publication bias.
[No]

A11
Quote: "Conflict of interest None."
Reasoning: The authors declared no conflict of interest for the systematic review but did not report the conflicts of interest of the included studies.
[No]

P1
Quote: "Laparoscopic versus open orchiopexy for non-palpable undescended testes in children: a systemic review and meta-analysis"
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
[Yes]

P2
Quote: See structured abstract on page 1.
Reasoning: The article provides a structured abstract with labeled sections covering the main PRISMA elements.
[Yes]

P3
Quote: "The undescended testes (cryptorchidism) is one of the most common disorders of childhood, affecting 0.8–1.8% of infants at 1 year of age, 3% of full-term newborns, and 21% of premature babies [1, 2]. Approximate 20% of these cases represent non-palpable testes (NPT) that can be abdominal (normal or dysgenetic and high or low), intracanalicular, ectopic, or absent (true monorchia or vanishing testes) [1]. It has been established that abdominal testes may be associated with an increased risk of infertility and cancer [3, 4]."
Reasoning: The introduction describes the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known about undescended testes.
[Yes]

P4
Quote: "So far, only a few reports compared the laparoscopic and open inguinal approach in the management of NPT in children [3, 5, 9–14]. Due to the variations in patients' demography and methodologies, it is difficult to draw the conclusion regarding the benefits of laparoscopy in the treatment of NPT."
Reasoning: The introduction states the review questions and mentions the PICO elements of participants (children with NPT), interventions (laparoscopy), and comparisons (open surgery).
[Yes]

P5
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors did not mention a protocol or registration number.
[No]

P6
Quote: "Eleven of these studies were subsequently excluded for only comparing the diagnosis of NPT, leaving 2 RCTs and 5 observational clinical studies (OCSs) for systematic review [5, 9–14] (Fig. 1). A summary of the studies' methodology, intervention characteristics, and measured outcomes was provided in Tables 1 and 2, including 176 cases of LO and 263 cases of OO."
Reasoning: The authors specified the study characteristics and report characteristics used as eligibility criteria.
[Yes]

P7
Quote: "All published articles until August 31, 2010 were searched with the terms "laparoscopic orchiopexy", "open orchiopexy", and "children" from Medline (using PubMed as the search engine), Embase, Ovid, Web of Science, and Cochrane databases. No lower date limit was applied."
Reasoning: The authors described the information sources searched and the date of last search.
[Yes]

P8
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors did not present the full electronic search strategy for any database.
[No]

P9
Quote: "After identifying relevant titles, the abstracts of these studies were read to decide if the study was eligible. Abstracts subsequently published as articles were excluded from this group to avoid counting of results twice. The full article was retrieved when the information in the title and/or abstract appeared to meet the objective of this review."
Reasoning: The authors described the process for selecting studies.
[Yes]

P10
Quote: "Three reviewers (GJ, LZL and TQS) independently assessed selected studies, extracted data from each article with a predefined data extraction form. Data regarding the following factors were considered: first author, study duration, methodology, participant features, intervention characteristics, and outcome measures."
Reasoning: The authors described the method of data extraction.
[Yes]

P11
Quote: "Data regarding the following factors were considered: first author, study duration, methodology, participant features, intervention characteristics, and outcome measures."
Reasoning: The authors listed the data items sought.
[Yes]

P12
Quote: "Each included article was appraised by three reviewers (GJ, LZL and TQS), who assessed the methodological quality of the selected studies independently. A critical review checklist of the Dutch Cochrane Centre was used to appraise the RCTs [de-Cochrane-centrum.nl, Last updated July 2010]. This checklist was also considered valid to assess the quality of non-RCTs."
Reasoning: The authors described the methods used to assess risk of bias in the individual studies.
[Yes]

P13
Quote: "Weighted mean differences (WMDs) and ORs were used for the continuous and dichotomous outcome variables, respectively."
Reasoning: The authors stated the principal summary measures.
[Yes]

P14
Quote: "Statistical analyses were performed using the Review Manager 4.2.10 Software (The Cochrane Collaboration, Oxford, UK). Statistical heterogeneity was assessed using the I2 statistics. If the I2 value was less than 50%, a fixed effects meta-analysis was applied; if the I2 value was 50% or more, the random effects meta-analysis was used [16, 17]."
Reasoning: The authors described the methods of handling data and combining results, including measures of consistency.
[Yes]

P15
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors did not mention any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence, such as publication bias or selective reporting.
[No]

P16
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors did not describe any additional analyses.
[No]

P17
Quote: See Figure 1 flow diagram.
Reasoning: The authors provided a flow diagram with the numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included.
[Yes]

P18
Quote: See Tables 1 and 2.
Reasoning: The authors presented the characteristics of the included studies in table format with citations.
[Yes]

P19
Quote: "Each included article was appraised by three reviewers (GJ, LZL and TQS), who assessed the methodological quality of the selected studies independently."
Reasoning: The authors assessed the risk of bias but did not present the detailed results for each study.
[No]

P20
Quote: See Figures 2 and 3.
Reasoning: The authors presented the results for each study with summary data and effect estimates with confidence intervals in forest plots.
[Yes]

P21
Quote: See Figures 2 and 3.
Reasoning: The authors presented the results of each meta-analysis with confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
[Yes]

P22
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors did not present any assessment of risk of bias across studies.
[No]

P23
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors did not report any additional analyses.
[No]

P24
Quote: "In this meta-analysis, we demonstrate that the operative time, time to resume feeding and full activity is similar between LO and OO. Although the hospital stay of LO was slightly shorter than that of OO, this benefit may be less significant due to the one day basis of both procedures in most centers. In addition, the recurrence, success rate and testicular atrophy were found to be comparable between LO and LO, suggesting that laparoscopy does not provide significant advantage over open surgery for treating NPT."
Reasoning: The authors summarized the main findings and their relevance to key groups.
[Yes]

P25
Quote: "Another study indicated the longer operative and anesthesia time in laparoscopic cases, due to the natural tendency that peeping testicle is considered as located in the inguinal canal during open procedure and as intra-abdominal under a laparoscope [3]. The overall rate of abdominal testes in 3 large open surgery series is approximately 40%, and there is a higher percent of absent testes in the laparoscopic series [25–27]. However, Ferro et al. [3] reported that the percentage of abdominal testes is same in laparoscopic and open surgical approaches, with a slight difference in the incidence of inguinal and absent testes."
Reasoning: The authors discussed some limitations at the study and outcome level.
[Yes]

P26
Quote: "Extensive mobilization of the spermatic vessels and the vas is one of the advantages of laparoscopy, which is very important for a successful orchiopexy [14, 31]. Conventional inguinal orchidopexy may not achieve adequate length of testicular vessels despite extensive retroperitoneal dissection and division of inferior epigastric vessels [31]. A literature review based on 64 articles containing 8,425 undescended testicles showed unsatisfactory success rates by the open procedure for intra-abdominal testes: 67% for Fowler–Stevens, 77% for staged Fowler–Stevens, 81% for transabdominal, and 84% for intravascular orchidopexy [19]. In contrast, the success rate of laparoscopic orchiopexy (either primary or staged orchopexy) for management of abdominal NPT was reported to be greater than 90% [32–37]. Abolyosr et al. [9] reported a very similar overall success rate between OO and LO in children with peeping testes. It has been believed that compared with OO, LO may have some advantages in children with high intra-abdominal testes, because the conventional open orchidopexy may not achieve an adequate length of testicular vessels [19]. In this meta-analysis, we found no significant difference in the overall success rate and recurrence between the LO and OO groups, and the success rates were well in the range of previous studies [9, 19, 28, 38]. Combined with the fact that the total operative cost was significantly higher when laparoscopy was performed, these results may suggest that the advantages of laparoscopy could be achieved by open surgery, with a favorable cost benefit ratio. However, we noted that earlier studies reported the unnecessary open surgery following diagnostic laparoscopy [5, 10, 12]. Better conclusion can be drawn until a series of RCTs are undertaken to compare the complete LO and OO."
Reasoning: The authors provided a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27
Quote: "Acknowledgment This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (No. 30200284, No. 30600478, No. 30772359, No. 81071997, No. 81072073), Program for New Century Excellent Talents in University (NCET-06-0641), Scientific Research Foundation for the Returned Overseas Chinese Scholars (2008-889), and Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities (201010025)."
Reasoning: The authors described the sources of funding for the systematic review.
[Yes]

Quote: "After identifying relevant titles, the abstracts of these studies were read to decide if the study was eligible. Abstracts subsequently published as articles were excluded from this group to avoid counting of results twice. The full article was retrieved when the information in the title and/or abstract appeared to meet the objective of this review."
Reasoning: The authors described the process for selecting studies.
[Yes]

P10
Quote: "Three reviewers (GJ, LZL and TQS) independently assessed selected studies, extracted data from each article with a predefined data extraction form. Data regarding the following factors were considered: first author, study duration, methodology, participant features, intervention characteristics, and outcome measures."
Reasoning: The authors described the method of data extraction.
[Yes]

P11
Quote: "Data regarding the following factors were considered: first author, study duration, methodology, participant features, intervention characteristics, and outcome measures."
Reasoning: The authors listed the data items sought.
[Yes]

P12
Quote: "Each included article was appraised by three reviewers (GJ, LZL and TQS), who assessed the methodological quality of the selected studies independently. A critical review checklist of the Dutch Cochrane Centre was used to appraise the RCTs [de-Cochrane-centrum.nl, Last updated July 2010]. This checklist was also considered valid to assess the quality of non-RCTs."
Reasoning: The authors described the methods used to assess risk of bias in the individual studies.
[Yes]

P13
Quote: "Weighted mean differences (WMDs) and ORs were used for the continuous and dichotomous outcome variables, respectively."
Reasoning: The authors stated the principal summary measures.
[Yes]

P14
Quote: "Statistical analyses were performed using the Review Manager 4.2.10 Software (The Cochrane Collaboration, Oxford, UK). Statistical heterogeneity was assessed using the I2 statistics. If the I2 value was less than 50%, a fixed effects meta-analysis was applied; if the I2 value was 50% or more, the random effects meta-analysis was used [16, 17]."
Reasoning: The authors described the methods of handling data and combining results, including measures of consistency.
[Yes]

P15
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors did not mention any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence, such as publication bias or selective reporting.
[No]

No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors did not describe any additional analyses.
[No]

P17

Reasoning: The authors provided a flow diagram with the numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included.
[Yes]

P18
Quote: See Tables 1 and 2.
Reasoning: The authors presented the characteristics of the included studies in table format with citations.
[Yes]

P19
Quote: "Each included article was appraised by three reviewers (GJ, LZL and TQS), who assessed the methodological quality of the selected studies independently."
Reasoning: The authors assessed the risk of bias but did not present the detailed results for each study.
[No]

P20
Quote: See Figures 2 and 3.
Reasoning: The authors presented the results for each study with summary data and effect estimates with confidence intervals in forest plots.
[Yes]

[Yes]

No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors did not present any assessment of risk of bias across studies.
[No]

P23
No relevant quotes found.
Reasoning: The authors did not report any additional analyses.
[No]

P24
Quote: "In this meta-analysis, we demonstrate that the operative time, time to resume feeding and full activity is similar between LO and OO. Although the hospital stay of LO was slightly shorter than that of OO, this benefit may be less significant due to the one day basis of both procedures in most centers. In addition, the recurrence, success rate and testicular atrophy were found to be comparable between LO and LO, suggesting that laparoscopy does not provide significant advantage over open surgery for treating NPT."
Reasoning: The authors summarized the main findings and their relevance to key groups.
[Yes]

P25
Quote: "Another study indicated the longer operative and anesthesia time in laparoscopic cases, due to the natural tendency that peeping testicle is considered as located in the inguinal canal during open procedure and as intra-abdominal under a laparoscope [3]. The overall rate of abdominal testes in 3 large open surgery series is approximately 40%, and there is a higher percent of absent testes in the laparoscopic series [25–27]. However, Ferro et al. [3] reported that the percentage of abdominal testes is same in laparoscopic and open surgical approaches, with a slight difference in the incidence of inguinal and absent testes."
Reasoning: The authors discussed some limitations at the study and outcome level.
[Yes]

P26
Quote: "Extensive mobilization of the spermatic vessels and the vas is one of the advantages of laparoscopy, which is very important for a successful orchiopexy [14, 31]. Conventional inguinal orchidopexy may not achieve adequate length of testicular vessels despite extensive retroperitoneal dissection and division of inferior epigastric vessels [31]. A literature review based on 64 articles containing 8,425 undescended testicles showed unsatisfactory success rates by the open procedure for intra-abdominal testes: 67% for Fowler–Stevens, 77% for staged Fowler–Stevens, 81% for transabdominal, and 84% for intravascular orchidopexy [19]. In contrast, the success rate of laparoscopic orchiopexy (either primary or staged orchopexy) for management of abdominal NPT was reported to be greater than 90% [32–37]. Abolyosr et al. [9] reported a very similar overall success rate between OO and LO in children with peeping testes. It has been believed that compared with OO, LO may have some advantages in children with high intra-abdominal testes, because the conventional open orchidopexy may not achieve an adequate length of testicular vessels [19]. In this meta-analysis, we found no significant difference in the overall success rate and recurrence between the LO and OO groups, and the success rates were well in the range of previous studies [9, 19, 28, 38]. Combined with the fact that the total operative cost was significantly higher when laparoscopy was performed, these results may suggest that the advantages of laparoscopy could be achieved by open surgery, with a favorable cost benefit ratio. However, we noted that earlier studies reported the unnecessary open surgery following diagnostic laparoscopy [5, 10, 12]. Better conclusion can be drawn until a series of RCTs are undertaken to compare the complete LO and OO."
Reasoning: The authors provided a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27
Quote: "Acknowledgment This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (No. 30200284, No. 30600478, No. 30772359, No. 81071997, No. 81072073), Program for New Century Excellent Talents in University (NCET-06-0641), Scientific Research Foundation for the Returned Overseas Chinese Scholars (2008-889), and Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities (201010025)."
Reasoning: The authors described the sources of funding for the systematic review.
[Yes]

llm_message:
A1
Quote: "We systematically reviewed the pediatric literature."
Reasoning: The research question and inclusion criteria were not explicitly established before conducting the review.
[No]

A2
Quotes: "Incidences of recurrent appendicitis, complications after IA, and carcinoid tumor were estimated accounting for interstudy heterogeneity. Cost and length of stay of IA were analyzed."
"Data relating to the risk of recurrence of appendicitis, morbidity of IA, unexpected histopathologic findings after IA, and cost were extracted independently by 2 reviewers."
Reasoning: Study selection and data extraction were performed in duplicate.
[Yes]

A3
Quotes: "A Medline search was performed using the keywords appendix mass, interval appendicectomy, and children from January 1964 to July 2009 to identify reports of successful nonoperative treatment of AM in children (<16 years)."
"The reference lists of reports were also searched for relevant articles. Titles, abstracts, and full text reports were analyzed."
Reasoning: Only one database (Medline) was searched, but reference lists were also checked. Search terms were provided but the full search strategy was not.
[No]

Reasoning: The inclusion of grey literature was not specified.
[No]

A5
Reasoning: A list of included studies was not provided. Excluded studies were not mentioned.
[No]

A6
Quote: "Data relating to the risk of recurrence of appendicitis, morbidity of IA, unexpected histopathologic findings after IA, and cost were extracted independently by 2 reviewers."
Reasoning: Some characteristics of included studies were provided in an aggregated form, but details on participants, interventions and outcomes for each study were lacking.
[No]

A7
Reasoning: The scientific quality of included studies was not assessed.
[No]

Reasoning: Not applicable as the scientific quality of included studies was not assessed.
[NA]

Reasoning: Heterogeneity was accounted for in the analysis. However, this item is not applicable as no meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

[NA]

Reasoning: Sources of support for the systematic review and included studies were not reported.
[No]

P1
Quote: "Is interval appendicectomy justified after successful nonoperative treatment of an appendix mass in children? A systematic review"  
Reasoning: The title identifies the article as a systematic review.
[Yes]

P2
Quote: See structured abstract on first page.
Reasoning: A structured abstract with labeled sections is provided.
[Yes]

P3
Quote: "Inflammation in acute appendicitis may be enclosed by the omentum and adjacent loops of bowel, resulting in the formation of an inflammatory mass known as an appendix mass (AM). A recent meta-analysis estimated that approximately 9% of all children with acute appendicitis have an inflammatory mass at presentation [1]."
Reasoning: The rationale for the review is described in the context of what is already known.
[Yes]

P4
Quote: "The purpose of this systematic review was to evaluate the evidence for IA in children after successful nonoperative treatment of an AM based on the current available literature."
Reasoning: The review question is stated but does not explicitly reference the PICOS elements.
[No]

Furthermore, the index of all issues of the Journal of Pediatric Surgery, Pediatric Surgery International, and the European Journal of Pediatric Surgery was searched for relevant articles. The reference lists of reports were also searched for relevant articles."
Reasoning: The information sources searched are described, but the date last searched is not provided for all sources.
[No]

P8
Reasoning: The full search strategy is not presented for any of the databases.
[No]

P9
Quote: "Titles, abstracts, and full text reports were analyzed. Only reports comparing IA with nonoperative expectant management in children after successful nonoperative treatment of an AM were initially filtered."
Reasoning: The study selection process is described.
[Yes]

P10
Quote: "Data relating to the risk of recurrence of appendicitis, morbidity of IA, unexpected histopathologic findings after IA, and cost were extracted independently by 2 reviewers."
Reasoning: The data extraction process is described, including the number of reviewers.
[Yes]

P11
Reasoning: The data items for which data were sought are not clearly defined.
[No]

P12
Reasoning: Methods for assessing risk of bias in individual studies are not described.
[No]

[NA]

Reasoning: Not applicable as no meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

Reasoning: Assessment of risk of bias across studies is not mentioned. However, this item is not applicable as no meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P16
Reasoning: Additional analyses are not described. However, this item is not applicable as no meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P17
Quote: "Twenty-three studies reported outcome after IA. All but 1 [9] were retrospective reviews. Seventeen studies reported histopathologic findings of IA specimens, and 12 reported data relating to the risk of recurrence of appendicitis, morbidity of IA, unexpected histopathologic findings after IA, and cost were extracted independently by 2 reviewers."
Reasoning: The number of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included is not fully reported, and a flow diagram is not provided.
[No]

P18
Reasoning: Characteristics of individual studies are not presented.
[No]

P19
Reasoning: Risk of bias of individual studies is not reported.
[No]

P20
Reasoning: Results for each study are not reported individually. However, this item is not applicable as no meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P21
Reasoning: Not applicable as no meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P22
Reasoning: Not applicable as no meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P23
Reasoning: Not applicable as no meta-analysis was performed.
[NA]

P24
Quote: "The most significant finding of this review is that, despite the relative frequency of the condition, we have been unable to identify any data comparing routine IA with a "watchful waiting" approach nor any prospective data relating to the risk of recurrent appendicitis in children. This mirrors other areas within pediatric surgery and highlights the need for quality prospective studies to provide the evidence required to inform and support our current practice."
Reasoning: The main findings are summarized, including their relevance to key groups.
[Yes]

P25
Quote: "Although these data suggest that hospital stay in the region of 3 days would be required, we acknowledge that, with current surgical practice of laparoscopic IA, this may be an overestimate [10,12]. The alternative watchful waiting approach carries a 1 in 5 risk of developing recurrent appendicitis and a very small risk (<1%) of missing a carcinoid tumor."
Reasoning: Some limitations at the review level are discussed.
[Yes]

P26
Quote: "When considering whether to perform an IA or not, the surgeon, parents, and, in some cases, the child are faced with choosing between the 2 approaches. The approach of performing an IA carries the benefit of removing the risk of recurrent appendicitis but at the cost of a hospital admission for a surgical procedure with a risk of complications. The alternative watchful waiting approach avoids an IA but carries with it a risk of recurrent appendicitis, requiring hospital treatment and likely an emergency operation, and, if this does not occur, then a risk of there being an underlying diagnosis, which has not been identified. Both approaches carry a cost implication. Once accurate data relating to each aspect of these 2 approaches are known, only then can a truly informed decision be made by surgeon and parents alike."
Reasoning: A general interpretation of the results is provided, along with implications for future research.
[Yes]

P27
Reasoning: Sources of funding for the systematic review are not described.
[No]
